content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												hi! this review mainly serves to inform buyers about the differences between the PC version of this game, and the console version which it is a port version of.i have played both PC and console (PS3) versions of the game. i played the PS3 version at launch and PC version this year.PC Pros:+ ALICE supports graphics enhancing injectors such as SweetFX, so if you are comfortable using this type of program and have the specs for it, you can have a higher graphical quality experience than is at all possibly attainable on the PS3 (and despite the slightly outdated graphics, this is still an awesome game from an aesthetic perspective!)+ if your hobby is sceenshotting games, or even recording gameplay videos, it's probably a no-brainer due to this that you would want a PC copy of ALICE simply because it's a lot more convenient and doesn't rely on the preset specs of a clunky console.+ if you don't mind adding some quick lines of code (see comments for how) to the config files of the game (which you can do with any txt-type word processor) this will also unlock many preset outfits for Alice to wear as alternates to her story-mode outfits, and these come with interesting buffs and debuffs (for harder and easier mode play)+ in general: the emotiveness, clever dialogue and creativity of the entire game is ever-present, and both the combat and noncombat scenarios are often blissfully relaxing as they are at other times a trifle vexing.PC Cons:- the game was supposed to come with a "bonus" hidden file containing the original American McGee's Alice game in addition to ALICE MADNESS... unfortunately, most copies of the game don't, and this apparently includes both origin & steam digital versions. a physical copy of the game called "complete collection" is the only way to get the 1st game bundled with this one (thanks @groen90)- unfortunately this game is licensed to Electronic Arts, which means it comes with a ton of awkward and invasive DRM, including the requirement to make an EA/ Origin account. i had no problem registering for this but nobody likes DRM, and nobody likes EA.- there is an UNPATCHED and potentially GAMEBREAKING bug relating to the 'Umbrella' weapon that some, but not all, players will encounter with the PC version. this bug is usually caused by remapping the keybindings from default to *anything else* but if you are prepared to deal with it, you CAN fix the bug and play with custom binds (which i do)this bug has been around for 4+ years and never fixed by EA, so if you plan to buy this game then *PLEASE* be prepared to deal with it as it may occur around the 20~60 minutes of play mark depending on how fast you go through the game world.there are many fixes for this bug, but it will require you to rewrite some lines of code in the .cfg files and do a bit of gametesting (it happened to me, but with help from the internet it was self-fixed and i have been playing with no errors ever since)i don't remember this bug being existent on the PS3 version of Alice. i do love this game, but hopefully these things will help you make your mind up. review may be addended later to be more concise~

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												I like how the developers took a more "animated" style for this (though some may not). The colors in the backgrounds and scenery can range from absolutely breath-taking, to horrifically morbid (in a good way). The character and level design is also very unique and while somewhat cartoonish, this only helps serve the purpose of resulting in a very creative and imaginative piece of art.Now, despite it's beauty, the game is also filled to the brim with what we all want: violence! It pretty much is a "hack-n-slash," type game, however there are also plenty of power-ups and abilities that can be used to "spice things up" a bit.Platforming feels solid. Double jumping not only looks beautiful with a cool graphical flourish but the "float" ability that allows you to glide and string multiple double jumps together is useful and cool to look at. The fighting is also done really well. I like dedicated melee and ranged buttons that allow the combat to flow seamlessly instead of constantly switching weapons back & forth as the situation and enemies demand a major improvement over the first. Theres also a dodge/dash ability that's both very useful and is awesome to look at. Locking on to enemies to and being able to change to another target during battle is very useful.The environments were stunning, from a beautiful forest, to menacing castle, and even the streets of London! Most games stick to one theme, such as being dark and scary to the end, or bright and happy, etc. Alice: MR had instances of gorgeous and serene, contrasting to the dark and ominous. They were the things of a beautiful, daydreaming nightmare!If your idea of a good game is one that involves stultifying realism, empty action, and hollywood cliches then odds are that you will not like this game. If your tastes go beyond that to the appreciation of literature, art, and above all imagination then this game should prove to be quite satisfactory.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Short Version:Pros:+ Beautiful art design+ Interesting story+Controlling Alice feels great+Combat stays fresh for most of the game+ Enemies' design is amazing+ Voice acting is mostly good throughout the game+ Tons of collectibles+ Cool weapons+ Great soundtrack+ Weapon upgradesCons:- Repetitive puzzles- Stale platforming- Annoying camera- Level design is as linear as linear gets- Tons of invisible walls- Some game breaking bugs - Getting stuck, getting knocked down and never getting up again (which means you will not die and have to restart)- Impressively boring if played for more than 20/30 minutes (longer periods of play)- The absence of the original's weapons still haunts me (Deck of Cards, Jacks, Demon Dice, etc.)"Long" Version:When you start playing "Alice Madness Returns", it is quite evident that its art design is unique and downright beautiful. Personally, I think this game is already worth checking out at least once just for its art direction. It starts out with beautiful, calm and bright landscapes - which are really colorful and highly detailed; once♥♥♥♥♥♥starts hitting the fan, that beautiful Wonderland turns into something ghastly, corrupted and quite disturbing - the catch is, it's equally appealing. As stated, eye-candy is abundant from start to finish and you will have many opportunities to catch your breath and take some beautiful screenshots.Platforming is a big part of "Alice Madness Returns" and it seems it gets worse as the game goes on. The problem is that one can only pull so many levers before getting bored. The level design plays a vital role here; it is extremely linear and you are pretty much getting from point A to point B with little to no side objectives - collectibles alleviate this by making you go off your main path; unfortunately, by the end of the game, you will most likely find yourself ignoring some (if not most) of them, since they required YET another lever and a couple more jumps and floats.Story-wise, this game shines. The story is nothing to write home about but it does a decent enough job of making you wanting to keep playing - I guess it ends quite abruptly but still, it's good in my opinion. It manages to keep you invested in Alice's "quest" and the use of "Alice in Wonderland"'s characters was refreshing (even though the first game did it better).Voice acting is, as said, really good. You meet your fair share of looney characters with high pitched voices and your dark enemies have intimidating voices and sound effects. The soundtrack is great. I think it is the kind of soundtrack I would buy if it was available. Weapon sounds also feels great as you cut enemies in halt and fill their♥♥♥♥♥♥s with (peppered) lead.Combat stays fresh for most of the game. Enemies require different strategies to be defeated and later on there are multiple types of enemies at the same time which requires you to adapt accordingly to the enemies weaknesses.You have 4 weapons (or 5 if you count the umbrella) at your disposal and, even though I wanted more weapons, including some from the original game, they are enough to keep the combat engaging. Being able to upgrade them with Teeth (in-game currency) is also a bonus since you can turn your fluffy looking Hobby Horse into a full-fledged fire breathing stallion of punishment and death or your traditional Pepper Grinder into a.... full-fledged fire breathing... cooking..... tool.... ..... of punishment and death.However, the camera tends to flip out during combat and changing targets is a shore, usually costing you a chunk of your health.Invisible walls are everywhere, some small holes and gaps where Alice could easily fit in are regarded as impossible to cross and, considering the game is "quite" recent, it is something I found both annoying and disappointing. They are everywhere.I made a mistake while playing this game. I thought "I am going to play this for 2 or 3 hours" and let me tell you that it is something I sincerely do not recommend you to do.Most levels go like this: Jump, jump, jump and float; pull a lever/switch; more platforms show up; you can jump some more just to pull yet another lever; once you reach a bigger platform, you will have a battle; once you finish off all the enemies, more platforms show up. You then put a Bomb on a pressure pad so the platforms don't disappear and make your way to the other side well before the bomb detonates; then you will jump some more and pull some more levers... Sounds repetitive? That's because it is! I believe, after the first 2 hours or, let's say, 2/3 levels, this game gets on your nerves fairly quickly. I recommend it in short bursts.But still, this may sound bad and all but Alice moves so effortlessly that the platforming sections feel graceful. It feels great even though it eventually gets boring.Some other bugs break the experience a little bit. One example is when you jump on a mushroom (it acts like a trampoline), you can only move again once Alice reaches the top of her ascension and starts falling down again; if you were pressing forward when you were going up, you will need to press it again after Alice starts descending so she moves forward - have fun dying because of it, since you will find yourself wasting extra jumps in the air while standing still.For me, "Alice Madness Returns" is a big disappointment, yet, I can't bring myself to hate it.Here's the thing: I wanted to like this game. Unfortunately, I found myself getting frustrated and bored for a big chunk of its 14 or so hours of story.Is it worth buying? Not for 10 €. I would suggest 75% off, considering the game's age. But still, if you like engaging stories and value art design in video games, 5 € should be ok as well. It is a game everyone should experience at least once!As far as replay value goes... I think you will only be playing this once.This game had so much potential. It could have been something as epic as "Batman: Arkham City". That's what makes me sad.Score: 6.5 out of 10.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												When American McGee's Alice[en.wikipedia.org] came out in 2000, it was one of many shots in the arm that gaming received back then (the original Half-Life and Deus Ex to name a couple), showcasing the idea that videogames could aim for higher and higher levels of creativity and ambition. The mythology of Alice, Lewis Carroll's inquisitive young heroine thrust into a psychedelic kaleidoscope of strange yet unsettlingly familiar characters, has changed hands and changed costumes many, many times since Carroll penned Alice's Adventures In Wonderland[en.wikipedia.org] and Through The Looking-Glass, and What Alice Found There[en.wikipedia.org] at the end of the 19th century. I personally love the original story and that's pretty much where my head first goes when Alice is mentioned. I don't think the gentle whimsy of Carroll's writing can ever be matched when it comes to the denizens and riddles of Wonderland. But even the malevolent nonsense of the poem "Jabberwocky"[www.jabberwocky.com], for example, never saw anything like American McGee's vision of Wonderland. The original game took many of the story's elements and twisted them up in fantastically demented ways and delivered the New and Improved Alice to us with flashy, blistering combat and a dark tone that was most certainly a product and an extension of the 1990s with their Hot Topic meets The Crow meets The Matrix mélange of gothy, trendy edginess. I'm not knocking that (okay, I am a little) because God knows I was cheerfully invested in it myself back then, but it is what it is. So, with that out of the way, enter Alice: Madness Returns.I can't really talk about the story too much without spoiling anything, but this isn't really a spoiler if you happened to notice the actual title of the game, so let's just say our gal Alice is, in fact, nuts. Insane in the membrane. Mad, you could say. And as she winds her way alternately through a dirty, dark London skid-row and a troubled, hurriedly collapsing Wonderland on a quest to solve a mystery and save her sanity, it becomes obvious, like in the first game, that as bonkers as she is, there are crazier -- and scarier -- things about, oh yes. Which is of course the main draw of a game like this. How bizarre can we get? Well, let's see. There's steampunk taxidermy gone horribly wrong, various ill-thought ways to use baby dollheads, an impressively grotesque and bloody take on The Walrus and The Carpenter, an entire level that feels like the drug-addled fever dream of M.C. Escher and Wes Craven locked in some padded cell together, and I think you even walk through a giant mouth at one point. And not in a Disneyland kind of way. Concerning the neverending search for weird♥♥♥♥♥♥ Alice delivers whole-heartedly. (Imagine me saying that while holding a pink, veiny, pulsing heart while twitching and grinning insanely.)As spectacle, it satisfies. I loved the originality of the levels and the many, many weirdnesses it serves up. I won't say anything about the story because, no real way around it, it does take a second place to the gameworld, the atmosphere, and the characters, but it doesn't help that it's really not all that great to begin with. It doesn't do anything necessarily wrong, and the voice acting is pretty good (especially Alice's), but it doesn't really do anything amazingly right, either. It's pretty much what you'd expect if you've played the previous installment. Disappointing, a bit, but whatever. Again, the story can be excused for taking a backseat to the visuals just because of the game that it is.Combat and gameplay... oh boy. Good points: melee feels GREAT. I want a Vorpal Blade in real life. I never got tired of dancing and blitzing that blade through the air. It's great fun. Other weapons are good too, in varying degrees, but sending Alice dodging through enemy attacks to be able to slash viciously back at them and then dodging away, in a beautifully animated burst of indigo butterflies, never ever gets old. Ranged combat? Not... so... great. Irritating controls requiring quick-switching targeting modes that also partially disable your camera make for some very frustrating battles, especially ones involving tons of airborne and ground enemies at once. No, sir, I do not like it.But then again, the Vorpal Blade is really, really sweet. So it's a mixed bag. And that honestly sums up my overall feelings on the game because while, like I already said, the levels are visually fantastic and new, the levels are also INCREDIBLY long and drawn-out. I mean, I like getting a lot of game for my money, but there's a point where you can almost hear the devs running out of ideas for a certain level or world and sad to say the game just sails right past that point into exasperated tedium. But that's me. Your mileage may vary, and very possibly will.In the end, this has everything you'd expect from a concerted effort to take your childhood and turn it inside-out and sideways and then tell you to kill it and smash it and blow it to shreds. As Alice herself might say, "Curiouser and curiouser! And completely covered in blood."

												A beautiful game. I truly mean every word when I say: Every environment is stylized, enchanting, made of peculiar objects born within Alice's mind. It makes truly amazing and unique landscapes. The enemies too are very well done.The music is amazing too, many songs I will remember.It has flaws, the combat, while fairly fun, is simple, there are few combos, you can change between your melee weapons while hitting, so it's nothing disastrous, it's fairly solid, but it does get repetitive. The game is also plagued with random minigame segments. Thanks to EA pushing the studio for early release.Still, the game is amazing, the story is one of the most ballsy a game could have. It is one of my favorites. Get this small masterpiece.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												The overall quality of Alice: Madness Returns is high, despite it feeling rushed. The qualities that made American McGee's Alice so enjoyable-the gory hack-'n'-slash combat, the gorgeous design, the rich dialogue, the menacing mood-are present and abundant.Alice: Madness Returns is a dream come true for fans of American McGee's Alice. It's a worthy heir and at the same time a fully modern game that can vie with the best contemporary representatives of this genre. It's long, it's difficult, it's rewarding and enchanting.Alice: Madness Returns is a wolf in sheep's clothing. This game may look honest and cute, but it's cruel and bloody.Alice: Madness Returns may not win awards for genre innovation, but it's the most darkly fun and gloriously batty game I've played.It's not perfect, but it's as close to the definition of masterpiece as it could be. A thrilling and exciting adventure to the dark corners of Wonderland.

												A frantic third person action game featuring a darker version of Lewis Carrol's Alice. Or maybe it was already dark enough until disney molested the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of it because you know, for kids. The sequel picks up years after the original where Alice is a grown woman now, having defeated the madness that plagued her mind. Or so it seems. Wherever it lacks in variety and innovation, it makes up with numerous gorgeous places to explore, bizzare characters and enemies to meet, and a captivating story that unfolds itself through Alice's madness in the most beautiful and sinister way at the same time. American McGee did it again just like he did with the original game over a decade ago. A must for the fans of the original; newcomers, tread carefully.7/8

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
Alice: Madness Returns ReviewGame DetailsPublished by: Electronic ArtsDeveloped by: Spicy HorseGenre: Action/AdventureRelease Date: 17 Jun, 2011Metacritic Score: 75 (Link[www.metacritic.com])Game Review"I'm not insane! I didn't kill my family. I am fine. I'm not mad, I'm innocent - I mean, not guilty!" - AliceWhat a little gem this is. In Alice: Madness Returns you control Alice Liddell, a girl who suffers from an emotional trauma caused by the death of her parents. To get rid of the trauma and learn the truth of her past, she once falls again into Wonderland, where a new evil force has corrupted it.The strongest attribute of this game is Wonderland itself. This creepy and dark vision of Wonderland is beautifully recreated in this game. The art design in it is top notch, and graphical wise it does it job well, even though there are some places here and there with some ugly textures. As you progress the game you will get to new areas of Wonderland, each one of it with its art style, which makes it feel less repetitive. Menus are also slick, easy to navigate, a negative being that in video menu you have almost no options of configuring the game graphically, you have to do your tweaks through the config file unfortunately.Sound is also pretty good, nothing mind blowing, but it does its job well enough. The voice acting its great as the soundtrack, but the second one can get repetitive very often.Gameplay wise, which its the most important factor in a game to me, is where this game falls a little flat. Controls are great, smooth and easy to use (I used a ps3 controller[/b]). Length is also a strong point in this game. Its not huge, but it is almost the perfect length to keep you interested during the game, with tons of collectibles to catch and areas to find. I spent about 12 hours to complete it and did not get all the collectibles, only about an half of them. You also have a neat diversity of weapons which make the combat more fun.Now to the negative things in the gameplay. The worse part its that the game gets very repetitive because it does not evolve much from the start. At some point, you will get to do the same tasks all over again till the end which makes the game a bit boring sometimes. Also the puzzles and other tasks to change the pace of the game are not very fun. Even less fun when they also start to get repetitive.The combat is very fluid and responsive, fast paced as well with a good variety of horrendous enemies to confront, but once you master it it becomes very easy.Acrobatics are also well done, which makes the navigation in Wonderland very smooth though jumps (even double-jumps and triple-jumps), floating and shrinking.The story is also one of the strongest attributes of the game, being amazing. Its full of interesting characters, riddles and surprising reveals.Game performance is pretty good, I played it on a laptop and only had 4 or 5 fps drops through the game. Its locked at 30 fps, but you can easily change that in the config files.Summary:Pros: - Beautiful dark version of Wonderland- Top notch art style- Smooth and easy to use controls- Great length- Amazing storyCons: - Tedious gameplay and puzzles- Steam version does not come bundled with the original game "America McGee's Alice"My personal score:  8.0If you love action/adventure and platform games play this gem, there arent many platform games on steam, so if you are into that genre this is a good bet. The awesome story and setting of this game will make you forget about the boring gameplay, and you will have an amazing experience for a game that gets very cheap in steam sales (I got it for 2.50 euro if I am not mistaken).

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
												TLDR: Game is beautiful, story is intresting and atmospheric, but gameplay streches too long and some parts will be boring and monotone - game is often on sale, a -75% usual one is GREAT to pick the game up. Don't bother with full price, I don't think it's worth it.According to Steam I've played this for the whopping amount of 36.9 hours - ingame timer says 16 hours, 91% completion.About this game: picked up a copy for a friend to return a friendly gesture and at the same time I bought it for myself, because I was really intrested in it (Alice + implementation of madness? Yes please, I'm in!)The game starts out wonderful. You'll keep making screenshots - the game world is really nicely designed and well-executed, some landscapes are jaw-dropping both in terms of quality and creativity.Platforming works great, there are no issues with controls - but after a time it can be boring, because most chapters (5 looong chapters, all in 1-2 different settings than the others) use quite the same mechanics/ideas as precious ones, only re-skinned.Combat is both lacking and feels rewarding. Why?  Personally I really miss combos and airbone attacks. Maybe I'm too new for the third-person platformers, but I think while combat plays a really central part in the gameplay, it could have been much better.  And why is it still great? You have 4 weapons - basically a light and heavy variant of melee and ranged. As most things, the weapons look astonishingly good, with real nice sound - and visual effects. But the biggest and best thing of combat system is the really different enemies. They all work in their own way - one is easy to take on with the pepper-grinder (machine gun), the other one's weakness is the heavy Hobby Horse's armor-breaking hits. Each enemy, and especially their mixed groups require different tactics to defeat them.  It's a little shame that by the time you finish a chapter, most likely you'll be bored of the enemies - the first Samurai Wasp is challenging, the third is an intresting enemy, but you'll stomp on the 8th one. Not to mention the 20th one. Level design: Gorgeous. In chapter 2? you'll go into a snowy landscape, to end up in a ship-in-a-bottle, only to get it sunk then continue your journey underwater. Another chapter is all about Japan and the East - koi pond, china-landscape, traditional fans.  Chapter 4 and 5 are just incredible and maybe the best ones from the game, both in terms of gameplay and design. If only chapter 2 and 3 would be similarly good.Though there is one thing that can put a dent on the experience: invisible walls everywhere. You can't touch most of the walls because you'll stop running ~ 30 cm before them, you can't jump on most things because pleasantly placed invisible ~2-3 metre tall "boxes" are placed on them because you only can jump on something you're *supposed* to jump on. It's a shame in a game from 2011.Minigames! There are various minigames/ tasks in the game you need to complete to continue: chess puzzle, sliding blocks puzzle, shoot 'em up game, sidescrolling platformer, guitar-hero like small puzzles.. I haven't expected this much variation, it's a really strong positive of the game. Collectibles: Collecting memories gives you a small quote (1-2 sentence) from a specific character of the story that deepens the main story. Even though they are quite conveniently placed and easy to find/get most of them, this makes collecting them really rewarding.  Game lacks backtracing at several points of the game, making impossible to get the stuff at the other side of the crossroads if you took the correct one  - without chapter selection. What a pity.Afterall, all I can do is to recommend this game. It has several really strong aspects, while the weakest points aren't worse than "average".   Previously I thought it's a silly suggestion, but *Good Guy Nick* is right - playing the game for more than an hour can induce a strong feeling if monotonicity. I feel like most chapters should be 10-20% shorter, because while there are enough action, jumping and fighting to fill the gametime, there is not that much "soul" in the game to keep the gamer playing for longer periods.  At the end, it was a nice - after how bad is EA's reputation in recent times, it was refreshing and pleasantly surprising to see a really creative and daring game under their name.

												Alice: Madness Returns is a solid game. Stunning and imaginative scenery, 


Alice: Madness Returns 
A Screenshot of Alice: Madness Returns
By: XJ9




spine-tingling music, good combat and platformer elements, witty, creepy, and in general fun to play. I've got a boat load of time logged on the game, granted, I believe a decent amount is on pause... >.>... but that's between you and I; However, it really is a fun game that you can lose yourself in. The boss fights are very spiffy, can be challenging (which is a bonus IMO), and the pace of the game is good. Little to no learning curve, you just hop right in and start killing things. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=250991152Combat throughout the game changes as you get new weapons, so there's a bit of variety as the game progesses. Also, get your screenshot trigger finger ready, because there's plenty of awesome stuff to snap pics of while you're playing!If you haven't, consider playing the original game as well. American McGee & Spicy Horse did a kickass job on both games, and they're both definitely worth having in your arsenal of games. http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=252748888Solid 9/10. One of my faves. Just a unique game everybody should try at least once.

content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												If you want this game because you think it's a cutesy little Alice in Wonderland game, then don't buy this game. If you want it because you want to play as a crazed lunatic who battles the demons in her head in a last ditch attempt to safe herself from insanity, and recover the truth about the death of her parents, then get a move on and get it, because it is frickin' brilliant.American Mcgee's twisted art style is just perfect for this game, and whilst some people might start finding the gameplay a little tedious towards the end, I think the combat is very well done, and the world surrounding you should make you want to carry on and see what other crazy things are gonna happen. As well as the art you've got a bunch of collectibles to find, like bottles, memories and flying pig snouts. (Literally). Alice also has the ability to shrink herself, revealing platforms and passages, which is downright awesome. It's games like this that make the real world seem pointless.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Since it's on sale at the moment (Steam Summer Sale 2014), I figured I'd write a quick review. Alice: Madness Returns is a solid game. Stunning and imaginative scenery, spine-tingling music, good combat and platformer elements, witty, creepy, and in general fun to play. I've got a boat load of time logged on the game, granted, I believe a decent amount is on pause... >.>... but that's between you and I; However, it really is a fun game that you can lose yourself in. The boss fights are very spiffy, can be challenging (which is a bonus IMO), and the pace of the game is good. Little to no learning curve, you just hop right in and start killing things. Combat throughout the game changes as you get new weapons, so there's a bit of variety as the game progesses. Also, get your screenshot trigger finger ready, because there's plenty of awesome stuff to snap pics of while you're playing!If you haven't, consider playing the original game as well. American McGee & Spicy Horse did a kickass job on both games, and they're both definitely worth having in your arsenal of games. Solid 9/10. One of my faves. Just a unique game everybody should try at least once.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												I invite you to a world where there is no such thing as time. And every creature lends themselves to change your state of mind...I finished this game about a week ago and for an old game it's pretty damn good tbh. Alice's past is pretty harsh and she dwells on it all the time thus her wonderland is falling apart.. again. And she must go into the depths of her mind to find the problem that's scratching at her sanity and execute it.I absolutely loved the scenery and artwork of this game the most. The levels were not too long but not too short either. And each chapter has so many secret rooms and hidden items. The storyline could have been a bit more compelling but it was still pretty good imo. It does have some decent plot twists. The game definitely has a pretty creepy feel to it and the enemies seem like something out of a horror movie as well. Some enemies can be very frustrating at first but once you get a good system on how to kill them then it's not so bad. The puzzles in the game were definitely a wide variety of fun, like how they should be in most games. They weren't too easy and they weren't so hard and/or confusing that it would just♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. One of my favorite aspects of the game were the weapons. Which you can also upgrade the weapons over time by collecting teeth. The characters in the game were just awesome. Ofc you have the ones you know like Mad Hatter, The Queen, Chester Cat, etc. The voice acting was spot on to the character's personalities as well and very good facial expressions.Another thing I thought was a really nice touch, was Alice's outfits. Each chapter she would change into a different dress and they would match the scenery of the current level. Also. I would eat Alice's green eyes. Even though I have green eyes myself, but... I just like her eyeballs. ಠ_ಠ The only complaint I really have about the game is that it can be a bit buggy. Sometimes when you kill an enemy it might move about like it's still kickin, but the game is just being derpy and the enemy will just disappear eventually. The only bug I had a real issue with (and others had issues on it too) was on one level, Chester Cat is suppose to appear and say something but he didn't. But it was an easy fix of just restarting the chapter again and it wasn't too far into the chapter either. But keep in mind that the game is just old.Overall, I highly recommend this game. I just didn't want to stop playing it honestly. And sometimes I find myself going back to the game and playing through a level or so. Still haven't found all the secrets and missing items though. Pros: -Amazing artwork and decent graphics for how old the game is.-The characters aren't dull-Not too easy and not too hard either. Everything in this game is pretty much a good balance-There is a lot more to do in this game than just hacking and slashing, defeating bosses/waves of enemies, and cut scenes.Cons:-Can be a little buggy at times-The story could have been a *little* more compelling

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Dear Alice,I find you dark and beautiful. You took me to place that I've never seen before and yet were hauntingly familiar. Introduced me to friends that I could have sworn I had met, and yet were different and twisted. Ours could have been a love affair for the ages. Now, four years after we should have met, I've followed you down the dark and twisting road of your past. I fell in love with you at first sight. You told me the horrific story of your past and for a time I sat raptured. I have so many good things to say about you. You're smart and graceful. Your movement is like a gazelle. You showed me places M.C. Escher would be proud to call his own. And yet, and yet.The truth is Alice, you don't know when to leave. I wanted to hear your story. I wanted to visit all the dark places that you promised me that we would go. I have to admit that you delivered on your promises. Each place we went was more interesting, darker, and haunting then the last. You just wouldn't leave. Every intersting thing you showed me you had to show me three or four times. As intelligent as I find you to be, your repitition was heartbreaking. The amazing thing is that your repitition was per location, not overall. As much as I wanted every time we met to be a joy, I found myself starting to resent you. I started to wish we could just finish this part and move on to the next visage that awaited. I knew that if I stuck it out, the next local, the next piece of the puzzle of your mind that you opened up to me would be amazing. It was just such a long time between one revelation and when you would open up to me again that I started to wonder if it was worth the time I was spending getting to know you. You had so many interesting insights, so many variations on how you viewed the world I wish that I could look past your refusal to grind through each and every insight multiple times. I wish, I wish, I wish. Dear, Dear Alice. You have so much to offer. Maybe it's not you, maybe its me. If another chap came up and asked me about you I would tell him how lovely you are. I would tell him how smart and charming you can be. I fear that after a few pints I would probably tell him that I just had a hard time with how long you would drag through any given situation. That the revelations were inticing, but the fluff between revelations didn't make me anticpate the revleations more, just make me resent the fluff.Love, KuasimoddoP.S. I am tentatively telling my friends you are a cool chick with the caveat that you waaaaay overstay your welcome.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Fantastic game. I truly recommend it. Reminiscent of early games such as Psychonauts. Mini games resemble Little Big Planet. Dollhouse level reminds me of Saw and the Jigsaw doll. The game starts to becomes a little buggy at the Oriental stage E.g. Alice's hands no longer grasps the chain when she pulls on them.You begin to see repeats and less unique creatures. E.g. Ink Wasps are Bolterflys, Wasp Samurais move like Madcaps, Baby Doll dies to plain shooting.PROS1. Great visualsThe concept behind Wonderland is truly amazing. Looking at the floating Hatter Industries, the Insidious Ruins, the crying statue, hidden pathways that can only be seen with tiny vision and the vaiety of monsters to fight against each with their own method of killing.2. CreativityAs above.3. Combat systemAmazing. Each monster is killed in a different manner giving you the feeling of a unique creature. Unlike normal hack and slash games, you have to remember each monster's pattern of attack, else you won't be able to kill them. E.g. Insidious Ruin has to be blocked when he throws a fireball or knives, dodged when he charges and attacked from range. Eyepot has to be hit with a range attack first, followed by a melee slash. Repeat twice.I was surprised to see that this game had such an amazing combat system. I was expecting a puzzle solving game instead. The dodge and block modes with the umbrella were fantastic.The Hysteria mode will give the hack and slash fans the frenetic joy they relish if they prefer not to remember patterns of attack.4. StorylineLove the story. I'm at the beginning but I can't wait to find out more.  The story gets darker as it progresses, child sexual abuse, paedophilia, child molesters masquerading as doctors, p rostituted children hypnotised to forget and used to satisfy the perversions of wealthy London clients.Steam censors the word P-R-O-S-T-I-T-U-T-E for some funny reason. Considering the type of content that they provide. It is most strange.5. MovementLove the double jump and the quick walking speed.CONS1. MovementJumping in the air is still a bit clunky especially using the air vents. Jumping in the middle of an air boost creates some problems for long distance jumping.2. Character modelsOther than Alice, most of the beginning character models (children in the hospital) are quite boring. You can see that they are repeated multiple times.3. EA AccountI do not want to create another account just to play a game. It's irritating.SuggestionsI would love to see the combat system put into an MMORPG. Hope EA and Spicy Horse Games can continue to work together on creating quality games like Alice.

Posted: November 27, 2013
IntroThe game has a very creative art style that changes throughout the game with various visuals and great atmosphere.StoryThe story is very interesting and getting the memories throughout the game to unlock more of the story itself is clever. Not only that but you are able to go back and look at the memories any time from a nice and effectively organized menu. The memories are interesting because they flesh out the personalities of the people around the main character and your understanding and roles of those individuals.GameplayThe game also offers you some rpg elements like being able to customize your equipment and upgrade what you desire. The combat itself is very fast paced, with some slow motion moments that allow you to quickly hit your dodge button to avoid attacks. ConclusionOverall the gameplay is great and fun, and so are the puzzles and challenges that become more involved the further you explore the game.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												 just finished the game today. I have no idea where to start to be honest.Let’s say I was blown away; not only by the amazing level design, but the strong moral behind the game reaches far down in the back of your mind.This game brings the true dark-side of the story of Wonderland up. Wonderland truly lives up to their motto: “We’re all mad.”Amazing graphics, stunning level design. They weren’t lazy at ALL. Every corner, every new step reveals something new to witness. Whether it’s a teapot with eyes staring from afar or a doll hanging upside down from the ceiling and black liquid substance dripping from the orifices…The drawings on the wall, dolls, skeletons and the overall lugubrious perspective of the game.The artstyle is truly amazing.Gameplay:Not your usual buttonsmash, but a hack and slash nonetheless. But you have a heavy attack, shield, range which you can upgrade over time by collecting Teeth…pretty much anything you need. There’s a lock-on system which is pretty nifty. The jumping can be a little tricky, but overall you’ll get used to it.Whomever thought this felt very repetitive: I disagree. There are a few places in the game where you’d do the same thing, the same kind of puzzle, but they are all within a good “stop” in between.I mean to say there’s a lot of platforming in between the puzzles, a lot of other things to do before doing something you’ve done before. I think it was alright, they balanced it out pretty well.Story:I love the story, and the level designs…all the drawings, props, traps, enemies, you really feel that these are all interpretations of Alice’s feelings; something that used to make you smile is now corrupted and is  turned against you.This little review of thought MIGHT contain slight spoilers:Overall, the story, it being quite the deep moral. A girl having herself blamed for something she did not do, the grudge being pushed down her throat and the endless pain and depression ever soaring through her mind. She tries to justify herself, she isn’t sick; she’s in pain. But nobody who really reaches out for her, giving her what she really needs. All but her Wonderland friends…Although they may appear threatening, or they may appear as they want to harm Alice, they’re all merely afraid of HER.She is destroying her own beautiful mind: Wonderland. They are the creatures who roam over wonderland, and she’s her own murderer - the Infernal Train is her own invention. And if it wasn’t enough, the doctor is ever more pushing it down her mind and blaming her. If one only knew the darker intentions the doctor had in mind by letting these children forget their past…They are nothing but mere numbers. They are but the mortal bodies that walk on the earth, all forgetting their “unproductive” memories. She’s not just being tortured by herself, but others around her, who suffer the same pain, have a huge influence on her as well. 10/10 from me. It’s a damn masterpiece.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												At it's heart, Alice: Madness Returns is a 3D platformer, with occasional action sequences that oscillate between (light) third-person shooter and brawler. Madness Returns is a diamond in the rough. It would have been so wonderful with more polish and time to add new original features here and there! I do not like brawlers nor third-person shooters, and yet I was able to enjoy the fights from Madness Returns. The first reason is that I gave a lot of thought to my key bindings so it feels as natural as possible despite the clunky design (it really requires too many inputs). The second reason is that the action is very tactical (at least in the higher difficulties, which I recommend) and has a great flow when the player masters the tools and weapons at use. For instance: Hit an enemy with the teapot canon to make it fall backwards and reveal its weak spot. Go in for a few slashes with the knife. Dash away to avoid another enemy trying to attack. Use the now reloaded teapot canon on that second enemy. Dash in to avoid the attack of the first enemy and quickly slash the downed second enemy. And so on. A ballet of butterflies and blades. New enemies here and there require different approaches, however the number of different enemy types is insufficient. Also, not enough true boss fights.Where the game really shines is in the environments. Chinese ceramics, doll houses, flesh castles, mushroom forests, steampunk factories: grandiose, beautiful, oozing with character and magnificence. The dark undertones of some locations is really fascinating, and builds a heavy atmosphere despite the childhood themes. Platforming and exploring in such locations is a treat for the eyes. Alice can go as far as to quadruple-jump and slow down her fall, and the levels accommodate in consequence with aerial elegance. The gameplay of these sections feels good, and is rather permissive (even dying by falling to oblivion is of little to no consequence thanks to an instant respawn onto a nearby platform), so progress flows well and the game feels like an adventure and not an hindrance. Exploration is well done, and some little traps and puzzles can add some spice to the platforming. Problem is, the levels are really big and long, and some sections can overstay their welcome. Well just one in particular in my opinion, the ice world. I would have rather preferred that they make the levels shorter and instead include some cool new ideas that got scrapped during development, but ok, this is just me yearning for more. The reality of game development is not as pretty as this game. Still, there are some sections here and there that are completely different than the main game and add variety, like a shoot-them-up or a 2D platformer, but they feel very floaty. Story-telling is not great, it feels quite disjointed. However the story itself is quite interesting, with lots of subtleties and darker themes. The person voicing Alice does a stellar job. Even though many people like them, I dislike the cutscenes that look like animated cardboard and would have preferred to see them done with the game engine. There are different costumes for Alice, some were part of a pre-order DLC or something. Thankfully they can be unlocked, but it is by editing the Windows Registry. Seriously, how annoying! And also if I remember correctly it is required to create/have an EA account of some sort to launch the game for the first time, thankfully not Origin or anything to install. But seriously, how annoying again... As a conclusion, Alice: Madness Returns is a game full of charm and character with grandiose levels to explore and a morbid undertone that builds a heavy atmosphere. Platforming and fighting is like a ballet once mastered, even if both will not please everyone: it can be argued that the platforming is too light and the fighting is clunky, and that both are repetitive. Alice is awesome, very elegant and pretty in all her dresses and movements, and she benefits from great voice acting.Overall Madness Returns lacks some polish and could have been better, but still very memorable and enjoyable as is.I liked this game so much that I finished it several times despite it being quite lengthy. I would only recommend it to people that are strongly attracted to its visuals and are not looking for state of the art game mechanics.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												This game is amazing. It's not your traditional platformer, that's for sure.Where should I start..? Probably with the best aspects of this game.The thing (that I believe) that stands out the most is the design. The game itself is like a work of art - it's a visual treat along with the interesting soundtrack and atmosphere. All the level designs are unique and they change often, keeping the player immersed and curious about the environment they are in. Sure, there are some disturbing or incredibly creepy stuff lurking around all the time, but I think that is what seals the deal. Just. Wow. I've never taken more screenshots in my life.Next would be the story. Now, I guess we don't really associate platformers with intriguing stories, but that's what makes AMR such a cohesive and linear game. As the player progresses through the story, he/she will realize why the levels are designed the way they are, why certain characters say certain things, etc. It'll all come together towards the end. Some people may think the story's a bit dramatic or just downright disturbing, but the purpose of the game is to uncover our protagonist's insanity and madness. It's GOING to be a bit provoking, at least.  But as for me, that's all the more reason to play this game.Finally the gameplay is quite smooth. Platformers need smooth controls, and I've played the first parts of this game using my keyboard, but then switched to controller (when I twiddled around with the menu and figured out it's compatible with one - just personal preference). For both methods, I think it runs fairly smooth. I've encountered a couple of problems with some levels where I had to calm down and then retry getting accross somewhere, but that just might be my technical ability to cope with the difficulties of some platformers. The only issue I really have is that camera control is relatively important in fights, but focus mode totally disregards that.  The puzzles are also pretty fun, and there are different minigames scattered here and there. It's refreshing...In conclusion I totally recommend this game. Maybe I should warn some people to not play this at night, but really, it's awesome!

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												A beautiful, creepy and surprisingly uplifting reimagination of a classic fairy tail as an unhinged girl's struggle with madness, abuse, guilt and probably puberty. Travelling between the bleak streets ov Victorian London and vivid dreamscapes of Wonderland, Alice battles imaginary nightmares and very real villains to fix her broken mind and her broken life. While as an action-adventure it is nothing special, and 3d-platforming sequences are boring and frustrating, it takes the player for an amazing journey of visions -- something that Tim Burton's version of Alice promised, but never delivered. Bittersweet, gruesome and fascinating, this game is something unique, something that every gamer should treat themself to.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
”And like a lot of dreams, there's a monster at the end of it.”A visually stunning journey into an otherwise broken mind, Alice: Madness Returns is a dark and bloody twist on the weird and wonderful world of Lewis Carroll’s classic novel. With an eerie and intense atmosphere throughout and the soundtrack reinforcing it nicely, this American adaptation is certainly a distinct shift from its source material and does not pull any punches. A morbid character study of the now adult heroine, you are thrown back into a hellish re-imagining of Wonderland, yet again corrupted by its own creator. With a similar vibe to Masochisia, (an incredibly well-made psychological horror indie that I actually wouldn’t recommend anyone play), the plot is heavily based on the symbolism of Wonderland and the slowing fragmenting parts of Alice’s mind and life. The ‘goal’, if you wish to call it that, is simple and singular: save Wonderland, and thus yourself, from oblivion.Portraying mental illness and the various (often cruel and archaic) methods of treatment in a way that’s both thematically appropriate and believable within the forms of game design is an extremely difficult task to pull off and very rarely achieved as a result. The Darkness II did it brilliantly, as did Masochisia. So though it takes a while to get going, (the final section of the game to be exact), and the painful RPG-like task grind that’s required to reach that certain point, the narrative of Alice: Madness Returns achieves a phenomenal take on a truly demented world and the inner recesses of a damaged mind. The problem here is whether or not the payoff is worth the grind.Roughly three-quarters of Alice is useless filler that pads out what could’ve been a tightly-packed masterpiece into a drawn-out and mediocre adventure game. Controls are straightforward to use but are frequently slow to respond or completely unresponsive, detracting from any possible interest one could’ve gained from the relentless platforming and puzzles. Framerate drops, texture popping and outright freezing at times is also a significant issue that plagues the game, but hey.. how about those hair physics? If McGee and the team at Spicy Horse had completely omitted the puzzles and platforming in favour of something like an intermittent walking simulator, it would’ve been to the game’s overall benefit. It was these rare sections that I actually enjoyed the most, as they were solely focused on the narrative’s progression.Combat is satisfying as hell, with some fantastic hack n’ slash, and all of the enemy types are sufficiently diverse and interesting to fight. Colour bursts out of the screen and the striking effect of the Hysteria ability in particular is reminiscent of the visual styles of Sin City and Betrayer. This really is a gorgeous game to behold; right up there with BioShock Infinite and The Witcher games.But what I certainly didn’t appreciate was the ridiculous side-scrolling and Guitar Hero-like mini-games that completely break from the rest of the game. As excruciating as the aforementioned grind, the inclusion of something so one-dimensional and cheaply made is bewildering.  This is a game that is quite clearly trying to be a work of art, not a coin-slot machine at your local arcade or pokies club. Some people might not appreciate the warping perspective of the third-person camera either; tilting sporadically and playing with depth, so beware if you easily suffer from motion sickness.  Props for the checkpoint system though, it actually places you in convenient positions upon failing, rather than back to where you were.. which you’ll certainly need when the dodge and glide abilities fail to respond. Unfortunately, the CD Key that’s (hopefully) been provided needs to be authenticated through Electronic Arts DRM, which also requires you to have an account in the first place. If you’re getting the system error message, just log into the same account via a browser or Origin and verify the code there before launching it normally through Steam again. You should be good to go. To be quite frank, I didn’t enjoy playing most of Madness Returns. Apart from the visual presentation, it was often uninteresting and demonstrated a poorly thought-out sequence of thinly-veiled grinding to pass to the next (and equally repetitive) section. Basically nothing happens for about 7-8 hours before the plot begins to truly kick in and the best the game has to offer finally appears. Until then, it’s fetch quest galore and the many joys of running errands for lazy characters. Yet Alice: Madness Returns still does the job. It’s far from perfect, but offers a decent experience that sets it apart from the rest. Thanks to an enthralling narrative that saves it from the dreaded thumbs-down, this is recommended to anyone with the patience to see past its many faults and experience a well-written and mature journey into the depths of Victorian London and the dark corners of imagination. A fantasy horror for the ages.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												I feel obligated to write a review after taking 18h 47m (according to the game itself) to complete the playthrough. (The 26 hours recorded by Steam of course includes time when the game was paused or sitting on the main menu while I had to be away from the computer.)+ PROSGreat artistic style: The game is over-the-top beautiful. Even with the game's age you'd be hard put to find many others that hit the level of pure artistry in imagining the twisted vision of Wonderland.Amazing level design: Each of the five story chapters (the sixth is only the final boss-fight and cut scenes) has a very different look and feel and are peppered with mini-games that break up the platformer main play with other kinds of puzzles. Great voice acting: The actors were simply excellent even when the material was on the thin side.+ MIDDLE GROUNDFlat story; As much as I was impressed with the voice talent and how well crafted the words were, the narrative itself was a bit ho-hum. And you get a lot of it by finding items that trigger memories (voice-overs). It's the same as finding audio-logs in BioShock but not as well executed because a lot of memories add only weak context to the story. It almost makes finding them not worth the time in some cases, but finding them is really part of the fun. Consider that BioShock Infinite takes just as long to complete on average as this game, but the Alice storyline has nowhere near the depth or detail.Combat: It's OK. You get five weapons and all have important uses. In general combat helps break up the platformer experience of finding your way through Wonderland. But there's nothing terribly bad nor satisfying about it.+ CONSToo long: As beautiful as it all is, the chapters are about 25% longer than they really need to be. This made the fifth and final story chapter drag because I simply wanted the game to be over by that point. This wouldn't have been an issue if there was more to the story driving the game play.Bugs: Clipping issues (getting stuck on a seemingly smooth path). Game locking up under heavy button-mashing requiring a reboot. Also the beginning of chapter three has horrible button lag that made it a chore to get through.Clunky mechanics: The auto-target system locks the camera on the current target making you circle around it when moving Alice. This makes it impossible to rotate the cam to see what's coming up behind you in some cases. It also was a bit wonky changing targets. You can't play the game without auto-target though because the game often forces perspective shifts that make it impossible to aim like a traditional 3rd person shooter. You just deal with it as best you can.No Steam achievements: Lots of unlockables are tracked in-game, however no one but you will ever know how many you got.Rating: 6.5/10Worth playing, just be prepared for a long haul if you intend to complete it. Replay value is very low.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2014
												If there ever was a competition to select the most bizarre, most grotesque video game I'm sure Alice Madness Returns would be in the top 3. Some of the art design employed by the game is simply the creepiest I have ever seen! But all this in the good sense as this is a damn fine game with jaw-dropping visuals and music that gives you the goosebumps.This is a journey through vivid and dangerous dreams - Alice's Wonderland but as opposed to the cartoon this is now a horrified, alternative version of the same where the only way to survive is for Alice to be equipped with a bloody knife and a teapot that works like a grenade launcher. I like how idyllic it all begins only to gradually get more and more corrupt and in the process Alice faces more and more dangerous creatures of the Ruin - this powerful force that tries to stop Alice. You fight throughout the game and you will do that a lot - but you will also solve puzzles and jump and also shrink so that hidden paths can be revealed for you to make progress.You will jump a lot and many will result in your falling to certain death. But once you have put enough trial-and-error the game will be grateful as it shows you the progress Alice makes - a desperate progress to find out what caused the fire that killed his family at their home.The game is pretty long and is full of hundreds of collectibles. I finished it in roughly 15 hours and got only 90% of the stuff scattered throughout Wonderland. There is a special menu called Troubled Visions in the main menu that is only unlocked if you collect every single bottle during each chapter. Pretty neat, huh? Plus, you can always try the New Game+ mode if you think "Normal" does not offer a real challenge for you.Buy this game and immerse yourself in this unique, nightmarish world of Wonderland!

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												A bad port of an unique (but mediocre) game that could have been absolutely brilliant if not obviously rushed.GOOD+ Atmosphere and setting - especially if you've never played the original, coming into contact with American McGee's vision for Alice will leave a lasting impression - the series takes some of the subtle dark elements of the two original books by Lewis Caroll and churns them into a twisted, disturbing world of Wonderland - part steampunk fairy tale, part psychotic nightmare+ Visually, the game is simply stunning - aesthetics, visuals, scenery, animations and character models (Alice herself especially) are all gorgeous+ audio design is top notch as well - weapons and enemies benefit from some great sound effects, the game features a large amount of voice overs and the soundtrack itself is quite good (though not as memorable as the Chris Vrenna's masterpiece in the 1999 original)+ a number of interesting puzzles and set pieces that occasionally break up the normal playBAD- action is roughly divided into 2 sections - combat and platforming, and they're both not that much fun really. Combat is repetitive and quickly tiresome (enemies follow the same basic pattern throughout the game, weapons are limited in usefulness or creative synergy) and the platforming/exploring suffers from pacing issues, confusing environments and bad controls- the game itself is also far too long (~20h) and drawn out for it's own good - each room, enemy or set piece quickly wears out it's welcome before being used at least 3 more times within the chapter, and by the end the games feels more like a chore than leisure time. - the game world feels largely empty, bland, lifeless and depressive (even when it's not supposed to) - there's unfortunately not that much to do and see within the game- while the story has some depth and deals with some mature elements, it's delivered through a meandering mess of animated cutscenes, character dialogue and collectible in-game snippets of memories that are all ultimately too cryptic and pretentious and just don't make much sense. All of the characters speak in a random mix of rhymes, gibberish and shakespearian dialogue that not even the cast themselves seem to properly understand, judging by the delivery of their lines.- camera and controls are clunky and finicky (even while using a controller) - some moves don't register as you'd want them to, camera doesn't always do a proper job at showing you what's relevant in your situation (but at least platform deaths are quickly resolved by a minimal impact respawn, in-game)- horrible checkpoint system in place of proper saved games- invisible walls galore, things that don't work the way you'd expect them to, frequent stuttering, crashes, performance issues, game breaking bugs, you name it- how hard would it have been to port the (Xbox) Achievements into the Steam version as well, really?It hard to recommend this game solely on its gameplay merits. It's not really a good game. However, if you feel you have the patience and drive to overcome some of the major faults, Alice 2 can still be quite a memorable experience that is at least worth checking out. Think of this less as a game and more of an art project - style over substance.Also ♥♥♥♥ EA for not letting this project have the budget, time and care it required.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Okay, first of all, ‘Alice Madness Returns’ is too long… way too long. If they had cut out a third of the weaker content, it would have helped the game a lot. I mean it is still a fun and interesting game, which I enjoyed playing. It just gets a bit tiresome and finding the excessive amount of collectables definitely gets boring.With some changes to the ‘config’ files I got it to run at a solid 60FPS on my GTX 980. The game is very well designed for the most part and has an interesting, dark storyline. The animation style used in the 'cut scenes' is really cool and the enemy designs are great. The platforming is fun too and there are even a variety of surreal mini games spread throughout the campaign.There is also a nicely detailed ‘Main Menu’ with unlockable content and a ‘New Game +’ mode which adds replay value. To be honest though, when I had finished my first playthrough, I was done. After 23 hours of playing through the linear campaign, I had still only managed to achieve 94% completion. Like I said this game is waaaaaay too long and it ends up hurting the experience over all. I might come back and play the ‘New Game +’ mode in the future but I need a long break first.I would recommend that you play this game, it’s definitely worth your time (for the most part). It’s a unique take on the 'Alice in Wonderland' narrative, with interesting design elements and fun gameplay.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I would consider Alice: Madness Returns to be primarily a platforming game with some fighting; including some arcade and puzzle elements to a lesser extent.The environments look pretty good and give the impression of a dream world, but the path Alice takes is extremely linear.  There is no real exploration in this game and there are no large open areas; in fact, there are hidden walls which prevent you from even walking behind some objects.  The main path will occasionally branch off to a deadend that leads to collectible items.  The deadend paths must always be followed first because events are frequently triggered that will prevent you from backtracking.Aside from the teeth you collect--used to upgrade weapons--there are "memories" that will provide you with a short audio clip and there are also bottles.  I had to google the bottles because they don't seem to do anything when collected.  According to the wikia, if all the bottles of a chapter are collected then it unlocks a piece of concept art to view.The weapons are an interesting take on conventional weapons (i.e., a pepper grinder chaingun), but there are only 5 to choose from: a knife, chaingun, two-hand club, canon, and timed bombs which may also be manually detonated.  After 13 hours I have yet to unlock the canon.  There's also an umbrella that, while not a weapon itself, can deflect bombs back to the enemies that threw them.  I end up using the knife, the weapon you start with, the most.  It has a really satisfying sound and animation that I never seem to grow tired of.  Upgrading the weapons change their appearance and makes them do more damage, but doesn't given them any new abilities.  Ammo is unlimited, but the chaingun will overheat if you hold down the trigger for more than a few seconds.There is no manual save option, but the game does a good job with autosaving right before some difficult platforming.  If you fall to your death while platforming, you typically won't have to worry about redoing much of that again.  However, if you die during a boss fight, you will have to redo some platforming to get back to the boss area.  This has got to be one of the more frustrating aspects of the game.  You could die on the platforming section literally 2 seconds away from the boss and only have to redo that 2 seconds of platforming again.  If you die figting a boss, you won't get placed at that save point 2 seconds away.  Instead, you might have to endure 2 minutes of platforming along with cutscenes that you can, fortunately, skip.  It makes no logical sense.A mechanic I thought was kind of cool is the "drink me" shrinking effect which can be used at any time simply by pressing a button.  This not only shrinks Alice, but reveals invisible platforms and tips scrawled on the walls and floors that are EVERYWHERE.  I emphasize "everywhere" because the developers somehow thought it would be good to hold your hand and tell you where every secret path can be found, what collectibles are down that path, what enemies to find around every corner, and what weapon to use on them.  Everywhere.  These tips can't be disabled.The most annoying aspect of this game is the constant camera hijacking.  The game will frequently pan the camera to some triggered event and then return it to a predetermined angle leaving you disoriented.  Infrequently it will fix itself at a particular angle and distance for platforming and also in confined areas.The mouse control was unplayable for me when I purchased this game over a year ago.  I decided not to play it at that time because of that.  You should consider yourself forewarned if you use a mouse because you may not be able to tolerate it.  I picked the game back up recently and I've been using a 360 controller which works fine--aside from having to manually edit an .ini file because the main menu does not include the option to disable force feedback.I find the platforming and boss fights to be enjoyable and challenging and not at all frustrating; instead, the frustrating parts are bad developer decisions that could have been avoided.  While the graphics and animations are beautifully done and the story is somewhat compelling, it doesn't seem like enough incentive to continue playing.  I feel like I'm playing just to get to the destination instead of playing it to enjoy the journey.I suggest only picking up this title during a Steam sale so you don't feel too cheated when you decide to not finish it.

												How is it humanly possible to make serenic views, tea parties, and undersea villages horrifying? American McGee found a way, and it is terrifying as it is beautiful. Even knowing how it would end (a friend spoiled it for me -_-) and without playing American McGee's Alice first, it was still fun and it kept suprising me.Pros:-Beautiful graphics-Amazing voice acting-The story (it's original and different compared to the other interpretations of Alice in Wonderland).-The soundtrack -The dresses are beautiful and after completing the game the dresses get buffs or debuffs (to give you a harder challenge)-Puzzles weren't too difficult-The graphics-You experience Wonderland and Reality, which is interesting to add to the story-Interesting weapons and mechanics-Did I mention the graphics?Cons:-Had to do a bit of modding to get it to work-Had to follow a guide and download extra files to get American McGee's Alice (but it works well)-Control support wasn't included but I found a program online that allowed me to use it-Keyboard controls were unresponsive at times-EA forced the developers to rush it out so it could've had more content (Damn it EA)-No trading cards, achievements, emoticons, or backgrounds for your Steam profile -Can be repetitive-Ran into a few bugs but nothing game breakingOverall, this game is as beautiful as it is haunting.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
IntroductionI bought this game on sale for $5 and it sat in my library for a couple weeks. After starting to play it, however, it quickly found a spot on my favorite games list. Even though some parts were tedious, the story kept me engaged untill the very end.Prepare yourselves for an exceedingly long wall of text (go to the TL:DR if you wish to skip).


HowTo: Unlock FPS ; more FPS [ENG|GER] 
A Guide for Alice: Madness Returns
By: Dein schlimmster Alpentraum

			In this tutorial i am going to show you how to unlock the FPS in Alice: Madness Returns :) Please leave a comment and usually your favourite when it helps for you Last edit: 28.03.14		


OverviewAlice: Madness Returns is a psychological horror game developed by Spicy Horse and published by Electronic Arts in 2011 for Windows, PlayStation 3, and Xbox 360. It is the sequel to America Mcghee’s Alice, made in 2000.Before I ramble on about everything that I enjoyed about this game, I would like to point out a few flaws with this version on steam.First: the umbrella to block projectiles might not work (it didn’t for me) and if so, you will have to change some files to get it to work right. Next: the combat focus mechanic is far from perfect and has many flaws. It feels awkward to use at first and could use some polishing. Love it or hate it, this mechanic is essential for fighting certain monsters. I got used to it eventually, but it was hard starting out (because you have to hold down the CAPSLOCK key to stay focused).You will also need an EA account for a brief activation (as far as I can remember) but then you don’t need it for the rest of the game.Now on to things I enjoy about Alice: Madness returns:Varied environments: from dark castles, underwater cities, Victorian London, an asylum, and even a train. All of these settings make for an interesting experience as you travel throughout Alice’s now twisted version of wonderland.Platforming: Satisfying and well designed (albeit repetitive) embodied by unique jumping mechanics (I will explain later). Something that would make the platforming better would be to include the edge grabbing mechanic originally shown in America Mcghee’s Alice.Story: I won’t spoil it for you but here is a brief summary: Alice tries to piece together memories of the night that her family died in a fire and ultimately finds out who is truly behind her madness… The story is presented in an interesting way, mostly told by cut scenes, brief dialogue and memory shards that are hidden throughout the levels. The story is very thought-provoking and I recommend that you go into the game as blind as possible because of how captivating the story is, especially towards the very end.Challenge rooms, puzzles, and game modes: There are several puzzles in environment, needing to be solved to more on (they can also be skipped). They vary from playing musical notes, finding blocks that need to be arranged to form a picture, and chess. I enjoyed most of them, but the finding the blocks for a picture is repeated around 6 times, which got repetitive. There are also multiple challenge rooms where the goal is to survive waves of enemies or complete a certain objective. When a challenge is completed, you are rewarded with some red paint. Each time you collect this paint, a part of a rose is filled in. Once you fill in a rose 4 times, you gain an extra rose container (like a heart). Lastly, there are a few game modes, each unique to its environment. An underwater side scrolling shooter, 2D platformer, and baby head rolling course (which is by far the most bizarre of them all).Weapons: There are 4 of them, not including the clock work bomb which you will collect as you progress through the story. In order of appearance they are: Vorpal Blade, Pepper Grinder, Hobby Horse, and Teapot Cannon. (there is also an additional variant for each of these included in the unlockable DLC). The Vorpal blade is your first weapon and used for fast melee slashing. Next, The Pepper Grinder is used rapid, medium to long range assault (and for triggering switches). The Hobby Horse is a slow but powerful short range weapon that is effective against groups of enemies (and is my favorite). The last weapon you get is the Teapot Cannon, is long ranged weapon of high damage and large radius (can be used to break some walls).Character customization: There are several outfits for Alice, her original outfit that changes depending on which environment you are in, a few others, and the DLC outfits. The DLC outfits and weapons each have buffs (or debuffs) that can fit your playstyle. Also, the Teeth you collect can be used to upgrade your base weapons, changing their look and empowering them.Mechanics: many of them stood out to me, aside from the combat focus. Shrinking: used to get through small keyholes and reveal hidden paths. Activated by holding down left control.Health system represented by roses. You can regenerate health by picking up roses that enemies drop or finding a purple flower (if you shrink on top of a purple flower, it will regenerate your health). You can increase your health capacity by completing challenge rooms.Hysteria (my favorite) where Alice taps into her insanity for several seconds to become invincible and gain increased damage. This can only be activated at extremely low health by pressing enter.Jumping: you can jump 3(?) times in midair, losing height with each consecutive jump. If you jump and hold down space in midair, you will slowly float. Also, while we are talking about movement, you can dodge by pressing left shift.Enemies: Small leech-like slimes to massively destructive blobs with baby faces and flamethrowers. Nuff said. Each monster has their own attack pattern and vulnerabilities, which you will need to recognize in order to be victorious. The enemies vary from environment to environment.Level design: predominantly linear with multitudes of secret memories, bottles, and challenge rooms to be found. A few puzzles (mentioned above) are included, but the vast majority of each level relies on platforming. This may get repetitive, but this is up to personal opinion. Although there are no steam achievements (wish there were), you progress is recorded and you can see how many secrets you have found (no one but you can see).Graphics/art style: Surprisingly stunning, detailed environments. One of the selling points for me. I was constantly taking screenshots and have 350 of them (200 uploaded). Half the time playing I was looking for the perfect place to take a screenshot (I got some pretty good ones).Performance: Mouse sensitivity takes getting used to, controls are clunky at first, but after playing for an hour or so, you’ll get used to it. The FPS and a few other things can be changed by editing some game files. You can find guides on how to do this if you look on the Community Hub.Free DLC: Although it is not enabled by default, you can enable the DLC (that includes outfits and weapons) for free by changing the value of GIsSpecialPCEdition from FALSE to TRUE. Due to how much I liked this game, I decided to check out the earlier game, America Mcghee’s Alice. For a game made in 2000, it really impressed me. If you want to play Alice: Madness returns or have enjoyed playing it I strongly recommend you get a copy of America Mcghee’s Alice. It even has slightly better controls (sensitivity wise). TL:DRTo summarize: Alice: Madness Returns features a unique atmosphere, impressive soundtrack (which I forgot to mention), surreal story, decent platforming, weapon appearance customization, interesting mechanics, linear level designs, vibrant and dark art style, and average performance. On sale this is a must buy and at $20 I would still recommend it (if you understand some of the flaws).For personal enjoyment I’m giving it a 9/10 and for review purposes, I give it a 8.5/10 because of its flaws. Just be prepared to troubleshoot any potential problems that could arise.
