content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
												Alice: Madness ReturnsGame DetailsPublished by: Electronic ArtsDeveloped by: Spicy HorseGenre: Action/AdventureRelease Date: 17 Jun, 2011Completionist Gameplay: 22 Hours“Alice Liddell, believing herself responsible for a fire that consumed her home and her family, escapes into a twisted version of Wonderland. While held at Rutledge Asylum for treatment, Alice was able to conquer her doubts, and eventually was released from the ward. Alice, now 19 years old, resides at an orphanage in Victorian London, under the care of Doctor Angus Bumby, a psychiatrist who uses hypnotism to help his child patients forget their memories. Though she believes herself cured of her madness, Alice still suffers from hallucinations of Wonderland.."The GameplayAlice: Madness Returns is an action platformer that presents itself with a creepy, dark and creative atmosphere. Wonderland is inhabited by squirming leaches, firebreathing dolls and evil looking teacups, creating a twisted and surreal vibe. As you float and jump through an eerie dollhouse, you can drop bombs, shrink down to a miniscule size or dodge ceiling spikes ready to slam down on you. Unfortunately, the gameplay doesn’t evolve much from the start. This causes the game to become quite repetitive, especially when often, your task is to go and fetch something for another character. If it were not for the distinct and peculiar backgrounds, you might be tricked into thinking you’ve been playing the same level since the start. However, throughout the game there are plenty of hidden secrets motivating the player to fully explore every grotesque nook and cranny. There are enough hidden secrets to make it worth inspecting Madness Returns' grotesque nooks.Alice:Madness Returns does try to change the gameplay up. There are ramps to slide on, an underwater combat scene, puzzles to solve, and a giant dolls head to control. Unfortunately, oftentimes the camera gets in the way of doing these things. There are awkward transitions going in and out of third person, and side views are generally useless. Instead of a heart-pounding flee from a giant executioner, it feels like Alice is just jogging towards the camera. You’ll certainly be glad of the change of tempo, but it leaves a lot to be desired.Melee is the best part of the combat system in Alice:Madness Returns. It feels light, fast, and incredibly deadly. My favourite melee weapon would have to be the Vorpal Blade. Alice will flutter in and around her enemies, slashing them to bits and leaving a trail of butterflies behind. Unfortunately, ranged combat isn’t as fun. The controls for ranged combat lock your camera in place and the targeting system is a little frustrating to use. Unfortunately, this makes many of the battles you will face in this game almost impossible, especially when you are facing multiple enemies.The SoundtrackThe soundtrack in Alice: Madness Returns is spot on in setting the mood. The voice acting is good. Nothing spectacular, nothing terrible, as it can get a little repetitive, especially during the longer levels.The ExperienceIf you buy the DLC, there are some stunning dresses you can wear throughout the game. The Fleshmaiden is a direct example of this. While wearing this, Alice’s pupils are white, her legs are bloodstained and the actual dress itself is a mesh of bloody flesh and tendons. The story of this game will be left in your mind for weeks after you’ve played it. It is engaging and a dark twist on your childhood memory of Alice in Wonderland, and you’ll probably never be able to read it the same way again.Overall VerdictWhile the gameplay can be a little repetitive, I honestly think this game is worth it for the dark, realistic take on a fairytale.If you'd like to read more reviews from me, join my steam group!

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												So after comepleting this game, I found out it`s a sequel to another Alice game. Wow I think I missed out on something here.Presentation: Right of the bat, we see that the game is split into to "stages". stage one is the real world, where Alice is lossing her memories, and tryes to find out how her familie got killed. The secound stage is wonderland, where Alice turns into a badass and kills the monsters of wonderland. The story is based around the Alice in wonderland universe, but the universe here is far more disturbing, and shows a more grim side of wonderland. I think I would apriciate  the tone more if I had played the first game, but as long as you know  Alice in wonderland. It dose not feel like you are missing out on anything.If you don't know about the Alice universe beforehand, I would say you would find this game really random at times, since no charecters wouldn't make any sense to you. Gameplay/Controles:In terms of gameplay, this game is acually very fun. It can get repetetive now and again but the balance between combat  puzzels and platforming makes the game seem more or less fresh all the time. In terms of main gameplay, there is your 3D platforming and your combat. In terms of platforming, the game can from time to time fell a bit slipery, but after you get use to it, you fly around the levels. The platforming is also mixed with puzzeling, where you have to activate a switch, and afterwards run back through some tricky jumps. This can be frusterating at times, but when you succed you feel great.The combat is simple, you aim with the mouse and leed Alice towards an enemy. You will get other weapons than your standard knife, like a heavy weapon, and a light and heavy gun. This makes it up to you, to find out how you want to take care of your enemies all the time, and it`s a great way to make palyers chose what they want too do, and what battle type they prefer. One thing though which I`ll also mention in visuels. I had problems with the game, and it started to prefomre purely when to many enemies where on the screen, this runied the gamepley a bit for me, but it is a matter to be overlooked, if you have a strong PC.The enemies are all themed from the stage you are on. There are teapot fighters from the Mad Hatter stage and card soldiers from the queen of hearts stage. You need to find all the enemies weakneses in order to win, and some of them, needs a bit more of stragetie to defeat. There are also fun ministages, such as a sidescrole shooters, a maze game, and much more. There is also a lot of collectebels to find in this game. Which only makes you want to explore the beutifull world even more.Charecters:If you know your Alice in wonderland, you`ll know most of the charecters. All of them have been givin a more sinister look and perseronality, which is also reflected by the stages. You`ll meet many great charecters such as the Mad Hatter, the Carpenter and the Queen of hearts. All the charecters are well voiceacted, and have there own persenalitty, and it is a joyride all the way through.Visuels:As said sometimes the game slowed down for me, but it dose not change the great looks of this game. Every single stage is beutifull in it`s own way, and everything is so well done, that I think the visuels where some of the most importent things of this game. Evey stage has it`s own charm and it`s own looks, there is a steampunk stage based on the Mad Hatters tea factory, there is a Water level that looks beutifull, there is a japanese inspired level, a cardhouse in the sky and much more, everything looks so beutifull and nice, that you want to explore everything, and see even the smaller details in this game.  Music:the music is very well made, and fits in with all the stages. Not much to be said here, other than I want the soundtrack so I can play it for a D&D night. Story:The story is accually not that complecated , Alice needs to find her memories in wonderland, and also find the out how her famelie died in the real world. The game switches from wonderland to real world, and you find out new things all the time. Alice needs to face many of her old friends in wonderland, and the progress you make all the time, makes the games story flow by pretty smothly. I am not going to spoil anything, but let me tell you, the end boss is a blast to fight.Conclution:This game is really good, with great charecters, fantastic visuels, and nice music, but tihs is maybe also the minor complain I have. The gameplay could at times be a bit better, and the art direction seems to have taken over with this game. This is not a bad thing, but if you are a gamer, that don`t care about visuels, this game can seem a bit flat at times.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												A beautiful 3D platformer (Don't rush through the levels, particularly the prologue and first level, stop and look around) that takes place after the events of American McGee's Alice. Alice, now older, returns to a corrupted wonderland to do battle with events from her childhood and her own insanity. EA initially market this game as a psychological horror game. While it certainly is creepy and dark at times I would never call it scary. This game has more in common with games like Spiro and Banjo Kazooie than it does with your stereotypical psychological horror title.The game is a lot of fun, both combat and platforming are incredibly satisfying (Having the ability to triple jump and glide from the beginning and LEARNING to master these abilities as opposed to unlocking them). Each area of the game grants access to new weapons, allows you to collect teeth (currency) to upgrade your weapons and gives Alice a new outfit whcih is a reflection of the level (a nice little touch). The game also contains 'memories' and other such collectables which allow you to unlock bonus content (concept art for example) which will appease the OCD side of the avid completionist.The game does suffer from some optimisation issues (It's a console port) and certainly does control better with a gamepad. If you are considering giving this game some serious playtime I would really recommend getting access to a controller. After a while the game does start to feel stretched out, few new mechanics and concepts are introduced and it turns into a slight grind to the end.Overall, I think this is definately worth buying and playing. If you are still making up your mind, check out this Let's play by Just A Friend and Sinatrapod from the lparchive:http://lparchive.org/Alice-Madness-Returns/Happy gaming.

Posted: November 2, 2016
												Bought this game on steam when it first came out and enjoyed it, despite some technical problems with the game. Reinstalled it this week to play it again and discovered that the third-party DRM is no longer working and the game can't be activated anymore. Despite a valid EA account and a valid CD-Key provided by steam, all activation attempts result in a very unhelpful "system error" message. I was finally able to activate the game through a series of methods discovered by searching extensively online for people with similar problems. All in all I spent about 3 hours simply attempting to launch the game - this is absolutely unacceptable. I notice that the game is still present on steam but can no longer be purchased. Perhaps Valve has halted sales because they know this game doesn't actually work? Or perhaps EA stopped new sales to focus on their competing platform. Either way, something needs to be done. Ideally valve would pull this game entirely and issue full refunds to all who purchased it, at EA's expense. I paid $60 for the perpetual right to play this game, and that contract has been broken. tl;dr: This game is approximately 3 hours long and takes place mostly in search engines, abandoned forum threads, and notepad. Not recommended.

content:
Posted: January 20
												Fantastic and brilliant game. I never considered myself a fan of Alice in Wonderland, but now I do. You see, it's not just about a girl who goes down the rabbit hole into Wonderland. American Mcgee, creator of this version of Alice, showed me just how awesome this mytho can be if you interpret it in different ways. In this particular version, which quickly became my favorite, Alice is a delusional girl who lost her family in a fire, and spent most of her life locked in an asylum. Wonderland is nothing but a fruit of her (twisted) imagination, and a way to escape the tragedy of the real world. This is a sequel to American Mcgee Alice, released in 2000.  Pros   Incredible world inspired by the original Alice's Adventures in Wonderland, but ultimately created by American Mcgee. Enjoy a beautiful, varied, twisted and dark version of the original place Alice has such a passion for. Characters also get the American Mcgee treatment and fit perfectly in this new world. Prepare to bond with poor Alice, who is victim of her own mind, and start to root for her as you play and meet new characters. Sooo much variety in Wonderland. Everything is just gorgeous to look at, holding a lot of style and originality. Alice is such a good character in this version that I think she deserves her own point in this list. Alice is a beautiful young girl, and you will start to care for her the more you explore her tragic past. As always, emotional affection in games just proves how high quality the product is. Dresses. Yes, dresses. Alice will get a new dress with each new place you explore in Wonderland, and they just keep getting cooler and cooler. Plot. Just amazing. Seriously. The more you play, the more you want to know about what's going on. Story pacing is just superb. Weapons. While there's not a lot of them, they will certainly keep you entertained. The Vorpal Blade and the Pepper Grinder are your initial weapons, but you'll get a few, more intereresting options ahead in the game. They are all very stylish and creative. I guarantee you've never seen anything like it. Interesting upgrade system. You'll be collecting teeth throughout your journey, which you can use to upgrade your weapons. This not only will make them stronger, but also change their appearance. Great combat system. Not only is this a platformer game, the action in it is awesome, and the combination of both things is something no other game has done. While not perfect, the combat system can be mastered, and soon you'll be kicking some Corruption♥♥♥♥♥ You can slash, bash, shoot, dodge, block, reflect, target, or throw a bomb to divert enemies from you. Great platformer. Madness Returns also stand out as a platformer, not leaving anything on the table when it comes to great 3d jumping and twirling. Enemy variety. No combat can be good without good enemies, and Alice: Madness Returns delivers. All enemies are fun to fight, and trust me, there are a lot of them. Enemy quality. Doesn't matter if you have dozens of enemies in your game and they all suck. Here, not only are enemies fun to fight (as I mentioned above), they are styled according to the place you're currently at in Wonderland. It's just awesome to enter a new place and try to imagine how the enemies will be, according to the current scenario. Hair. Alice's hair in this game is really a thing. While clearly not perfect, it works really, really well. The wind effect is just beautifuly created. Good boss fights. Bosses are just as good as regular enemies. Gameplay variety. You simply can't get bored when playing this game. There are at least 5 different gameplays in here, and most of them are great (see: Cons). Gameplay time. This game is really long (especially for a platformer), all while maintaining a great pace. It will surely keep you entertained for many hours. Great amount of collectibles that are actually fun to look for. Voice acting is top notch. Soundtrack. Oh, my. Just remembering that main menu theme gives me goosebumps. Graphics. While not the best (keep in mind this a 2011 game), they deliver. Holding up greatly to this day, they are supported by the outstanding art. Optimization. Very optimized game. And I don't mean "I can max it in my gtx 970" kind of optimized. I mean "I can run it in my celeron, gt 620 combo with decent graphic options" optimized. All cutscenes are skippable (useful when you're replaying the game). You don't need to play the first game to get into this one.   Cons   There are a few short segments (4 or 5, I think), where the game turns into a 2d platformer. Those parts are atrocious. Boring and sometimes unfair and glitchy. 30 fps cap (can easily be fixed). Negative mouse acceleration (no way to deactivate it). You can have a few problems if you remmap the keyboard keys, such as actions not happening, even though you are pressing the correct button (yes, I'm talking about that damn umbrella tutorial). A lot of people manage to get past it, and others don't. I had a little bit of trouble, but I got lucky and it worked. If all fails, I'm sure plugging a controller is a 100% reliable method.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												The design, feel and visual uniqueness of this game is hard to describe.  Being rather fond of surrealistic elements and other-wordliness, this game struck me from way across the field as both visually-aesthetically beautiful and packed with an overall feel and mood that makes playing it like being in a dream.  Really.I love it, I love the game mechanics, the design, and for what it matters there's also a storyline, but I scarcely care about it because whoever drove the main gist of this game is someone so well in touch with their own nocturnal affairs that simply walking through the maps is an oddly, bizarrely enjoyable experience.The only downside is the sluggish response and non-optimized engine.  Ever had that hard-to-nail feeling that "there's something wrong here.. like I'm walking in shoes with sticky soles, or trying to drive a car with a slightly loose steering wheel and laggy servo mechanism" ?  That's the feel I get in Skyrim too, the feeling of something made for a console (and in my world, game consoles are an entertaining, but utterly inferior species) ported to PC without optimizing.  'cause feck the PC gamers, right? They'll just buy new hardware, right?It's from 2011, this is 2015 and I think a dual core 2.8Ghz with a Radeon 290X ought to be enough to run these graphics smoothly, with no input lag.  Alas, not the case.Don't let the above deter you, I'm fairly confident these are somewhat card/driver-specific, and it's not actually a problem unless I max the physics (which I don't really notice anyway).  Just take heed if you're someone who's bothered by these things.Imagination, visuals, gameplay, cool mechanics and a unique atmosphere, it's a fantastic game, totally recommended.  Beautiful.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Alice: Madness Returns is one hell of a ride. It is hard to describe such an hybrid of a game; If there is one game that doesn't quite fall victim of genres, this would be a great example. It is loosely based on Lewis Carroll's "Alice in Wonderland", but with a much darker setting. The thematic present in the story is somber and sometimes psychologically disturbing. This is definitely an M rated game, due to a very mature story (younger players may have an hard time understanding it due to it's complexity) and the gore level involved, but even on this aspect this game is unique, the violence isn't gratuitous and it always serves the purpose of the story and the setting involved. Madness Returns is a mix of a third person adventure with a great combat system implemented for the action sequences. It has exploration as well, with plenty of collectables to find, but at it's core it's an action adventure game, but it's unlike anything else out there. This game is a work of heart and art. The enemies, settings, artwork in the game world are all unique. And unique is the best word to describe this gem. There is also variety in the game, some sections are played in 2 dimensions in a cell shaded style, and many more surprises that are better left unspoken. Designed and produced by American McGee, an experienced game designer that has worked at ID Software, on Doom and Quake, and also the designer of the first Alice game, Madness Returns is quite an accomplishment. The visuals are simply amazing, breathtaking and draw you in. You have never seen so much use of colour on the Unreal engine before, and the quality of the textures really manage to impress. Graphically it is one of the best looking games to ever grace your PC, even today 2 years after it's release. The real winner though, is the art and design of the levels themselves. You have to see it and experience it to believe it. The music is quite good, Chris Vrenna (Nine Inch Nails, Marilyn Manson) is the man responsible for the soundtrack, and it matches the visuals in perfection. This is one of the few examples where the audio is just as important as the visuals and the story. They all are and feel like a perfect match to each other, and not so many games can claim the same. There are some flaws though. The camera is a bit shaky at times, and it does get in the way on occasion. The mouse control is very sensitive and it will need adjustment. Some people may find some exploration parts boring, but it was not the case with me. If you decide to purchase this gem of a game, do so knowing it will take you quite a bit of time to finish. It is a long adventure. The Good-Story, superb visuals and audio-Unsurpassed art style-Animation-CG sequences are a living painting -Voice acting-M Rated-Variety in gameplayThe Bad-Camera angles get in the way on occasion-Some players may dislike longer exploration sections9/10

content:
Posted: May 28, 2016
												I am torn on this game, on the one hand the Gothic and peculiar style of the game is amazing, and provides a nice dark twist on the classic story. The graphics are very good for its age and most of the time, the combat feels great. However, every level feels the same as each other, with just a different skin dashed over the same mechanics, the same platforming, the same monotonous puzzles and honestly this is where the game completely lost me. The story is barely there, the game feels drawn out purely for the sake of stretching playtime as it adds nothing to the story and when you've killed 1000 black baby blobs, you've killed them all and it starts to become a chore more than actual fun. It also doesn't help that the game, on a technical level is objectively♥♥♥♥♥♥ The performance is dire when compared to any other game from 2011, the numerous glitches forcing me to kill myself in order to restart the section because some how a giant monster is walking on air and it won't die, the slight jolt in game rendering as it places "moving objects" at the incorrect moment just adds to how frustrating this game is and ultimately killed it for me.See, that is the worst thing about it, if you would have given me this repetitive but stylish game in a better engine, I would have been happy and would have more than likely completed it, but as it is, it's a repetitive, annoying, broken slug fest and that is a damn shame.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
 The short answer is that this game is a work of art. It's a paradigm of how other works can be adapted into new and great ideas. I think it's also the last "Art" that EA ever published.First, the good: The graphics are gorgeous for its time. It may have been made in 2011, but it could easily pass for 2014-2015. The problem that I find with most of today's action-adventure platformer titles is that they feel short. Madness Returns, however, is a meaty adventure. It's filled with all kinds of secrets, nooks and crannies to explore, and pig noses to shoot. The environments of each chapter are varied and detailed, right down the very clothes that Alice wears. The story is interesting in its own right, although I'll admit, there were points in it where I got a bit lost. The characters are all good adaptations of the ones from the original book. They still follow similar roles, just in a darker way. The combat is a decent challenge, although it can get a bit easy once you fully upgrade the Hobby Horse. The thing I like about it is how the battles are well placed, with a good amount of time set between encounters. The enemies are also diverse, although there are some instances of re-use (i.e. Boltorfly and Ink Wasp doing basically the same thing). The platforming segments of the gameplay are executed nicely. It felt like the levels had been designed with care, rather than just spitting random moving platforms and ledges everywhere.Now, get ready for the bad: You know how I said earlier that this was a meaty adventure? That can be a double-edged sword. Yes, it has a lot of level to play, but sometimes the levels drag on. This game was tagged as being a horror game, but I wasn't scared for most of it. It didn't spook me until the last chapter, and maybe once in the second. The one consolation here is that Madness Returns doesen't rely on cheap tactics like jump scares when it tries to scare you. The things that spooked me were actually kind of nightmarish.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Alright so, you found out about this game, came here looking for directions, wanting to know if it's worth your hard earned money, and is currently reading this review. Unfortunately, as you probably noticed, this game is not on sale anymore on Steam (but you can still buy it from another popular digital distribution platform).Which is a REAL shame.Why is it a "REAL" shame?Let me start by saying that this game is a masterpiece, graphically speaking. Its enviroment design is gorgeous, each chapter has its own feeling to it, its own story, its own enemies (which are decently diversed), I can say without a doubt that this is the most beautiful game I've ever played in my life, period. I'm not one for art, I never really cared about art in general but this game made me actually stop whatever I was doing to enjoy the scenery, enjoy each and every single detail in it. To sum up, this game is breathtaking. For real. The focus the developers put into making every moment unique is already worth the buy....Wait, what exactly IS Alice: Madness Returns?Let's get something out of the way first: it isn't a horror game. It certainly has some horror elements to it, but you won't be constantly scared of what's going to happen. It's more of an adventure-platform game. You'll be jumping and stabbing creatures like crazy, though. It's a fun game, I'll tell you that!Beautiful that, gorgeous this, but what about the gameplay?The gameplay is not the best, but it's good nonetheless! The controls are pretty tight, you can feel that you have total control over Alice, and if you fail trying to do something, it's all on you buddy. You'll be double even triple jumping during most of the game, so you better practice your timing and coordination.This is vital to explore the world. The main plot is uncovered by simply just going from a chapter to another, but the sub-plot is revealed by discovering memories hidden all around the level, so you have to be paying attention to everything and be willing to do some crazy tricks to find them all.But you'll probably spend some time familiarizing yourself with the controls when battling, since they are kinda confusing and frustrating sometimes, but mostly at the beginning when you're still learning how to focus on an enemy while trying to evade multiple attacks, among other things.Since we are talking about the combat, I'll let you know that this is also not a hack'n'slash game. Yeah, you'll be gutting creatures like it's f****** christmas, but the game will force you to strategize your attacks, since each enemy has its own weakness, and you can't kill them all using the very same technique, even more when there's a bunch of them attacking you at the same time.So, the game is beautiful and the gameplay is decent. But what about the story?"Alice: Madness Returns", as you probably already know, is the sequel to "American McGee's Alice", released in 2000, but I wouldn't say it makes much of a difference to play the first game before this one. Since Alice is just revisiting Wonderland after 10 years, the only things you'll be missing out are how this one character ended up this way and why some places are like this, apart from that there's no major event that you should be aware of that'll actually prevent you from fully comprehending what's going on in this game.And, boy, what ISN'T going on in this game. I won't talk about the actual plot since that is vaguely explained in the game's description for a good reason, but I can guarantee you that I enjoyed every part of the story. The game's premise is pretty interesting and it does a very well job in making you theorize about if Alice is actually in Wonderland or not, and if you really are paying attention to everything that's happening, you start "losing" your mind. The story hits a point where  even you, the player, the only mentally stable person so far, starts to question what's real or not, and that, my friends, is what really got me hooked up in story.Alright, alright, but a game is nothing without a good soundtrack!This is not an issue either. If you really care about music in videogames, then I must say that you're in for a superb ride! The soundtrack, totally orchestral, composed by Jason Tai and Marshall Crutcher, is absolutely phenomenal. Each track captures the moment you're at, more "aggressive" tracks will play while on combat, more relaxing tracks will play while trying to solve a puzzle or while exploring the game in general, and some tracks will even make you stop and just... Think.Alice: Madness Returns has one of the best gaming soundtracks, in my opinion.Come on... This game can't be perfect! Tell me some bad stuff about it too!You're right! Nothing is perfect, so here we go:  It's too repetitive. Alright, I understand, you can't go many different ways with a platform type of game, you'll have to jump and jump and jump again to reach that item, that's not my real issue with it, but they actually re-use the same puzzle at least two times in a chapter, and when you're reaching the end of the story and all you want to know is how it's going to end, they actually get reaally annoying. There's a straight path ahead, but you can't cross it because you HAVE to finish this simple-yet-frustrating puzzle. Besides, some mini-games are just plain boring.  It's buggy. It became a routine during my gameplay to get stuck in the ground after a cutscene or "just because". Or sometimes after a battle the game wouldn't let me progress because it kept waiting for me to finish off all the enemies, even though all of them were dead already. This is the worst type of bug, but didn't happen often, at least.  It crashes ocasionally. During my first playthrough, which took me 17 hours, the game crashed at least 4 times. It isn't much, and maybe it won't happen to you, but a crash is a crash, so be aware of that.I'm still not sure if I should buy it!Alice: Madness Returns is not a game for everyone. If you like to play all kinds of games, if you want to watch a good story unfold in front of you or if you like platform mixed with adventure and some action, then I would highly recommend it. You won't regret any single minute of it, assuming you'll look past the game's flaws and focus on the bigger picture (which isn't hard to do).But, if you're here because you thought this game would be all about that psychological terror or some hardcore hack'n'slash, then you'll be disappointed.I shared with you my thoughts about the game, so now it's up to you to decide for yourself. As you can probably see, I loved this game. Maybe you'll love it too!

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I don't think there could have possibly been a better sequel to American McGee's Alice. It's darkly gorgeous and creative with brilliant level design and simplified combat driven by a dark, psychological story. That said, the boss fights were underwhelming to me, especially the final one (Just start the game on Hard or Nightmare), but all my complaints are minor. In contrast with the first game, there are few memorable music pieces, as there's much more focus on background ambience, though the addition of heart-pumping fight music is nice. Still a bit disappointing considering it's Chris Vrenna. Anyway, there are plenty of moments where I got stuck not knowing where to go - another leftover from the original, but this sequel really succeeds where it counts.There's simply much more plot going on here, more characters and a mystery to unfold - all fueled by solid voice acting. There are some loose ends still untied once it's all over and I did feel some of the symbolism - especially with the end villain - was forced, but considering the dark creativity at display with the monsters and levels, I can easily forgive that. Seriously, the amount of detail put into places you won't even necessarily visit is amazing. Anyway, if you enjoyed the original game, absolutely play this - and vice versa. I didn't even like Madness Returns at first, but it won me over for all the above reasons.

content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Do you like third person platformers?  You'll like this game.  You are born into the world with not only the ability to double jump, but you can quad-jump, and you can glide after each jump!  Platformers dream come true.The imagery in the game is beautiful and twisted.  Some scenes are wonderfully gorgeous, while other scenes are ruthlessly violent.  I'm not really a screenshots kinda person, but I did end up taking a lot of screenshots of this game.  And the hair physics...you wouldn't think something so small as which way Alice's hair blows in the wind would be such a big deal but it is surprisingly pleasant to watch during those moments when I stop to smell the roses.The platforming complexity is decent.  Hardcore types might be turned off because the path forward is relatively linear and the puzzles themselves are relatively straightforward, but it's still a satisfying experience.  Especially because this game has not frustrated me even once, which is surprisingly difficult for games in this genre.The fighting isn't incredibly complex and the moveset is fairly limited, but it does give you four different weapons, fast melee, strong melee, fast ranged, strong ranged.  Some attacks work better than others against some enemies.  The fighting adds a nice break between platforming segments; I don't grumble when a fight starts, but I don't get all excited either.For the completionist, there are lots of little things to look for that are hidden away.  I'm usually pretty thorough at searching for things and I've managed to miss two or three things in each level (out of about 30-40).  Fortunately, the game allows you to replay previous chapters you've beaten, so you can get a perfect score.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
ENG: Score 11 ouf of 10! The worst fears a kid can have is from the people he thought were good, if they do bad stuff to him it's just hundred times more hurting. And if this kid is emotionally sensible, the pain can be multiplied by his perception, as you can see the aesthetic beauty from Wonderlands, before its falls. It happens that these crazy things just made a super fun and never old fighting mechanic, with some creative and dynamic gameplay. Better yet, American Mcgee and his team rightfully leaves EA as Bioware should have done a long time ago. Impressive.But the last thing you hear before descending to the Wonderlands is ''I need a drink'' from a over caricatured granny, from some over caricatured, 18th smoky world who is curiously leaving Alice's beauty untouched. Curiously her psychologist isn't charicatured neither. You're just on the ugly fourth dimension looking at a third dimension caricature, mirroring your world's real beauty. Clever.Little silly spoiler ahead I never saw such line so perfectly timed with an event in a game's plot. Already expecting the worse, Alice's mind immediately triggers the Wonderlands, but gradually warping the place into a hell hole makes you think. What is exactly that is happening, assuming this is but an dream? "It's just a game'' claims the skeptics, but the undertones on the dark music will never let you forget to theorize things like beating or touching. Water falls made out of tears are sad enough, but hot grease/tea eruptions? Shocking.Thoughts, not spoiler On my opinion, whatever is happening, Alice is obviously far away from being a hero. I don't like her so forced voice acting, but she's anti-hero by all rights and means. And even if a darker plot is taking place she isn't saving anything, sometimes not even her own self. In the other half you feel this ''I don't care'' trying to erupt somewhere. That's a common child abuse collateral. No worries, this is just another subtle message from the writer, we live on a society that bad plus rebellion equals to hell. Like literally assuming she-demon powers, like in the first version? Intriguing.Post Traumatic Disorder victims treatments often relies on remembrances, you do that the whole game but the memories seems to be all but fragmentated, shattering the little reality there is and you just can't trust the Cat. (best voice acting in the whole game) Curiously, he seems to be the salvation. The granny is drinking to get higher, Alice's drinking to get smaller. Step on a violet plant with arms pushing her down, it closes but you don't lose any health. Sad.My interpretation This is truly an sophisticated psychological triller of the most saddest and subtle meaning I ever came to play and because of that, I'm always fully depressed during and after my gameplay. (the game is great for delivering it so precisely and subtly) I don't have control over my character, I don't know what is happening to her real ''her'' in the third dimension that is, leaving lots of room for interpretation. It makes me feel that I'm just helping the character to get even more lost instead of saving her, and this is absolutelly depressing. Devs went after some psychologist or pedagogue on the matter, Alice is definitelly being molested on her outter self... But as the game has a non-realistic approach on the theme, it is obvious that some darker forces are taking advantage of her unfortunate condition. So you will find a lot of possible fantasy themes in there and not all of them are on the third dimension... see? If the dark music is cool, so it's when on action, making the game looking even weirder (positively). Outstanding.To avoid any massive spoiler, I'll finish it. Sick/saddest/awkward game I ever played, which wages an perpetual war between subliminal conceptualisations and a nice third person gameplay. Go for it, but please, this isn't a children oriented game. Speaking of which, always be smart and gentle with children and teenagers... that's what the message is all about. Optimistic?

												The artwork in this game is really awesome, I love the scenery and the whole style of the game in general. It can go from a bright beautiful setting with an upbeat tune and nature sounds, to a dark twisted scene with eerie music and a cold feel, in matters of seconds. content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Alice Madness Returns is a great, well put together, 3rd person action game. First of all, you can clearly see from screenshots and videos that this game is a great looking one, sometimes even breathtaking. The game is divided into 6 chapters and each chapter has its own unique look and they all look great and I think the developers did a really good job in creating a Wonderland that is shaped out by Alice herself. Along with the corrupted Alice mind and the corrupted Wonderland the creatures that once lived there also became corrupted and even though I found the enemies to be really well designed at first, they quickly get repeated over and over throughout the entirety of the game but they still provide solid and enjoyable combat scenarios.Alice Madness Returns tells you the story of how Alice thinks she's responsible for the fire that burned down her house and also killed her parents and sister. She gets the help of a doctor from an asylum which tries to make her forget about what happened and that it wasn't her fault. By thinking that she was responsible for the death of her family, her mind becomes corrupted, and so the Wonderland, and this is where the game takes place. Throughout the game you'll visit various regions of the Wonderland which have become corrupted and each one them has been designed in a very unique way.Alice Madness Returns is pretty much a straight up linear third person action game with alot of platforming segments, puzzles, minigames and alikes. The game rewards exploration by giving you extra health and teeth, which you can use to upgrade your weapons (knife, hammer, pepper gun and tea cannon), not only you get small benefits by exploring but you'll also be able to collect "memories". Memories are audio logs that when picked up they will trigger a memory of someone you know on the real world, this, in my opinion, makes the storyline progression not that linear in the way that if you don't explore and don't collect all the memories you probably won't get certain parts and you won't understand the game that well. The gameplay is pretty simple, you walk/run, you can jump, glide while in the air and jump multiple times while in the air, this is the key, along with great timing, to solve alot of "jumping puzzles" that are scattered throughout the entire game. I mentioned above that there are also some kind of puzzles and mini games, the two examples I can think of right now is some kind of minigame which plays pretty much like Super Monkey Ball and another one is chess, except that in this chess you have a maximum number of moves that you need to use in order to move two pieces of the chessboard to a certain location by moving them at the same time (pressing right will make one piece go to your right and the other piece move to your left, inverted chess if you can call it that way).Besides what I already mentioned I think nothing else needs to be told about this great video game. Absolutely gorgeous environments and music, well designed and breathtaking scenarios, surprisingly good and interesting storyline and characters along with the solid and satisfying hack and slash combat are reason more than enough for me to recommend this game and for you to pick it up.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Alice Madness Returns is possibly my favourite game of all time. It's a beautiful game, with cleaver puzzles, lock-based hack'n'slash combat.The audio is very well done, with excellent ambient music and scores. You play as Alice Liddle, exploring the memories of your past to find who set her house on fire, killing the entire family.You can shrink to fit in tight spots, and see things that you normally wouldn't see.Triple jump, with a very nice floury effect, floating to those; hard-to-reach areas.Dashing out of the way is nicely done, turn into a flutter of butterflies then reappear out of harms way.The environments were stunning, gorgeous and serene, contrasting to the dark and ominous. Cut-scenes are fantastic, very well animated. (Love the art style)It's a memorable experience; a game you'll never forget.The minigames are enjoyable and well designed.Had puzzles that once completed I thought "damn, that was pretty cool." so I loaded an earlier checkpoint to replay the puzzle.Makes me sad that the first game (American Mcgee's Alice) isn't on sale anywhere. Not even on origin. Controls take some time yo get used to. (if playing keyboard) but it's still playable.Collecting teeth will let you upgrade your weapons to make more powerful versions. Each has it's unique use.Bugs:I have had several issues with enemies/minibosses being invincible, thus prevent progress. (Mostly in CH5: The Dollhouse) Restarting from last checkpoint/restarting game fixed it, but it got rather annoying. * There are a few tweeks you should do in the config file before playing, ie; Removing the 30fps cap, unlocking the dlc...)(Check player guides)* Required a one-time activation on Origin. Origin does not have to be open to play this.10/10 Must Try.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns.(What is it?)This game is a twisted take on Alice's wonderland, often macabre and dark,  sometimes just gloomy, this game touches on topics like denial, insanity, murder and molestation, and the story is probably the darkest i've ever seen in a video game.  The story has a TON of twists and plot holes, though i wont spoil it, if you have any triggers about♥♥♥♥♥♥ insanity, denial, murder and so on; do NOT buy this game.Best storyline i've seen in a LONG time 9.5/10(Is the gameplay good?)In MY opinion, no, i do not like the platforming, and the combat is very flawed. The level design sometimes suprises me, but it's often just generic platforming with very little inspiration. I can tell that this game took inspiration from psychonauts and the previous alice game, however. it fails miserabely to emulate the charm and wit of those games. As quoting the children in the orphanage "Mad as a hatter, without the charm" I will not lie, the game has allot of suprises when it comes to gameplay, and dependant on what kind of gamer you are, these changes can make or break you. I did however feel a huge rush of adrenaline when in hysteria mode.Decent-ish combat, but sub-par level design. 6.4(I do not mean the graphics and visual stlye.)(How does the game look?)Put Psychonauts in a blender, add some denial and a few doll heads, and some rabbit blood to boot. There's your game. In all seriousness though, the game looks amazing. The visual styles often remind you of how you're inside alice's broken mind. Graphical quality could be better, the post-processing is ugly, and the game doesnt run as well as it should.Amazing visual styles, but i bet this game would run on the original xbox. 8.8(So is this game right for me?)If you're like me, you like a deep and dark storyline over amazing gameplay. The gameplay in this is not to my tastes, but the story is just perfect. I recommend playing the previous Alice, however, first. As I like a deep/dark story line WITH amazing gameplay, I'd play Kingdom Hearts 2 Final Mix over this any day, but this is so much darker.If you liked the walking dead and psychonauts, yes, this game is right for you.(Replay value?)Nothing for me, i doubt i'll go anywhere near the game now that i've completed it.No score for this yet.SUMMARY:8.5 The game is great, though very flawed, the story makes up for the lack of innovative level design, and  shabby combat. If you're just in it for the combat, don't get it. If you want a story that will be in your mind forever, It's well worth whatever you pay.Small update: Haven't played for about a year now, and I have no desire to.

												Alice... Alice... Alice... I have to say i was very skeptical about getting this game, seeing that im not as big on Alice in wonderland than a lot of mainstream society. I jumped into it and found it to be a very smooth game with devilish humor and dark suggestive intents. This game fits me perfectly as for my studies in college and career wise. It plays on psychological themes in Alice's mind. Her memories, and within those memories a very dark and gritty atmosphere. I have only just started this game and i feel i definitely got my money's worth and i plan on continuing this game. The graphics in this game.. although they're not amazing, they're clear, dark themed and her hair... my god, every strand of hair she has moves with her. They did quite amazing on the physics. This game not only captures a dark mind of a schizophrenic Alice, but involves a dark world with kind of a scary, horrific tendency to keep you compelled to keep playing. The combat is actually fun, i actually really enjoyed it and it's difference on crouching and dodging. It involves her teleporting into butterflies and shifting around the enemies. The combat so far uses a knife that can upgrade. it's actually quite fitting for the type of game it is. So i leave you with this, i recommend this game through and through and i'm not even done the story yet. When i do finish the story i will probably update this review even more but i just feel with this game it's too good to pass up. I just wish i had played the first one so i could understand everything. Enjoy this game.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												This game revisits the fantastic and equally unique, Quake-Engine built, American McGee's Alice, and went under the radar as a rough diamond at the time of release mostly because of its rushed release schedule, and in part because of how different it was. It's a relic of a better time in that it uses good old golden-era game design elements, like introducing you to new enemies every so often, teaching you how to use abilities and combat techniques, and then testing your skills with bosses and platforming sections. Some players will find frustration in these forced hold-backs and see them as restrictions, others will love the less forgiving gameplay.HighlightsExploring the world and discovering the, albeit thin, story and character history while passing through some stunning visuals is a real blast. I couldn't stop taking screenshots from start to finish and most of what makes this game so much damn fun to dig through comes from the diverse but always distinct and visually compelling art style.* Interesting, worthwhile collectibles and extras which add to the replay value. For example, unlocking new dresses gives you different abilities.* Some of the best visual elements and art styles of any game ever made, despite the now aging graphics and texture resolution.* Lots of interesting new gameplay elements as you progress and weapon design of a somewhat different calibre.* Old school Apply-What-You've-Learned boss battles and progresion.MistakesDevelopment for this title was rushed out by EA and it suffered as a result. Despite a number of small issues in different areas, it's a striking and alluring solidly built piece of awesome gaming which lets you to forgive its few mistakes.* Invisible walls, when coupled with the, at times, unpredictable controls can cause frustration and take away from the gameplay.* Mildly repetitive combat and lack of weapon variety despite the very interesting weapon designs are an oversight.* There are annoying bugs and a general lack of polish in some areas, and some underlying technical issues.RecommendationsAlice clocks in at an incredibly satisfying 13-15 hours of play time and even has lots replayability for completionists. It's fairly priced, currently at £14.99/9.99€/$19.99 it's cheapest by far from Europe. It goes on sale at -75% at least once per year on Steam, usually during the big sales and is well worth buying then.* Like most EA games, Alice: Madness Returns includes a free CD Key which can be redeemed on your Origin account/client. To activate, right click Alice in your library menu and select View CD Key, then simply redeem that key from inside Origin as you would any other game.* The DLC is included on Steam for free. It's hidden, but takes 60 seconds to activate. [Instructions to unlock the DLC are available here](https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=121133044)* While fine with a keyboard, Alice handles better with a controller.

Posted: November 25, 2012
												I really enjoyed playing this game. My initial reaction was that it handles horribly, but once you actually get past the real world and into Wonderland the game really opens up and allows for excellent platforming and combat. The pinned down and awkwardly restricted feel of being in the real world serves to highlight how liberating going to Wonderland is for Alice, even if it has been overrun by horrible monsters. The story is dark and quite cleverly written, which really helps to drive the whole game along and keep you wanting to find out more (as if exploring the scenery and cutting up creepy slime-oozing dolls wasn't enough to keep you moving through Wonderland). Collecting memories as you explore your damaged mind helps to slowly reveal the entirety of the story in all its ugliness. Definitely worth a play; I would have to list this amongst my very favourite games such as Psychonauts and Second Sight. 10 out of 10, would psychoanalyse.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2016
												Alice: Madness Returns is possibly the first game to make me wish that reviews had a third option: a shrug. A "meh". A non commital "eh, it's alright."Well, that went ahead and summed up my review. To explain, I need to emphasize that this game is in no way a bad game. It simply has too much going for it to be a bad game. The art style, something many agree upon in their reviews, is tremendous. Each scenic area is more beautiful, more mystifying, more creative, and more surreal than the last. The combat is visceral and feels great. Indeed, it is very responsive and very smooth. When you're not pitted against enemies, you're platforming, and the controls in a platformer need to be of a very high quality lest the player get upset that they're fighting the controls and camera. Alice: MR succeeds at this and provides more than enough options for the player to overcome any and all obstacles and jumps to be done.This sounds really positive, but honestly, these are the only positive things Alice: MR deserves, as it simply fails at so many other things. While the combat feels great, it gets incredibly repititive and boring, never really rising above any sort of difficulty. In fact, I died two times in the entire game, and felt challenged only in one of those two fights. Every single other encounter had me quickly dispatching the enemy and moving on, never really feeling like I was overcoming anything. On the other hand, the platforming feels great, but due to the fact that Alice gets three jumps as well as a long distance float, levels end up being stretched to large scales, creating a sense of emptiness. Indeed, while the levels look very pretty, they are also nearly completely lifeless and hollow.But you know what's worse than the levels being as lifeless and hollow as they are? The fact that they go on FOREVER. Seriously. Alice: MR should not have been longer than a five hour game in all honesty, but it took me fourteen hours of what I would describe as "slogging" through the game in hopes of finding a conclusion to the madness. The various chapters will pack a punch in the beginning but will ultimately fail to keep you interested not even before you get 1/6th of the way through a chapter. You'll be forced to perform some ridiculous pace breaking puzzle like solving a shifting cube puzzle or playing chess instead of simple progression, and believe me when I say that you will end up just skipping all of the minigames after a certain threshold of tolerance. Before every level there is a segment where Alice wanders through her city in a non combative, explorative manner, and honestly, this is the best part of the game. This is where all of the (very minimal) story is, and once it's over, you realize you're going to have to slog through 3-4 hours of repetitive gameplay before you get to have more story. And that's weird, right? Wanting the gameplay in a video game to be over with so you can enjoy the non gameplay parts. Guess that's just the sort of Madness in Alice: Madness Returns.I think the biggest problem stems from the fact that there is no hub world like, say, Super Mario 64 or Banjo Kazooie, Instead of getting a variety of small but interesting levels with lots to do, you are forced onto a "train" of endless repetitiveness and linearity. Imagine if Super Mario Sunshine had no Delfino Plaza but, instead, you simply moved from one level to the next, and instead of these levels being detailed and full of stuff to do, they were stretched out into a blank, empty shell of its former self. Actually, I guess that kind of sounds like New Super Mario Land. Huh.So, do I recommend Alice: MR? Yes, but with a huge caveat: it's entertaining, but only in the shortest bursts. Attempting to play for too long will drive you... quite mad.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												Charming, twisted and beautiful; a 3D platformer set in a darkened, nightmare dreamscape of the Wonderland mythos. Aside from the theme, what sets Alice: Madness Returns apart from other 3D platformers? The answer here would be, without a doubt, the environments. The platforming itself isn't taxing, it's simply the mode through which we traverse the obscenely pretty level design; whether it be the Victorian, smokey and claustrophobic city; the pristine fantasy of Wonderland, contrasted very quickly with a horror-packed perverted version of; a dirty, mechanical Hatter's domain; or an underwater grotto. What of the gameplay? The platforming is fun, and whilst not difficult, it's not dull either, and is often spiced up with some combat - which, with a controller, feels fairly robust, isn't overwhelming and offers a satisfying break from platforming. The story, in collusion with the environments, delves into the sick mind of our mad Alice, spiralling downwards with a half-memory of burning her home, and in the process, killing her family. As is often hinted at, Alice is duelling with real-life turmoil manifesting itself through her fallen-from-grace Wonderland, and therein lies the key element of the game, the pivotal relationship between her unreconciled conscious and unconscious.  All in all, Alice: Madness Returns feels cohesive and well put together. The gameplay is solid, but the real reason to play is the journey you'll take.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I went in with not much of an idea what the game was, but I expected a dark themed Wonderland with some Wonderland themed enemies, weird looking scenarios, and maybe something more of a horror story. Sadly, that wasn't what I got.What is the game? Imagine God of War, with less fighting, more awkward floaty jumped platforming and stuff to collect that you might not even know what it does, and no boss fights even though it teases you like there's going to be one, but then cancels it, plus a very weird narrative that you are supposed to care for.Do I recommend it? Well, no, not if you're expecting greatness from this game. If you're on for a mediocre game that in terms of gameplay puts nothing new on the table, and has a story that might get more interesting and twisted and psychological towards the end (which I personally still hope it does, as I have yet to see anything like that), then sure, go for it.To mark my point it might just be better to list what I liked and what I didn't. Just keep in mind that these are my opinions and that I have yet to complete the game, and these are the points I already feel are faulty for the enjoyment of this game. Let's start with the dislikes:· The camera acceleration is too fast and feels wonky, as in unstable. When in first person view though it becomes too slow.· Weapon upgrades that just upgrade the weapon and give it a new look, what new features it has beside that? Who knows, more damage? Maybe, didn't feel like much though after upgrading the knife twice.· Enemies. The common enemy is a petrol blob with a baby doll face and some tubes on it's back. Then there's a giant version of it with more faces and doll arms. A floating version also exists and who knows what else. Not the most interesting enemies to see. Each zone seems to have 2-3 extra monsters in it, which is still underwhelming to be honest. Industry zone has a nice looking mechanical tea pot, which fits the theme of the Mad Hatter, flying screws that come from a metal nest, not the fanciest of designs, and some goblins with cutlery and cups as helmets, which are fine. Water zone has walking Angler fish and crabs with a cannon arm and a cigar to light it, yay?· The combat lock camera and parry. You want to fight multiple enemies at once and parry? Then you shall only lock onto one and THEN be able to use the parry, and while locked, not know what comes from behind as you can't really move the camera and are constantly facing the enemy.· No boss fights. The thing I hoped would happen after so many repetitive fights, but no, there are no boss fights, which might have been even a good idea, cause who knows how they might have turned out.· Bugs. Most noticeable during a 2D ship segment, which is supposed to be able to fire, yet none of the commands worked, not even in a secret room which had a harder version of that segment. Sometimes a line is said just before another characted finished his. Some say there are more, I haven't found them yet, thank god.· The jumps are way too floaty and combined with the weird camera you'll probably miss a lot of jumps, specially since most of the game seems to be floating platforms.· The soundtrack (if I dare call it so). I read praise for it, yet when I play the game, all I can hear is a 5 tune loop that becomes very repetitive, obnoxious and boring. It makes the platforming even less entertaining. It just feels slow.· Alice's voice acting. For a character that at the start of the game narrates that she's traumatized and her Wonderland is broken and twisted, as the imagery suggests, she sounds pretty uninterested when she actually lands there. She sounds the same in all the conversations I've heard her speak yet. The other characters at least put some emotion or charisma in it, whereas Alice probably could see her house go on fire (again) and say "Oh, well that isn't pleasant at all, what a shame, better move along".· The graphic designs of the levels. I've seen 3 areas, and I only liked the first one, as it was Wonderland, it was nature mixed with weird elements like domino pieces, statues, the potion that lets you shrink, the colors. It was nice to look at indeed. The other two areas, well.. The second is an industry level, which, oh joy, mostly greyish and brown colors, like in all the other games, though admitedly, some rooms where alright when mixed with the lava fountains. Third area, water levels (without the physics), cause everyone loves them, specially when it's all dark, the wall decoration doesn't stick out much, and once again, there isn't much to look at. And yes, I said I expected a dark themed Wonderland, but then again, what part of this is it? And if you make the platforming boring, at least make the visuals more fancy.· The narrative. The point that should get you hooked, but kinda fails to do so, at least for me. Care as this part might contain a bit of spoilers until the 3rd area, which is where i'm currently at. It starts with you telling your Doc your trauma in the real world, which is pretty♥♥♥♥♥♥ as you might expect and that's perfectly fine. Then you're sent off to get some medicine, on the way you encounter people with weird rabbit faces (which would have been nice enemies, but I have yet to see them), which turn out to be illusions which disappear after an old lady talks to you. Till this point, I found it pretty good. Then you are on a rooftop with the old lady, some dialogue happens, she gets a weird rabbit head, the floor breaks and you fall into neverland. I suppose that it despicts your mind while you fainted in real life. What I don't get is how after the 1st and 2nd area, you go back to the real life world, and have her wake up at a port, there's not too much that explains it, and once again Alice does not sound concerned at all. Meanwhile in Wonderland, the part that you play more actively, you "have" to collect your memories, which are very loose sentences someone spoke, either your doctor, or your therapist, or family. I say "have" because it seems to be more of an optional task, as you can miss them, simply ignore to collect them, and some are even hidden (though not too much either because the game tells you everything about the level). So, while there are cutscenes after long whiles and completing an area, which talk about Alice's past, these memories do so as well, yet not really in a satisfactional way. I remember one saying something alike "Some insects eat their young, Alice. They have much to teach us, alive or dead.", which only made me question what the hell that had to do with my house burning down.I really don't know if I'm missing something because I haven't played the first Alice game, but this one feels just weird.Things that I liked:· Alice's character design and change of dress when in a different area.. The idea of a twisted Wonderland.. The characters you encoutner and their voice acting.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Alice: The Madness returns is a game where the enjoyment of the gameplay and narrative may stand apart from eachother.Let's start with the part that  ends up failing: Its platforming.There is a distinction to be made between not challenging and boring or tedious. In this game's case, it is the latter when speaking of it's platforming element, the practise of jumping across platforms to reach your destination.While the difficulty of the jumping puzzles does raise slightly, it rarely introduces new elements or methods of thinking that help you pass future puzzles. The gimmick remains simple. Jump platforms until you can no more, shrink yourself to see secret platforms or keyholes, and flick switches and shoot targets to progress further. The implementation of the latter two eventually ends up to be slightly confusing in the last chapter, but not excessively so.This simply is a case of a gaming element that is it's weakest part, while being omnipresent. If the platforming wasn´t basically the only method of transportation throughout the game, it could´ve been forgiveable. But right now it becomes a question of whether the game can be redeemed by it's strengths.One thing that surely is not one of it's strengths is the combat. A lot of interest from this games comes from people having played the original American McGee's Alice. There, the platforming was somewhat reduced and combat took a much higher priority.In Alice: Madness Returns, combat takes a little bit of a backseat. The grand array of weaponry has been replaced with your faithful old knife, a pepper grinder for a quick firing ranged weapon, a Hobby Horse as your heavy attack and a Teapot as a heavy bombardment firearm. Each of these are unlocked throughout the game, and do tend to play a part in progressing the platforming. But not in a Metroidvania style, of course. There's no level backtracking, which is good because that only helps one of the games strengths stand out: The design.If there is one thing that the game developers did spot on, it was level design. In many levels, you feel like things have been hand placed. Every area feels unique, and are beautiful in their own respect. Seldom have I felt as enticed to just stop and look at the areas that I pass, as I have with this game. While I will not say that there have been some less interesting corridors, they are far and few between. All in all, the world does not just imply madness, it genuinely invites the player to believe that they are in a world of fantasy, where they can safely forget the rules of reality. And a play on reality this game really is, at least when going by it's story...The story of Alice: Madness Returns is not the best I've ever experienced. In the end, it did not make me think deeply or differently about the things that I already knew in life. But it follows three storylines and beautifully merges them together at the right time. These storylines are mainly Alice in reality, dealing with events around her as she tries to manage menial tasks ; her investigation of why her 'Wonderland' is slowly falling to ruin ; and her placing pieces together of her past, the burning of her home and family that left her in this state to begin with. These three branches meet in the end and reveal the final plot, which wasn't very surprising, but very well orchestrated nonetheless.Alice: Madness Returns is not very good as a game. But as a narrative story that allows some interaction, mainly serving progress, it can manage to suck you in and make you want to finish it. Which is the way that everyone should experience this game:Play it once, enjoy and experience the story to it's fullest and end, and keep that experience with you. But probably not play it again.Priced 10 at time of writing, a 50% off should certainly justify the purchase of this title.Get this game if you are interested in a good story and are curious about American McGee's version of the Alice universe. Put the game on easy (there are no achievements to speak of) and try to muscle through the platforming, and you'll be rewarded with a worthy storyline, well narrated and voiced appropriately.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Bought this game then proceeded to spend three quarters of my waking hours over the next few days spelunking through the depths of Alice's insanity, the girl's got issues, to say the least. And after that dose of crazy, I've been having funky dreams, too. Been a while since a game drew me in this much. Consider this TL;DR.Now onwards, to the good, the bad, and the ugly.THE GOOD:The aesthetics. The scenery is really satisfying and pretty, even when obviously bad things are happening. It changes slowly, sometimes subtly, but you can't help but notice how broken Alice's mind is once you scratch the surface. And the journey is going to be long, indeed. Things will get worse before they get better. Also Alice's dresses, they're lovely and fit the theme of whichever part of her mind she's currently in. Complete mood whiplash when you swap into the monochrome-with-red Hysteria mode that's one of the best visual depictions of psychotic episodes I've ever seen.The combat. It flows nicely, and all enemies have their weak and strong spots. A few occasions will pit you against a formidable challenge, and split-second decisions will need to be made to survive. The weapons are imaginative and you can switch between them seamlessly, and Alice isn't shy about using them. The variety of enemies is decent, and all of them represent some mental problem Alice is dealing with. You also get a last stand mechanic, once you're down to your last rose, you can enter Hysteria mode (or "Psycho Mode" as I like to call it) which renders you invincible and increases damage for a short while (while looking awesomely morbid and badass), and if you gather more health while under effect, you can chan it if you drop to a single rose again. Don't get too reliant on it, though, later on many enemies can do enough damage to not even let you have the chance to use it.The sounds. From Alice's voice acting that does wonders for relaying her personality and Cheshire Cat cryptic snarking, to the ambient sounds and the soundtrack itself, you won't even notice most of it because it flows so seamlessly into the setting and just becomes part of the whole experience. The subtle puns. "Train of thought", "Jumping off the slippery slope" and "Shattered mind" are quire real in the Wonderland, to say the least.The ending. It leaves things open to interpretations, of which I have at least three competing ones at the moment, ranging from mildly optimistic to downright depressing, and none of them is more likely than any other. It's that kind of game.THE BAD:The lack of bosses, especially since it's obvious they were planned, but only one made it to release. Why did that happen? Well, likely budget or deadline problems, and considering who published the game, that doesn't surprise me. There are some tough, mini-boss like enemies, but they can't both present challenges at significant points of the game, AND not get a little repetitive as the time goes by.The game feels shorter than it could have been. There's more to explore, Alice's mental issues run deep indeed, and at times I felt as if things were unraveling too fast, some characters aren't explored as deeply as they could have been. With the cast, content and concept, this game could have been made considerably longer, however...The platforming sections sometimes feel too long, and start screaming "filler" at you. Especially in the first and fifth chapter, there were extended times when I felt I wasn't actually doing anything, nor getting any closer to the underlying mental taint while I spent long periods of time getting from point A to point B. The platforming puzzles themselves are okay, but sometimes too concentrated.The focus mode. While combat is good, this is one aspect that simply doesn't work. The focus mode only really works one-on-one since it forces you into wonky camera angles, so aside from the scene not looking as gracefully badass as it couls, the beasties trying to eat your brain from directions other than twelve o' clock are going to become a real problem. This mode is reduced to something you use to deal with the strong enemies once you've dispatched the trash mooks through normal (and impressive-looking!) combat. A shame, really, because it has much potential for blocking and ranged combat.The occasional glitches. The only one I really ran into occasionally was invisible ankle-high-walls in the middle of nowhere that I got stuck on and had to jump over which cost me just enough time to have to restart the jumping puzzle, but people also report crashing and the like.THE UGLY:The truth. Not going to spoil, but bloody hell, the truth is ugly.Several enemy types. If you think being insane could be kind of cool, remember that you really don't want these abominations traipsing through your skull. Sanity is not overrated.Everyone except Alice. Honestly, pretty much everyone except the protagonist looks like they just crawled out of the gutter. Whether it's just her perception of everyone is up to interpretation. I'd say that it likely is, especially considering who the only other relatively normal-looking character is.THE BOTTOM LINE:If you like platformers, atmospheric horror, and disturbing, morbid content, this is a game for you if you're willing to forgive its flaws and the fact that it requires EA authentication (but not an Origin account, oddly enough). Oh, and this game definitely isn't something you want to let your kids play in the evening.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Alice: Madness Returns is an underrated gem. I think for many people, this game flew under the radar, at least during the year of its release. Quite simply, Alice is one of the best platformers to come out in recent years. Even after 5 years the game holds up incredibly well. The art style is simply unparalleled, the ominous music and dark vibes are enthralling and the game is stunning all around. The combat is definitely solid, perhaps the only area  that isn't stellar are the platforming sections. However, I really don’t find as much fault with these sections as others have. The only major fault I have is that the PC version by default is capped at 30 fps. There was no need for this at all. (This can be changed in an .ini file)If you haven’t played this game yet, please, do yourself a favor and pick it up!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												It's really good... yet flawed. The game is excessively linear and can feel a bit repetitive after the first chapters. There's a lot of platforming sections, and I really think you should use a controller to be more precise with your movements. Also unlocking the 30 fps cap helps a lot because it will obviously make the game feel a lot more responsive. You are also sometimes presented with puzzles and mini-games, but these tend to be very basic and fail to result interesting... some of the mini-games simply outstay their welcome. The combat is fast and feels good, thanks to interesting weapons and some creative enemies. Yet the camera does sometimes go nuts when you lock on targets, it gets stuck in the most unconvenient of angles.Aside from solving puzzles, fighting stuff and jumping from platform to platform, the game doesn't really offer much more in terms of gameplay. It took me 12 hours to finish it on hard difficulty and I have to say I don't really feel like going for a second playthrough. I guess I could raise the difficulty to nightmare, find all the collectibles (they add details to the main story) and maybe change the voice acting to my native language but... 12 more hours are going to feel like a lot of time now that I know how the story unfolds.The narrative and writing in this game is what really got me, I think it's pretty good. Many things are left unclear because Alice is costantly in a state of deep mental confusion, so that you are left with interpreting a lot of stuff on your own. Including the meaning of the ending sequence. The developers have revealed what you may call the canonical meaning for the ending of the game, but it doesn't really feel much of a payoff to me, so I am willing to simply reject it in favour of my own interpretation. Another strong aspect in the game is the overall graphical design. Every chapter takes place in completely different landscapes, and all of them feel very inspired and sick. The screenshots in the store page don't really show you that much, but this is a game where Alice's mind is on the verge of complete and utter madness, so don't expect Wonderland to look all cute and safe. Even the real world sections are great and succeed in depicting industrial London as a grim, dirty and vicious place. The beginning of chapter 2 is the only part of the game which I didn't like from a graphical standpoint, but that section lasts merely half an hour.Keep in mind that you will need to activate the game via an EA account before you can play it, and that buying it from Steam will NOT give you access to the DLC and to the original game American McGee's Alice... though it is possible to unlock the DLC by changing a single parameter in the same .ini file that you need to tweak in order to get rid of the fps cap.To summarize, avoid the game if you don't like platforming. Do not expect any replay value unless you like hunting for collectibles. Use a controller, enjoy the writing and aesthetics and don't miss the train!
