content:
Posted: January 22
												I love Alice:Madness Returns. It's a wonderful perspective of the classic Alice in Wonderland story. It centers around Alice being insane, suffering from the guilt of killing her family by accidentally setting her house on fire while everyone was trapped inside. (Don't worry, by the way: none of this is spoiler) Bereft of a home she's forced to move into an orphanage for kids with troubled pasts. While there she gets treated by a psychologist who advises her to create a "happy place" in her mind, also know as "Wonderland". However, her inner turmoil slowly begins to pervade and poison Wonderland, causing it to decay and fall apart. Throughout the game her favoriate imaginary pet/spirit animal/Jiminy Cricket Cheshire, along with the other iconic characters of the book, guides her through her tattered mind in an attempt to help fix Wonderland, and, by extension, herself. However as she digs deeper into her mind, she finds that all is not how it seems.The game is absolutely beautiful; everything you would have read in the book is here is this game, but completely reimagined to fit the new story. Most of time, you'll be tempted to just stop and oggle at all the beautiful, colorful structures there are. The developers attempted to encompass quite a couple different art styles in the game as well. There's one chapter where everything has been imagined as if it came off the scroll of a traditional Japanese painting. It's eery but still beautiful at the same time.It's your traditional platformer; not much to say here. You run, you jump, you try to keep from falling. That's not really the most difficult part of the game, but it can be challenging when the platforms move around so creatively. It gets difficult at some very rare times, but not so much to become frustrating.The part that sold me the most was the fighting. Over time Alice is equipped with a unique arsenal of weapons, each specifically tailored to handle a particular set of enemies. She has a knife for elegant-yet-deadly combos, a hobby horse for hard-hitting skull-bashing, a pepper shaker that doubles as an smg, a tea kettle cannon ('nuff said), and a dainty little umbrella to repel and block the heavy hits she can take. And if all of that isn't enough she come fitted with a dodge that allows her back-stab/smash just anyone that gets in her way, which, in this game, is just about everyone.Overall, the game attempts to have a little something for everybody, at least, those interested in RPGs, anyway. There's puzzles, fighting gauntlets, 2D and 3D platforming, ball-rolling puzzles, shmupping, and some other stuff I've probably missed. If some of those don't tickle you, then don't worry. They happen in chapter formation, so even if you don't like a particular mechanic, you won't see it for too terribly long.The game is great! I would totally buy it if you love beautiful scenery and excellent fights!

												Absolutely gorgeous exhibition of the Unreal engine.Well made, no bugs, if you're someone who digs on graphics, buy this, right now.If you aren't, and it's on sale, buy this, right now.The story is great, the gameplay is great, it's a well made action-slasher.I have 402 games in my library, this remains on my top 3 favorite out of all of them along with Fallout 4 and Don't Starve.Pros:-Beautiful scenery-Story-driven gameplay (but not the kind that drags on with text boxes)-Excellent voice acting-Costumes change with the theme of the level, in addition to being selectable later, they also grant bonuses, this really helps to keep the game fresh-Collectibles, so many collectibles-Good selection of weapons, as well as upgrades for them-Support for VR with VorpX-Incredibly polished 3D mode (one of the few that runs perfectly in 3D), the butterflies, dear god the butterflies-Themed steampunk/gothic style environment for a change from the norm-You can buy itCons:-Combat can feel a little dull when fighting super-bosses, they quickly become rinse/repeat cycles-Finding all the collectibles can be a drag if you're a perfectionist-The game ends-No native VR support-No googly eye mod for Alice-Features Kim Jong Un as the March Hare-I don't have any more drugs-You haven't bought it yet

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												A good third-person Action/Adventure Platformer with varied weapons, enemies, collectibles, locations and even gameplay.Great art, story and protagonist.It has a casual design with simple mechanics and most everything being explained to you before you can figure them out for yourself, you can even skip the already few puzzles.The combat works but the narrow camera angle makes it hard to see enemies around you, a lot of spinning is necessary.Also you can't switch to enemies off-screen with the Lock-On system, so you have to constantly turn it on and off as it is needed to fight some of the enemies.Getting used to these things makes the combat better.The biggest problem I have with the game is the fact that most of what you do in it is traverse environments devoid of enemies but FULL of easy "puzzles" like putting weight on a pressure plate for a platform to go up.Ignoring collectibles/sidetracks makes the experience flow a lot better.The music is great, but most tracks are short and get repetitive quickly.You'll need to change some things in .ini files to go above 30 FPS and unlock the extra content.Check the Steam guides.Played with a wired Xbox 360 controller.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												This is one of those divisive games, and one has to look no further than it's Metacritic page to find evidence: 75 among critics, 85 among players. It's certainly a weird one, so it earns both sides of the argument. But here's whats up and why you should pick it up: The combat is like the R rated version of Wind Waker and is oh so fun when it shines. I recommend playing on a harder dificulty to increase the visceral satisfaction. Switching between weapons is fluid and natural (Hobby Horse/Vorpal Blade combos are SO satisfying).The atmoshpere is astonishing and unsettling in equal measure. The environments are gorgeous but there's always a sense that something isn't quite right, a sense magnified by the very sparse background music and ambient noise.The weapon upgrade system is satisfying and gives a purpose to the collect-a-thon style gameplay. And here's some nagging issues:It's overstays it's welcome. Seriously, levels stretch on and on and there aren't enough world-specific mechanics to sustain interest. There are multiple times when one can't help but think "alright, I get it. Can we move on now?". Spicy Horse could learn a thing or two from Nintendo's book on how to constantly surprise the player.There are some shockingly bad textures in this game, which is so strange coming from a game with an otherwise very strong visual aesthetic. I understand it's an indie title, but more than a handful of other titles have proved that simply being an indie isn't an excuse.  Overall it's an easy recommendation simply because there's not a lot else like it and if the darker aesthetic is something that appeals to you then you're in for a treat. Buy it and revel in the glory that is the Hobby-Horse.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2014
												"Only the savage regard the endurance of pain as the measure of worth"-cheshire cat Alice Madness returns Takes place almost almost as soon as you leave The asylum from the First game and Return to the World of Wonderland...not only is wonderland Shattering but most of its inhabitants Though Deranged and Wicked are also feeling the effects of alice's own Horrific Imagination.  *Note that i beat alice on nightmare and got 99% complete, =( missed like 2 Memories </3    Mechanics wise for a Platforming/Adventure game Alice plays very solid as the combat is Fluid and somewhat Forgiving with some heal drops from slain enemies, but Difficutly can be ramped up with the Cosmetics like denying Those heal drops and only recovering health through special Flowers found in the level.  Controls Feel Great on PC with Key board and mouse, though i believe it is possible to hook up your Xbox Controller. The only problem i have found is that the camera tends to Swing left and right very dramatically while exploring in areas where the developers wanted a sudden change in camera angle (though not game breaking). Jumping from platform to platform and other various puzzles feels great.    Art Style and Presentation is off the chart, this game had some talented designers since every chapter is a diffrent theme, impressive and not even campy. From Bizzare land scapes to under water Habitats, very gruesome killings, body parts, decapitations, hangings, etc  it is all well done, the game puts you into a very immersive ride through alice's Story. Character designs are great, even a Enemy or two actually gave me chills while fighting them, especially in the kids land...*shivers*   THough the game differs from the 1st alice, it plays really well along with some old returning characters more as Interactable characters and plot devices. With a slew of Toys such as the Memorable Vorpal Blade, The Hobby horse that breaks most if not all gaurds, A shield that knocks enemy attacks back and some long range fire power, there is a multitude of ways to beat your enemies but employing and quickly switching too and fro through all your weapons is a must skill to have if you wish to live long enough on higher difficulties.Locking on to enemies is a great way to Focus fire and dispatch weaker ones, i found it more usefull to actually not lock on for bigger fights and use a combo of Hobby horse/Pepper grinder/Rabbit bomb ;D manual fight! dont be a scrub ;DNow those are some Good points, now lets talk about some downers.1. EA registration is involved i believe (i downloaded this game a long time ago but just got around to it, might have changed)2. 30 FPS, this is the Unreal engine on a PC, why in all that is Sane is it 30FPS? you can unlock it in your Alice Engine file to make it go 60 FPS (you should) then the game will feel like you are in a movie, its incredible. here is a guide 


YouTube™ Video: SidAlpha Reviews: Alice Madness Returns - The Birthday Review 

			Views: 316		

			A Promise made is fulfilled. In thanks to all of my Subscribers, and one in particular who is very fond of Bunnies, I Review Alice Madness Returns dressed as the White Rabbit from Alice in...		

 3. Limited Graphical option for being a Unreal Engine game, only AA, Gama, Bloom, and Physix. woop de doo...4. You ned to unlock the DLC, guide here--->http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1211330445. The game tends to Crash/stop and go, this could be with current Nvidia drivers, i have had this GTX660 when i downloaded Alice and played long ago and ran like Butter, but now its having some weird crashes, so im gonna guess its Current patches that botched it all up, not to much of a problem but really sucks to restart. (in short Performance may vary)6. Akward camera angles when exploring at times when developers change the camera angle on you.*This game is for everyone who likes fast action Platformers, a moderatly Good Combat System thats not to in depth but enough to have fun, and a Driving Story that actually makes you hunt down for the extra Items for more back ground story to connect and make sense of! Did i mention the Story is full of twist and turns? gruesome scenes? Funny commentary, disturbing spikes of Slaughter, demented children, Tim burton-esk Themes, Prostitution, Acts of violence upon kids?! yes and more! then this is for you!!Alice Madness returns 8/10    * a under dog Game with a Hype Story and game play!and once the Madness is over...well who is to say...that it is truley is over?   =3

number of helpful: 9 of 15 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												(I'd like to point out that this review was written before the whole "I recieved this game for free" checkmark box became a thing so I think it would be good to state before reading what I have to say about the game that I recieved it as a gift from a friend for free.)This game is awful. Let me start off by saying that I wanted to like it. I had wanted it for years and when I finally got it for a gift I was estatic because I've been wanting to play it for so long. The concept is beautiful, the horror atmosphere with the unique weapons and gothic take on Wonderland appealed to me more than anything. But then I played it on Nightmare mode.I assumed through my vast experience in playing insanely difficult games that I could handle Nightmare mode (and 13 hours in I'm still convinced that anything lower would have been too easy) right off the bat. In playing Nightmare mode, as unforgivable as I expected it to be, I slowly grew to despise this game and can safely say that I will never purchase or play another Spicy Horse game after this.Why is the game awful? Well, here's why:1) Clipping - Clipping is usually something that's never an issue in video games. Usually the developer understands that it's better to underclip and make a few objects that a part of the terrain mere textures so that the area is easier to move through for the player and removes the problem of the terrain being an issue during combat, puzzles, anything at all really. In Alice: Madness Returns the clipping seems uber random and is the one of the most annoying things about the game. Every single texture is a part of a clipped object. Literally all of them. I'm sure there may be a few of textures that aren't clipped, but from what I've seen, every single thing is clipped. So what? Well, now, in the middle of fights you'll get randomly stuck on gravestones or in the middle of a shinking puzzle you'll get caught on the edge of an invisable platform and oops, because of that error you're either dead or at the beginning of the puzzle again.2) Hitboxes and Colision - The hitboxes in this game are gigantic and the way hitboxes colide is infuriating. The hitbox for every attack is 100% garunteed to be larger than the animation for the attack, the hitbox of Alice is bigger than she is so the already large hitbox of the attack easily hits you unless you've made an awkwardly large amount of space between you and your oponent. The hitboxes of the enemies? Also overly sized. This means that while you're already getting caught on every single surface, you're also getting caught on every single stationary enemy. Lovely.3) Checkpoints - I want to punch whoever decided where to place the checkpoints in this game in the face. Let's look at an example: In Chapter 3 once you get into Wonderland, you're faced with a large enemy as a part of learning how to use a new weapon you just obtained. The enemy is uber strong and on Nightmare mode can kill you in a single hit (though Nightmare mode is the hardest difficulty, so I expected that to happen; I am in no way complaining about the damage the enemies deal). Once you beat that enemy? Checkpoint. Great! I won't have to redo that terrifying fight. Then I do a few parts of a jump puzzle, fight a pseudo-boss, do more jumping puzzles and - oops - ten minutes past that initial checkpoint I died. Ah, that's alright, there's no way I didn't run into another checkpoint, right? Right...? Wrong! Back to the beginning of the chapter you go! I shouldn't have to explain why that's annoying.4) Jumping Physics - I still don't even understand them. Ever since the first jumping puzzle I haven't been able to understand them. The "Float" mechanic that you're allowed to use after a jump that replaces an extra jump (you can jump three times mid air, which I found to be way more useful) is useless, Jumping mid-air does nothing after your first mid-air jump while the rest just... I don't even know, prolong the inevitable fall? On top of that, every time you land you slip all over the surface you just landed on which makes the jumping puzzles insanely annoying.5) Forced Fights - Forced fights in a game aren't bad. They make the player have to face the strong enemies and learn how to conquer them, and I like that. But when 99% of the combat in your game is forced, you're doing it wrong. When some of your fights are clones of previous fights in the game and they're still forced, you're doing it wrong. When your fights require memorisation in order to clear on the hardest difficuty, you are doing it wrong. Essentially the forced fights in every chapter work out like this: First, introducing a new enemy that's kinda difficult that you have to learn your way around. Not really that hard, usually beatable in the first try. Not a problem. Second, locking you in a room with that new enemy and a pseudo-boss. Kinda annoying, but the hierarchy of threat is pretty clear in this game, so not impossible. Towards the end of the chapter, locking you in a room with at least two pseudo-bosses and a rapid income of high strength grunts. This is annoying - no - infuriating, and in some cases impossible unless the perfect series of events occur.This game is not worth $20. This game is annoying, infuriating, and I would be upset had I spent real money on it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												[Full review of Alice: Madness Returns]Graphics:Not gonna lie, the graphics are not the strongest aspect of this game, so if that's your main focus then you may dissappointed. The graphics aren't necessarily bad though - just not the best. However, the art style is phenomenal. I mean I absolutely fell in love with the creepy environments and character designs. I even bought the art book for this game and have spent many hours going over the Timburton-esque style drawings. - 9/10Audio:Definitely the stongest aspect of the game for me. If you haven't listed to the soundtrack all the way, YOU NEED TO! Seriously, it's on Spotify, I listen to it al the time. It is unbelievably atmospheric, even just the title screen music is indescribably perfect for the tone of the game. - 10/10Gameplay:Okay, so this is where I stop praising the game. It's a bit of a button masher and one of those hack and slash types where the enemies NEVER stop coming even though you got bored of killing them like 5 hours ago. There are several different types of enemies (not too many or too few) that all have to be killed in specific ways. This would be fine if there were more varieties of weapons and/or upgrades for the weapons you already have. You basically end up using the same strategies throughout the entire game to defeat the same types of enemies and bosses are no exception. As for the platforming and puzzles; they're a'ight. - 6/10Story:I'm feeling pretty conflicted about the story because I liked certain aspects (like how dark and creepy both Alice's real life and Wonderland were) and I've always been a fan of the Alice in Wonderland story anyway. However, I was extremely confused about who the real villain was and what my ultimate purpose was throughout the entire game. Though you do find out who the real enemy was all along, I never felt like I fully understood the story even after I finished the game. However, I did enjoy the parts of the story that I understood. - 6/10Replayability:Unfortunately, I would have to say that Alice: Madness Returns has very little replayablility due to it's repetetive gameplay. Though the art style and soundtrack are nothing short of perfection, they can both be appreciated outside of the actual game. Combine the lackluster gameplay with the confusing story and I'm afraid there's not much incentive for a second playthough. Unless, of course, you enjoyed the combat mechanics. 4/10Overall:Though obviously not perfect, I do not regret my playthough of Alice: Madness Returns and would recommend it to any fan of the original game, American Mcgee's Alice. If you can get it on sale, it's a steal. - 7/10.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is by far one of the best games I have ever played. Alice is a strong female lead that although can do everything, she's still human. Struggling with her own mind you venture through her insanity and pick up the puzzle pieces together with her, figuring out what's really going on, what really happened. It felt refreshing and great to play as a young woman and I think many women will feel the same, she is fierce, witty and most of all, capable.Not only is her world and mind extremely beautiful, you will find many allies and really enjoy the combat. The world is so visually stunning and well thought trough. Her world is lurking with secrets and absurd creatures, and it is up to you to figure all this crazy mindboggling stuff out.If you're looking for a game were absurd and crazy comes into mind this is really the game for you. The combat is simple but yet very satisfying and easy to enjoy and learn. It is a casual game that's hard to not fall in love with. I enjoyed it a lot more than I thought I would.Would absolutely reccomend this game.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												This game has a decent story and amazing creative level designs, reminding me a lot of Psychonauts. (If you haven't played Psychonauts and you like this game, then you need to get on that.)Negatives would be the lack of options for camera controls (no invert horizontal camera), and the targeting system is very lame for how often you have to use it. Your target will basically lock on to whatever it wants and you cannot switch it directly, you have to turn it off and on (toggle or hold) until it catches onto the target you want, and often when surrounded by a ton of enemies, it's not going to typically lock on to the one you wanted. Then when you're locked on you cannot change the camera angle at all! This is fine when you just need to take out a bunch of mobs at ranged, but not when they get up close. This became extremely frustrating towards chapter 3. Melee/close range is flawed.Also the blocking ability does not have its own button when you play on a controller. you MUST be locked on to something to bring out your blocking umbrella. And if "locking on a target" is acting up, then good luck trying to block anything in time, as you must also be standing completely still to block. Your umbrella does make you basically invincible when you are able to bring it out in time. TIP: Also get that DLC early, you just need to lookup what line to change from False to True in some text file. Easy but dumb that you have to do that. The alternate dresses you can unlock are really overpowered so if you have trouble, just use one of those.There's some parts I wish weren't cinematics, they take it away from you and make you watch the little movie instead of letting you get to complete the bosses. That's kinda anti-climactic. The game definitely doesn't have enough real boss fights, just tons of "mini bosses" or over powered mobs who become redundant.Those are all my biggest complaints, these types of flaws wouldve been so easily fixed if they did slightly more testing or even a patch.Other than that, I definitely recommend the game if you're into surreal stories and you like platforms.

												[Full review of Alice: Madness Returns]Graphics:Not gonna lie, the graphics are not the strongest aspect of this game, so if that's your main focus then you may dissappointed. The graphics aren't necessarily bad though - just not the best. However, the art style is phenomenal. I mean I absolutely fell in love with the creepy environments and character designs. I even bought the art book for this game and have spent many hours going over the Timburton-esque style drawings. - 9/10Audio:Definitely the stongest aspect of the game for me. If you haven't listed to the soundtrack all the way, YOU NEED TO! Seriously, it's on Spotify, I listen to it al the time. It is unbelievably atmospheric, even just the title screen music is indescribably perfect for the tone of the game. - 10/10Gameplay:Okay, so this is where I stop praising the game. It's a bit of a button masher and one of those hack and slash types where the enemies NEVER stop coming even though you got bored of killing them like 5 hours ago. There are several different types of enemies (not too many or too few) that all have to be killed in specific ways. This would be fine if there were more varieties of weapons and/or upgrades for the weapons you already have. You basically end up using the same strategies throughout the entire game to defeat the same types of enemies and bosses are no exception. As for the platforming and puzzles; they're a'ight. - 6/10Story:I'm feeling pretty conflicted about the story because I liked certain aspects (like how dark and creepy both Alice's real life and Wonderland were) and I've always been a fan of the Alice in Wonderland story anyway. However, I was extremely confused about who the real villain was and what my ultimate purpose was throughout the entire game. Though you do find out who the real enemy was all along, I never felt like I fully understood the story even after I finished the game. However, I did enjoy the parts of the story that I understood. - 6/10Replayability:Unfortunately, I would have to say that Alice: Madness Returns has very little replayablility due to it's repetetive gameplay. Though the art style and soundtrack are nothing short of perfection, they can both be appreciated outside of the actual game. Combine the lackluster gameplay with the confusing story and I'm afraid there's not much incentive for a second playthough. Unless, of course, you enjoyed the combat mechanics. 4/10Overall:Though obviously not perfect, I do not regret my playthough of Alice: Madness Returns and would recommend it to any fan of the original game, American Mcgee's Alice. If you can get it on sale, it's a steal. - 7/10.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												Madness Returns is an acceptable sequel to the fantastic Alice which was released so many years ago.The dialogue in the game is as nonsensical as you'd expect it to be considering the source material and then putting this psychological twist to it where Wonderland is some how Alice's way of dealing with her problems.    It's a tad unfortunate that the game doesn't explore this more beyond just some short cut scenes and the even shorter collect-able "memories" that you can retrieve.  Levels are usually too long and a bit boring also so if you miss one of these collect-ables it's not exactly enticing to go back and get them.Speaking of the levels, at face value they seem pretty interesting.  The very beginning of the game has you start out in a lush green forest area with fungi and all sorts of vegetation.   This doesn't last long however as the game quickly gives you the impression that they got lazy.  This is because the level design is quite heavily invested in the platforming.  You'll come upon one area after another that's wide open and is littered with several tiny platforms that you must jump through.  None of it is very challenging and it just feels like it soaks up time.  There's not much to look at beyond the platforms either.  The sky boxes look nice, but that's almost all you'll be seeing for each area.  Unfortunately this is the bulk of the game and it doesn't take long for it to become dull as it feels like a chore.  Another thing that can make these areas last longer than they should is that there are often secret invisible platforms that often lead to the collect-ables.  These are found by pressing the LB button and making Alice shrink in size.  So frequently as you hop through areas you'll have to stop, shrink and visually scan your surroundings to make sure there's nothing you missed.  As stated before these collect-ables give you teeny tiny hints to the story.  So tiny in fact that most of them only last about 3-5 seconds.  It's not very rewarding and there's at least a hundred of them.I should also mention that there are small mini-game type sections within stages as well.  These are also quite boring and some of them seem slapped together at the last moment.  For example in one section the game changes up into a shoot 'em up style game where you control an under water ship shooting at skeleton fish.  It's not challenging, it's slow, there's no boss, and no power ups.  You just tap the fire button and wait till it's over.  Other mini-games include slide puzzles.  None of these mini-games add anything to the experience.  They just slow down the game.The combat in the game is very Zelda-like, as in you target an enemy, wait for an opening and attack and some enemies have a weakness to a certain weapon.  It's alright for what it is.  However many times when there are several enemies to fight picking the one you want can be a hassle and sometimes the camera doesn't give you the best angle.  The weapons are cool though and very fitting for the theme of the game.  Alice has the Vorpal Blade, which looks mostly like a giant kitchen knife, a Pepper Grinder which operates like a machine gun, a Hobby Horse that acts like a giant sledge hammer and a Tea Pot that lobs drops of tea like grenades.All in all this is an okay game, but the level design is absolutely atrocious.  At $20 it's a little pricey, I'd pick it up for around $10.6.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												This game has a decent story and amazing creative level designs, reminding me a lot of Psychonauts. (If you haven't played Psychonauts and you like this game, then you need to get on that.)Negatives would be the lack of options for camera controls (no invert horizontal camera), and the targeting system is very lame for how often you have to use it. Your target will basically lock on to whatever it wants and you cannot switch it directly, you have to turn it off and on (toggle or hold) until it catches onto the target you want, and often when surrounded by a ton of enemies, it's not going to typically lock on to the one you wanted. Then when you're locked on you cannot change the camera angle at all! This is fine when you just need to take out a bunch of mobs at ranged, but not when they get up close. This became extremely frustrating towards chapter 3. Melee/close range is flawed.Also the blocking ability does not have its own button when you play on a controller. you MUST be locked on to something to bring out your blocking umbrella. And if "locking on a target" is acting up, then good luck trying to block anything in time, as you must also be standing completely still to block. Your umbrella does make you basically invincible when you are able to bring it out in time. TIP: Also get that DLC early, you just need to lookup what line to change from False to True in some text file. Easy but dumb that you have to do that. The alternate dresses you can unlock are really overpowered so if you have trouble, just use one of those.There's some parts I wish weren't cinematics, they take it away from you and make you watch the little movie instead of letting you get to complete the bosses. That's kinda anti-climactic. The game definitely doesn't have enough real boss fights, just tons of "mini bosses" or over powered mobs who become redundant.Those are all my biggest complaints, these types of flaws wouldve been so easily fixed if they did slightly more testing or even a patch.Other than that, I definitely recommend the game if you're into surreal stories and you like platforms.

content:
Posted: January 16
Product received for free
												Alice: Madness Returns is an adventure game that features the characters and settings that are all derived from the classic Alice in Wonderland. Our character suffers from the trauma of losing her parents, and is seeking therapy from a psychiatrist, Angus Bumby. Without stating or implying any spoilers here, it is clear that the methods Mr. Bumby is using are not effective. Alice is still at a constant struggle to recover her own sanity. That is the basis of the plot. Bland and not too hard to find in the Horror genre of games from my experience, but with its own story that is different from the old novel. So there is some credit there for its originality.The gameplay is where the fun comes in. Yes, you will meet those inevitable moments of trying to stay in the air, on the edge of a platform or having ½ life point left while facing a strong monster (i.e Colossal Ruin). The monsters have their own individual weaknesses and strengths that we must consider to strategize/defeat them – examples being the red gem of the Eyepot that we must target when in combat with them, and to aim for the mask of any ‘Ruin’ type creatures. With each chapter you complete, you're introduced to new enemies, puzzles and new challenges along with the old ones. I remember always being thrilled to see what’s new in store, when we, as Alice, enter a new world and after completing the former chapter. It’s as though we are given small rewards for our progress which is an effective way to grasp and keep the player invested. Alice even has her clothes changed when she starts a new chapter!That being said, you can tell that the artists have placed in a lot, if not the most, effort into the game’s aesthetic appeal. The original characters from Alice in Wonderland have been re-designed, and Alice’s Wonderland never fails to baffle me with its stunning themes – from Oriental Grove (aka Mysterious East), to the deluded depths, the artists has touched on nearly every unique part of culture of our real world and has it implemented. There is also the wide variety of music, from calm and settling, to loud and eerie depending on our environment and how close we are to specific characters or monsters. One funny feature that I always find amusing is the snorting sounds that would alarm if a pig nose is nearby.The voice acting was also well made, and suited to the culture where the story takes place. Their accents and old-style English indicates that this is taking place in Britain. The major downside to this game however, is the repetitive nature of the game. There’s the likelihood that you will meet more former enemies then you will to meeting new ones, and having to repeat many of the same notions like invisible pathways to reach to an end.To sum everything that's said: the cons were the dull story that all wrapped up into a … slightly disappointing ending, and the repetitive nature of challenges. The pros however, were the stunning atmosphere (both Wonderland and the real world) the characters and its audio + music. I recommend buying this game, and give it a 2 thumbs up!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												The biggest asset of this game is its visual style; it is breathtakingly gorgeous to look at. The environments are truly stunning, lending real depth to the tortured imaginings of a fragmented Wonderland. The story line is dark, engaging and entirely adult despite the youthful protagonist and fantastical thematics. It's twisted and downright brutal in places, and I particularly enjoyed the gothic stylings of the game. However, having just completed this game, I'm actually quite disappointed, and it's hard to explain why. I should have really enjoyed this game as it's something that's normally right up my alley - beautiful graphics, interesting story, developed characters and relatively easy-to-learn gameplay that's just the right mix of gaming, cut scenes, puzzles and combat. The major problem for me is that Alice: Madness Returns is actually much more fun to look at than it is to play. I could spend hours looking at the pretty graphics and backdrops but actually negotiating the levels got downright repetitive - if you like jumping from platform to platform then this is the game for you, because that's about 90% of the gameplay. It's fun at first with the triple-jump and float functions, rendered as they are with butterflies and graceful effects, but after a while you do get bored of doing the same thing over and over for five long chapters where the only thing that really changes is the scenery, and Alice's dress. The combat style is pretty simple to learn but can be difficult to master - the odd target lock function leads to weird camera angles and can frustrate you when there are mutliple targets. Most battles end up being fairly frantic but the game does force you to think tactically when facing multiple foes, as you will need to employ different weapons to defeat certain enemies. To its credit, it's not the straightforward hack n' slash that I'd first anticipated. The enemies have a good range of abilities and tactics to counter, though it would be nice if there was a bit more variety in appearance - okay, doll's heads are creepy, but after a while you do become immune to the terror-inducing effects of black goo with an empty-eyed doll's head for a face. Adding more doll's heads does not make it creepier. Just harder to kill...The game does suffer from a number of well-documented bugs, just check out the community hub, which solved 99% of the problems for me. These did not make the game unplayable but did detract a lot from the enjoyment and flow of the gameplay, particularly an inability to access one of the weapons for nearly all of the first chapter in my case without having to exit the game and/or reload from my last save point. Another thing that I found incredibly irritating was the minigames - for some of them the switches in artwork/style/gameplay seemed a refreshing change at first, but then you realise it's just more jumping from platform to platform, just in a two-dimensional or other such different setting. On some of them the camera angles are so odd you end up having to work towards the camera with no clue as to where you're going or what you're supposed to be doing. "Maybe that's the challenge!" you may cry - true enough, but it's pretty annoying when you can't see where you're going and you end up dying a dozen times before you work out where the next platform is in relation to where you are. Some of the smaller puzzles, which involve chess pieces, or playing a tune, can be skipped entirely without affecting the game play, so there seems little point in them at all. Hidden objects are strewn throughout the game, but there's no real impetus to find them all unless you happen to be really into your extra features/concept art/character profiles. Perhaps if the game supported Steam Achievements or some other such reward it might have been worth spending more time searching out these items, but after a while you will probably decide it's all more effort than it's worth - after all, it's not like you're short of platforms to be jumping to and from in the main storyline. I do recommend this game, though, simply for being a visual spectacle and an interesting, dark, really screwed up story line. Definitely one to purchase during a sale at a heavily discounted price, as I did - I think I'd be much more disappointed if I'd paid full price, especially given the minor bugs, the repetitive gameplay and the many small irritants that made this game a lot less enjoyable than I'd expected it to be.  Oh, and at the risk of a spoiler, don't expect any "big boss fights" until the only one that comes at the very end of the game. It teases you by making you think there will be some, but each chapter usually just ends with a cut scene that doesn't explain anything and tells you to go talk to someone else instead. Now go jump across some platforms to get there...

content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												This game is truly a work of art. The visuals are incredible, both the design and graphics absolutely excel to give you an experience that is visually fantastic, and this factor makes this game nearly worth it alone. Not only is the game itself gorgeous, but the cutscenes are done in a paper-doll style, which really gives them flair and makes them a marvel to watch. It also sports a sublime soundtrack, although the tracks are a little on the short side, and a brilliant plot. Taking up from the first Alice game, but giving enough information that a new player can hop onboard no problem, this is an excellent and highly original take on the concept of a "darker" Alice in Wonderland.  I will not spoil, but it is very interesting, and the conclusion is very satisfying. This game also features excellent voice work, with most actors reprising their roles from the first game. The gameplay itself is a mixture of hack-and-slashy combat, platforming, and puzzle solving, with several unique and intriguing mechanics, as well as several segments that introduce a completely different set of mechanics for a short while, offering an interesting change from the regular gameplay. However, although I would absolutely recommend this game, there are a few issues: The controls on PC are less than stellar, as this is a console port. The game likes to tease you by constantly letting you think there will be a bossfight and then not giving you one; this persists throuought the entire game, and apart from some regular enemies that are slightly harder to beat, there is not a SINGLE proper boss fight in this game until the end. Finally, I found it quite irritating not being able to summon the Cheshire Cat at any time as could be done in the first game. This may not matter to some, but to me, it's quite a disappointment, albeit a minor one. But to summarize, this is an excellent game that is well worth your time and money with fun gameplay, great visual design, and a compelling story.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2016
												This is a very average platformer, it had potential to something much more though. The game lacks variety in the gameplay which would have been fine if the platforming and combat wasn’t so basic. You are mostly double jumping and gliding between big gaps landing on big square or circle platforms floating above a giant pit. Great platformers like Jak and Daxter keep the platforming fresh each level by changing how you traverse the level with it’s unique level design which is something this game lacks. You do the same thing from start to finish it never changes things up and there is a lack of challenge because of how basic and easy the platforming is which makes the game less engaging. The game ends up being a bit of a bore the more you play it because of how repetitive the experience ends up being, especially because it’s surprisingly a really long game. Combat is ok, there is nothing to really praise about it though. The story works just fine but I wasn’t too invested in it, I did like the ending though. The game has some unique design and aesthetics. Even though the level design is kind of being held back by the basic platforming, it does throw out cool environments and details in the levels.  I know a lot of people really like this game but from my experience, I just didn’t have fun with it. 5/10 (Average)

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												EH.... I love Wonderland. I love the source materials and I like the direction this game went but it feels like it did not quite make it. There are numerous points where I notice what looks like corners being cut to keep this game in budget which is an understandable concern but not something that should be so easily notable by the player. A particular disappointment is looking into the characters section at the main menu and seeing a LOT of them that were never seen in game.Alice also feels exceedingly dim in this game. Not because she's necessarily unintelligent but rather because the game in a not-at-all-subtle manner let's you know the plot 'twist' concerning who is responsible long (reeeeaaaalllly long) before Alice herself figures it out.At times the story moves jerkily like a puppet dangling from strings. It's a beautiful puppet but it doesn't have much life despite how unique many of the character designs are.About half-way through I realized I wasn't having much fun anymore but forced myself to plow through to completion for principle and not to see the end. Speaking of which, if you don't know already the end boss (which is also the ONLY boss) is actually pretty spectacular in itself but the story is handled like someone trying to complete three separate jigsaws at once which ruined any emotional impact it could have for me.Do I recommend it? Not really. That said, as a fan of Alice in general I would have been disappointed had I not followed through and I have no regrets.

												The game for money well spent. Something between art and game which makes it quite an unique piece of entertainment. Wonderland is on the edge of crisis and corruption once again which is reflected on the more and more desolated level environments. Lead Alice through 6 various chapters with each having it's unique design and followed by little backstories leading Alice to discover the Real truth.Arcade combo action combat system when you have to time your strikes to make precise blows through enemy lines or just turn on Hysteria mode to destroy everything standing in your way. Upgrading weapons, lots of various collectibles which you have to find by using all the game mechanics altogether. All of these things make this the game what I really like and enjoyed so much.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												Would I recommend this game? Yes! 8/10Alice: Madness Returns somehow manages to have colorful lands that are still dark, grey and a bit disturbing. The gameplay is a bit hack-and-slash, some shooter, and platforming. The voice acting is great; I love Alice's voice and the Queen of Heart's as well, and I love the Cheshire Cat's the most...so dark and yet a bit soothing.Alice has a tendancy to be a bit snarky and doesn't respond so dramatically as many female game characters out there, which can be a good and a bad thing at times, but overall she is a well made character who comes across as rather lethal. Depending on te stage of the game her outfit will change which is a nice touch, and her animations are great; attacks fall one after the other without any clipping and move beautifully, dodging is quick and comes with a cool butterfly effect, and jumping and floating seems a bit elegant.Cutscenes are interesting because they are done in a pen-and-ink 2d style that gives the game a book-like feel as it tells you a story about her insanity. They often give insite to her mental state and her past.Most gameplay takes place in wonderland, but starts off in reality. The scenary changes with each location (and as mentioned before, so does her atire). In reality, the scenery is dark, dank and dreary, and the people of the towns don't exactly qualify for any beauty pagents. Despite their uglieness, their appearance adds to the atmosphere. When you first get to Wonderland though everything becomes colorful and vibrant...then slowly changes to dark, then darker, then even darker yet. Water turns to blood, vibrant green grass turns dead and ugly. Even in areas like the frozen landscapes has its own disturbing atmosphere with frozen animals that have exposed inards. Pleasant, right?Each area of the game acts a platforming area where you have to run and jump from place to place, pull levers and turning things on and off. As you move around the game you are attacked by monsters and things, and these opponents can get monotonous as you are often attacked by the same things over and over at points. The enemies do differ frm level to level but there comes a point where you'd rather kill something else.This game is well done, fun and disturbing. Some of the dialog is a little hard to follow, but its clever and dark and often strange, but remember she is insane and this is Alice in Wonderland (and we're not talking Disney). And as I've said, the voice acting is great so dialogs are enjoyable.Alice: Madness Returns is well worht the money.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Madness Returns is one of the best games I have played in a long time.  I do have a thing for Lewis Carrol's creation and by extension, American McGee's creations in Alice and Madness Returns.  The original Alice was okay, but Madness Returns simply takes off as far as sound design, graphic detail/design, and control.  It plays almost like a God of War game in terms of combat.  You have light, heavy, and ranged attacks.  The combat is fun and can be challenging.  It is a beautifully grotesque world created in the mind of a mad girl (alice) and the "real" world is something straight out of Sweeney Todd.  There are light puzzling elements and a wonderful twisted wonderland to explore.My only regret is that I didn't buy this game sooner.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Pros:Incredible art direction/aestheticsImersive enviromentFluid combatMemorable charactersRefreshing gameplay mechanicsCons:BuggyRepetetive combat/gameplayConfusing/bad keymappingOddly unresponsive menus and at times in game inputExtremely on rails/linear gameThe game itself is a ton of fun to play ignoring a few cons that should have been fixed during development (bugs/ wonky aiming and lagging menus). At its core it's a hack and slash action platformer. In fact, most of the game is either slashing away at enemies, or jumping from platform to platform. This may get repetetive to some, but that's what the game is. And it's a damn fine looking platformer at that. The aesthetics of the game are fantastic, from boring dreary London (?) to the vibrant and morbidly twisted wonderland. Voice acting is also spot on.Overall, if you can overlook a few bugs that will require a quick restart from checkpoint, and don't mind gameplay getting repetetive after a while playing, Alice: Madness Returns is a really fun game to anyone looking for a arcadey hack'n'slash platformer. Psychonauts comes to mind when playing this so if you enjoyed that game at all, this one is very much worthing looking in to.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Visually beautiful and disturbing at the same time, I really enjoyed the gameplay. It's more casual than Bayonetta (no crazy combo chaining), though the visual styles are somewhat reminiscent (butterfly and feather motifs). It's as fast paced as you want it to be; you have the choice of finding all the hidden paths and items, but you can just as easily skip over them in favour of just sticking with the main story. The music is low-key and nonintrusive, but lends itself to the general mood and theme very well.I love this reinvention of Alice. I only wish its prequel was available on Steam.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Alice: Madness Returns is a game like none other I have ever played. If you are a fan of Wonderland, then you will love the creepy, strange beauty of this game. Each chapter is rich with artistic detail that looks as if it has been pulled straight out of a Tim Burton movie. Every chapter has a unique look that will make you well acquainted with your screenshot key.While the art style is clever and interesting, the level lengths are quite long and can be a little tedious after a while. Don’t go into this game expecting a fast play through, especially if you plan on collecting everything. The boss fights, are thankfully, unique to this game. They are challenging and had me at times wondering if I was actually playing a mini Dark Souls game instead. The clumsy controls make for an aggravating experience when facing enemies in flight, and don’t even get me started on that umbrella.  Besides the games shortcomings, including a few bugs and glitches here and there, the game really does make you feel as if you were traversing through a strange, yet wonderful Wonderland. There are several challenging puzzle games spread out through the chapters that I felt were a nice break from the constant platform jumping, and the characters you meet along the way are interesting and unique.My overall score for the game: 7/10. I would recommend this game for those who like challenging puzzles or those who just want to experience a darker version of Alice in Wonderland.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Alice: the Madness ReturnsBackground: Big fan of American Mcgee's Alice and Alice in Wonderland in general. Been excited to play this game for some time now.Impressions: When you are dealing with a place called Wonderland you really need to give people a sense of wonder. A:TMR does some really interesting stuff with Lewis Carroll's base material and adds it's own twists that compliments the imagery established in the first game. In short it's dark, twisted and does everything right that Tim Burton's film got wrong.The Good:* The grim 'reality' of Victorian England is grotesquely exaggerated.* Glorious and twisted Wonderland is the perfect counterpoint.* Some absolutely gorgeous visuals, outfits and backdrops.* Thoughtful plot with cues and callbacks if you pay attention.* Honours the design, voices and locations of the original.* Weapons have impact and look great.* Voice acting is decent throughout, huge improvement over original.* 24 hours plus game play.* Shrink/Hint mechanic is fun and helpful.* Very linear but lots of content keeps you wanting to progress.The Bad:* Lots of jumping puzzles, but few are particularly hard.* Enemy lock-on makes encounters feel samey.* Killing enemies is repetitive, use the same tactics over and over.* Limited range of weapons and upgrades could have been more visual.* Dark themes, visuals and language are not for everyone.* Shrink mechanic could have been more diversely used. * Hint mechanic can be too helpful.* Hidden items rarely challenging to obtain.* Retry system sometimes takes you back further than at other times.* Side scrolling sections are unchallenging.* Feels slightly 'console port' like but not overly so, plays well with keyboardRecommended for: Fans of the first game. Those who like twisted and dark fairy-tales. The 15 age rating seems about right.Conclusion.8/10. Great fun to play and explore with some interesting encounters for those that like their fairytales with a hint of gothic about them.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												A classic story such as Alice in Wonderland is a bold platform(er) to stand on; bolder still to instill such a dark flavored atmosphere.  “Why?” you ask?  Because for many of us, our most recent memory of the character Alice is bleached Disney.  For me, there was a G rated nostalgia barrier I needed to break through to fully immerse myself in the experience.  Embracing the dark connotations that Alice: Madness Returns has to offer was effectively my rabbit hole.The environments and overall feel for the gameplay pay a solid tribute to that N64 era of three dimensional platformers.  From hidden collectables to Alice’s environmentally adaptive dresses, the developer’s attention to detail is apparent throughout. Further supplemented with artistic story-book-style cutscenes and well executed phasing to/from Alice’s mundane real world existence.  I found myself stopping to paint the rosses and taking an excess of screenshots.I highly recommend this title to all platformer loving gamers.  9/10.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
Product received for free
												FULL WRITTEN REVIEW:Aww Alice Madness Returns. Ive never got obsesses with a game this much since half life 2. I knew this game before but never really got to play it because i never had the chance to untill a couple of months ago and i dont regret playing it and ill explain why. The idea is just fantastic. A game based on Lewis Carroll's famous novel Alice Advetures in Wonderland (aka Alice in Wonderland) but with bloody, dark, twisted theme and story is just a very original, genious, fantastic,cool, awesome.......gosh im lost for words.====STORY (SLIGHT SPOILERS FROM THE FIRST GAME)====So, the story in my oppinion is very original and unique. Alice Madness Returns is a sequel to the 2000 game American McGee's Alice released only on pc at the time with a ps2 version that was in development but got cancelled. In the first game, Alice, after feeling guilty for her parents and sister's deaths, goes insane. Her madness made wonderland as twisted as it is. At the end of the game she leaves the asylum thinking that she is finally cured from her madness. In this game, Alice's madness and bad memories about her parents and sister's deaths return, hence the name Madness Returns. The game sets in a victorian age London with a Tim Burton-like artstyle (if i do say so myself) which makes for a really beautiful looking game. Alice, now 19 years old (if im correct), lives in an orphanage where she takes medication for her madness. After her therapy session with her doctor, doctor Bumby, Alice is told by Bumby to get some pills from the High street chemist. Alice leaves the orphanage to get the pills and stumbles upon a white cat. She then procceds to follow the cat into a dark alley where she begins to hallucinate people with insect-like heads (i believe its the jabberwock's head). After her hallucination, an old woman by the name of Nurse Witless (a nurse from the asylum Alice was in) touches Alice's shoulder and she then tells Alice to come with her. After that, Alice starts talking with nurse Witless asking her if she was going to return her to the asylum where she was internee in the first game. Alice then has an hallucination of nurse Witless as a monster and Alice retreats slowly in fear. Then the floor beneath her breaks and she falls into Wonderland. After falling through the floor, Alice finds herself in Wonderland where the Cheshire Cat appears in front of her to inform Alice of a new evil that reigns and is destroying Wonderland. The Cheshire Cat points out that the evil isnt from her head, it is something from outside. Now throughout the game Alice needs to figure out where is this evil coming from. An important fact that is mentioned in the game is "the destruction of Wonderland means the destruction of Alice" (youll know why later on), thus begining a new adventure for Alice.====GAMEPLAY AND PROS====Lets begin with this game's beautiful graphics, combat, enemies, visuals, soundtrack, etc. The level design is so beautiful, the levels are very detailed and colorful at times. The music fits so well with the environment that youll get the chills like i did. The platforming is fun and enjoyable and neither very hard or very easy. The voice acting, holy cow, it s just fantastic. The character animations are really well made including the lip sync. The different dresses you can unlock are really cool and good looking. The combat is really fun and unique. You have a total of 6 weapons. The vorpal blade is your main melee weapon, the pepper grinder is like a gatling gun that shoots pepper projectiles, the teapon cannon (it has a really big downside but ill talk about that in the cons) is a short ranged teapon that shoots powerful hot tea projectiles, the hobby horse acts as a very powerful sledgehammer-like weapon, the clockwork bomb is a doll bunny that explodes and acts as a disctraction for enemies and finally, the umbrella acts like a shield for low powered attacks. The enemies resemble toys or characters from the novel and get harder the more you progress. The visuals are not the most realistic but they look really beautiful. This is one underrated game that should be played by anyone who loves a good and complicated story like i do. The game might not be a legendary 10/10 but it is a good story driven platformer and it delivers its story bits in a really interesting way. So, throughout your journey you can find items such as bottles and memories. The bottles being collectibles needed to unlock concept art and character bios. Memories being items with the shape of different items that represent Alice's past and belongings such as toys, syringes, houses, etc, that can be found in secret places. When collecting one of these memories, you can listen pieces of dialog from Alice's past and memories. Collecting these memories is a very good representation that throughout Alice's journey she is trying to uncover and remember her past and experiences about the incident of her familiy's deaths. Also, throughout the game you can find these pig snouts which you can shoot with your pepper grinder making them sneeze and revealing secret rooms with collectibles in them.====CONS====Now lets talk about an important thing that is, of course, the game's cons. First of all and most important, why and the hell is a triple A pc game capped at 30 fps? that is so pointless since the game runs very smoothly even on lower end hardware. Another annoying thing is the fact that EA involved Origin on a steam game which if you ask me it is totaly pointless. In many instances the textures can look so low res that you wonder if the game is just loading the textures or just buged. The graphics menu is lacking a lot of stuff such as anisotropic filtering, different types of alti aliasing (the anti aliasing is just "on and "off" without giving the information of what type of anti aliasing is the game using), vsync, ambient occlusion, texture detail, etc. The game can get a bit repetitive at times but you dont really notice it because you focus more on the story. The game's Nvidia Physx option isnt well optimized like many games with Nvidia Physx have suffered. What i hate is that the combat isnt balanced. I mean, once you aquire the teapot cannon and fully upgrade it the game gets impressively easy and once you beat the game you can use the different dresses that give you buffs and when you figure out how to unlock the DLC dresses in the .ini files you are practically unkillable even at the highest difficulty. Im not saying that the combat is bad, it is really good compared to other button masher games, the fact that you can easily die if you just rely on only one weapon is a nice touch (unless you have the horribly unbalanced teapot cannon fully upgraded or if you just wear the most overpowered dress in the game, Late but Lucky) , its just that it could have gone better. ====CONCLUSION====Even after all the cons i pointed out, this game is still a very good game because it focuses more on an engaging story and that is a big part of this game. This is one hidden gem that should be recognized as a good game by many more people and we will probably never see a third game and it makes me sad because this franchise has the pontential to be a succesful and well-known triple A experience. After writing this review and playing through this game i can officially and proudly say that Alice Madness Returns is now one of my favourite games of all time and it is totally a 20 dollar worthy experience. Alice Madness Returns gets an 8/10. It is a good game but ill be honest, the combat can get really repetitive that it almost earns a 7 but i feel like thats way to low. It honestly didnt bother me because i was more engaged in the story and i love games with complicated stories and oh boy this is one of them.If you really took the time to read this entire review thank you very much, i appreciate it alot and i hope i encouraged you to give this game a try

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												This game is horrendous. Incredibly buggy, poor platforming design, the jumping must be so precise that it makes this game twice as long as it needs to be. You will die a TON if you are even slightly off with your timing. Tedious, my god is it tedious. This game is a chore, I'm so far into it at this point I'd like to just finish it, but every step of the way is incredibly painful and time consuming. I've played almost 16 hours and I'm only halfway through. Pros:The game is very aesthetically pleasing and colorful. I've always really liked American McGee's take on the Alice in Wonderland tale.The invisible platforms are a pretty neat idea. Cons:BugCertain platforming areas I've likely spent half an hour on just to get across to the other side. In the section where you must free the souls in the Lost Souls Locker, some of the platforms will glitch out and get stuck at the bottom if you've failed and died too many times. Of course you don't want to redo the entire section so you must let yourself die some more until the platforms actually start working again. BugThe side scroller mini games are also terribly buggy. I use shrink to dodge some fire cannons and of course it gets stuck in shrink mode, meaning I cannot jump and therefore must start the entire mini game over again.BugYou must change your key bindings in the config file as well as going back and changing them in game. It doesn't recognize your changes if you only do it in game.BugThe cube puzzles only let me move one piece up or down. I cannot select any other piece surrounding the piece I just moved therefore making the puzzle impossible to complete. Poor Game DesignOh, you've just completed a really difficult part and then died soon after? Welp ♥♥♥♥ you because this game only auto saves (that's the best feature of the game btw). You must complete the entire section over again ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)Poor Game DesignWhatever health you have is all the health you get when you are going into a boss battle. I was not warned that I would soon be fighting a Colossal Ruin so I didn't know that I needed to heal myself. I had 3 health going into battle and needless to say, died many times. Even when I died and restarted the battle it still did not give me any more health than what I had going in. Design flaw.Poor Game DesignA very minor gripe I have is that when upgrading weapons it doesn't tell you exactly what is being upgraded. The weapon looks different but you aren't exactly sure if it does more damage, has a shorter cool down time, faster firing speed, etc. You just have to hope that it would upgrade all of those things ¯\_(ツ)_/¯If you're looking for a scary, thrilling game, this is not it. The enemies are more obnoxious and monotonous than scary.I really wanted to enjoy this game, but it's horribly disappointing.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												The only reason I finished this madly bad game are its visual designs, which are in most cases beautifuly done, sometimes even breathtaking. However everything else is utterly shameful. Enemies are not there to present a demanding challenge as they are a horribly boring obstacle on your way to encounter just another senseless fight. And its mostly fighting the basic enemy in different versions (Ruins), annoying you the whole game instead of giving space for other enemies (Card guards were the most enjoyable ones). Puzzles are so stupid, you'll bash your head against the head hoping for more mental activity. You can fail only because of poor controls. Oh, the minigames... an atrocious attempt to make the game richer making it only even more dumb and empty. The story, dialogs, cutscenes, all of this is a bunch of plain and childish writing culminating in a "finale" of zero thrill, zero emotion, I could not care less. I was happy that this game and its frustrating save system ends. Alice: Madness Returns is a resentful sequel to American McGee's Alice and I deeply hate it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2013
												Alice Madness Returns can be very fun, and for the most part it is - but it can also be tedious. It has never been patched (thanks, EA) and suffers some bugs and glitches and performance issues (plus its an obvious console ports with the usual problems).It plays well enough however (better with controller), platforming is a lot of fun, combat is alright, like a watered-down spectacle fighter, story is just a creepy/crazy/mad as you'd expect... its a good sequel to the first Alice game, I would just hope it was more polish. And a bit more trimmed - some levels are just too long and some parts are superflouos. Thankfully you can skip some of the (many) minigames included.Either way, its a fun game. Unfortunately it is very expensive in Europe still.

number of helpful: 31 of 60 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
Promising game fails to deliver to the fullNote: after replaying parts of it, I've rewritten some parts, being more "mild" ;-)This is - once more - one of those occasions I wished the Steam-review system had a third, more neutral, option. I've been tossed between thumbs up and down all the the time - some it really should be "neutral". Alice: Madness Returns is by no means a bad game. It's a sequel to the earlier American McGee's Alice, a game I loved at first sight when I played it. Compared to the original, this second installment in the series is darker, grimmer, more mature, focusing more on the evil going on in Wonderland and on the catastrophy that happened early in Alice's childhood.The first couple of hours into the game are stunning, and I felt like being on for a rare gaming treat. The way in which 19th-century London where Alice lives in an orphanage is depicted, is visual genius. Every detail counts and adds to an unforgettable atmosphere. I felt like walking round in one of my beloved novels by Charles Dickens. These "London" scenes do re-appear in the course of the game, but all too far and few between, and much shorter than the opening scene. Controls and actual gameplay felt very intuitive, and made me reach for my gamepad. This is after all a genuine third person Action Adventure (or Platformer quite often), and I prefer my Xbox 360 gamepad for this genre.After marvelling at the way London was depicted, I all of a sudden fell into Wonderland, and the visual contrast with the grim and grey London atmosphere was huge. Wonderland feels at first like, well, a real wonder: brimming with colours, flowers, trees and unusual animals, most of them well-known to anyone who has read the book. The game does well in gradually introducing new weapons and abilities to Alice, and during the next couple of hours into Wonderland, fighting off my first enemies and meeting my friends of old, I still felt very much at ease with this game. But, when the first chapter in Wonderland (the Mad Hatters Domain) continued on and on and on, with jumping puzzles following each other in a very similar fashion, and ever more difficult fights with over-powererd enemies following suit, a feeling of unease raised its head. Surely the next chapters would be better, with more variety, better difficulty balance, more original puzzles? Alas, they were far from it. The second and third chapter felt like under-developed, since the visual quality dropped all of a sudden - it felt like etiher an altogether different team developed these graphics (and ininspiring level-design), or out of lack of time the middle levels of the game got less attention than the outer ones.Anyway, I really, really had to convince myself to keep going, stumbling through chapters 2 and 3, only to finally reach the much better two final chapters. Graphics and level-design are much better there, but in a weird way the difficulty issue came back, only reversed. After having upgraded most of my weaponry to full power, I smashed through the different enemies all too easily now. It's a real pity the developers could not get the difficulty curve for the entire game right.The sheer outburst of creative imagination however the developers let flow in the last quarter or so of the game, is stunning: it made me even feel worried, at unease, looking behind my shoulder now and then. I got a few stomps in my stomach as well, especially when the subject of the Asylum where Alice spent most of her ill-fated yout, is touched upon again.In the end, Alice: Madness Returned felt like a partly missed opportunity of ideas that could have written game-history. If only the level of imagination and wonder of the first hours could have been maintained throughout the entire game, it would have been a classic. It should have been much shorter too: at half the length, the less inspired levels wouldn't have made that devastating an impression. Now it feels like over-extending a not very substantial story.Gameplay: 18/30 (most of the fighting is ok, albeit too repetitive, some of the jumping action is quirky)Graphics: 13/20 (the first and last quarter would have gotten 18 out of 20...)Sound: 9/10 (the soundtrack is wonderful)Technical & stability: 6/10 (even after setting the nVidia-based physics to low on my AMD-system, I got too many stuttering)Replayability: 6/10 (single-player only, but it's a very long game clocking at appx 20 hours, and that's without looking for all the collectibles)Steam integration: 3/10 (nothing extra here, which is a pity)Personal appreciation: 7/10 (out of love for the scenes in London)Overall: 62/100Buy and play at your own risk, having enough time and perseverance to continue through the awful middle section.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												I've only played one chapter of the game, but i love it so far. The animation is absolutely beautiful, the music is splendid, the mood and atmosphere is creepy and chilling etc, the enemies are terrifying, and aesthetically it is absolutely great. I could foresee the fighting becoming menotomous, but so far it's extremely enjoyable and runs pretty smoothly. A lot of people complain about the controls without a controller (which worried me greatly,) but with my Anker gaming mouse, i can just set the dpi way down and it works great. I'd also reccomend (if you go the mouse option, which would require a gaming mouse, not just any off-the-shelf wireless deal) setting some of the utilities to programmable mouse buttons (instead of [Caps Lock] i've set the lock-on to one of my thumb buttons, along with the shrink and dodge. i'd recommend this game if you're looking for a pretty standard platform/hack-n-slash game with a good story and creepy feel. just a protip: when you use the mushroom-trampolines to jump, dont hit [spacebar] until you've reached the max hight of your bounce, otherwise you will waste the jump and wont be able to double-jump as effectively.tl:dr- beautiful game, pretty standard gameplay, mouse and keyboard works if you have a programmable mouse (low DPI), and i reccomend this game

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												I love this game. the graphics for it are nice and each level is very different. Goes from a forest setting to under the sea. The gameplay can be a little rough here and there due to the camera but quickly you get better at it during fights. The story was a bit confusing at first but comes together nicely at the end. The story makes you think one thing and quickly switches your mind to think another which makes guessing the plot a lot harder. Alice madness returns gets creepier as you play along making more exciting. There are some parts here and there that make you wish they would just move on or wish you could skip but almost every game has parts like this. I suggest playing it when you get a chance especially if you love puzzle games, then this game is really for you. The puzzles get from easy to difficult as you progress through the game. I had a few moments that i had to stop and think about what i was missing to move on which no gamer wants an easy game to play through. Finally, I loved the length of the game its over 14hrs ish of gameplay which is nice and unlike some games a second play through isnt that bad. You discover some paths you missed and fight new monsters. I only wish Steam got American Mcgee's Alice, the first game before this, so i could understand the story a bit better. Overall I would give this game an 8/10 and suggest people to play it when they get a chance.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2016
												Twisted and inventive, American McGee continues his fantastic work on the sequel to cult classic American McGee's Alice. McGee took Alice-in-Wonderland in a vagarious direction sporting a dark tale of torment and psychological abuse, whilst creating a world of whimsy constricted by underlying dread with an approach to recognisable Wonderland characters in both a stylised and unnerving manner. All of which is contained in visually stunning locations whilst an atmospheric soundtrack does the rest making for an unforgettable experience.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												Where to start, where to start...If you were ever a fan of Mcgee's original work, it goes without saying that you will utterly love this. I personally jumped into playing the Alice games without knowing anything prior, it was merely something that peaked my interest, and I'm glad it did.From start to finish I loved this game. The character development throughout the entire thing is incredible, the expressions of emotions pulls you so deeply into it that you just keep wanting to play through. You can really begin to sympathise with Alice as you begin to piece together her story. Each stage is tailor made to help with sucking you in, the aquatic level and the Queen of Hearts has to be my personal favourites. You, at a point get to be a giant cranky stomping Alice. What more could you want?When it comes to graphics and level design, I cannot tell you how many times I stopped just to take screenshots or simply to admire the scenery. Each spot has something special to it, little details that are so well placed to give it depth and character, sometimes you almost want levels to last longer just to enjoy each one a little more.Levels, really decently long, oozing with story, characters developing right before your eyes, beautiful scenery, and all around are well put together to make the entirety have substance, this is all helped and topped with incredible voice acting and sound effects just being the cherry on top.OH! The weapons. The weapons... I want each and every single one as a replica on my wall. The detail to each unique piece is marvalous. The different feels and different looks to each upgrade, how well they fit into the environment, how they handle. Not one single complaint about them, aside from the lack of replica's.. Also When it comes to the hobby horse (my personal favourite), I almost didn't want to upgrade it to the final level due to the black deathmare being so badass.When coming down to it, I only have a few major gripes.. One resting with the god awful camera controls making certain places to get through a nightmare and some if not most fighting areas a near impossibility that is made even worse with the wonky targeting feature. Half the time it is targeting something you can't even hit while the closest enemy is in your face almost killing you. All while you're juggling to get the camera to not be looking at the pretty rock behind you but to focus on the crabs with cannons now blowing your face to pieces. Which then leads to your respawn, generally half a level behind, or just at the beginning of the same fight that you've been struggling with for about an hour now, making it even more infuriating. None the less, it's worth suffering through to enjoy this masterpiece. Afterall, we're all a little insane.
