number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2011
												If I could describe this game using one word, it'd be "stunning". For a while, I've lauded the platformer Trine as having the most beautiful aesthetics. The moment I set foot in Alice: Madness Returns, I realized I was wrong. THIS game takes the cake. From beginning to end, your breath will be taken away by each unique shift in scenery.But a game isn't all about visuals. In terms of gameplay, Alice is a mindless but fun hack-and-slash. You'll often be able to brutalize hordes of enemies with ease, but once in a while, tactics are required. My biggest gripe about the combat system is the inaccurate lock-on and obstructive camera system.But more prominent than combat is Alice's platforming aspects. You'll find yourself jumping on platforms after platforms, reminiscent of older games. As an element rarely found in modern games, I thoroughly enjoyed these sections.The plot is convoluted by dialogue excellent. Wonderland is definitely a world you can't miss.Grade: B+

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This game is surreal enough to keep me interested even if it gets annoying with the platformer feat. Jumping from one falling rock to an other just to get trapped by unnamed horrors - if you don't fall down, they will get you surely. It gets annoying after a time, but as I said, something in the game keeps me wanting more, it makes me care for Alice enough to push on, so I get over the next obstacle, then I get a boss fight, then an other, totally messed-up environment and new enemies. It gives me nearly everything I look for in a game: story, interesting maps, a level of horror and action, good-enough graphics, I would say give the demo a try and buy it when it's on a flash sale.

But after beating it it is then worth beating on New-+ because thing makes since, and you realise that chapter 3-4 were in-fact important for the story, but you had no way of knowing that or feeling that, until after chapter 6. lol. This game will mess with you, and you'll feel happier not playing it. But once you beat it you'll see the world in a new mindset. haha

McGee took Alice-in-Wonderland in a vagarious direction sporting a dark tale of torment and psychological abuse, whilst creating a world of whimsy constricted by underlying dread with an approach to recognisable Wonderland characters in both a stylised and unnerving manner. content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is an action platformer inspired by Alice in Wonderland. This is a follow up to American McGee's Alice, and shares the same style. That style is what this game has in spades. It stars the Alice in Wonderland characters, but in a very grimdark/steampunk universe. If that is your cup of tea, then this game is definitely for you. If not, then take a closer look at the gameplay to see if you would like this.This game is a very linear action platformer. You will be ushered along from point A to B in mostly constrictive environments. Along the way, you will battle baddies with you selection of weapons (blade, hammer, pepper gun, umbrella) and look for collectibles. Collectible teeth can be saved to upgrade your weapons. The other collectibles have no noticeable effect apart from filling in some backstory. Combat can be quite exhilirating at times, since the enemies are varied and are thrown at you in different combinations. You will definitely have to use dodging, blocking and switching weapons to succeed. I mostly stuck with the Vorpal blade since it seemed to be the quickest, although some enemies require the Pepper gun to create openings. Learning enemy patterns is also very necessary to survive. The combat can also be very difficult at times, which would not normally be an issue, but if you die due to enemy attack you could be set back several minutes in progress. Checkpoints save automatically, but on more than one occasion I found that after dying I had to complete several sections of platforming just to get back to the battle. This can be quite annoying, especially since if you happen to fall during platforming you are usually just sent back to the platform you fell from. I do not know why they are different checkpoints for each, and I would much prefer just starting again from the beginning of the battle. The platforming controls are tight and fun, with double jumps and floating at your disposal. You know you made a mistake when you fall, and that is all you can ask for.The graphics are definitely a selling point, especially if you are a fan of steampunk. Everything is heavily stylized, with only Alice having a hint of being realistic. There was some noticeable slowdown in certain areas, especially during battles. Framerate came to a stutter a few times, which is odd considering I can run most newer games from 2014 in medium-high settings and this game came out in 2011. The music and voice acting are all very well done. Once again, if you like Alice in Wonderland or steampunk you will probably really enjoy the dialogue, but if not, well it can be quite silly at times.I would recommend Alice: Madness Returns to all those that are huge fans of action platforming, or like the idea of a steampunk Alice in Wonderland. While it is not the best of its genre, it is worthy of a try if you really like those types of games. I found myself not terribly interested in the story, but I am just not a fan of that style and i won't hold it against this game. People that are only mildly interested in platforming might want to look elsewhere first.Grade: B-

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												When I was just 12 I got my hands on this games predecessor, American McGee's Alice. Back in the day, it was well known for his beautiful graphics with a very nice horror vibe, a haunting soundtrack by Chris Vrenna and a great story. And these parts of Alice: Madness Returns as just as great as in its prequel.The game continues the story of the alternative Alice we met in 2000. After the events in wonderland Alice is being released from the asylum and now lives in London under the care of Dr. Angus Bumby. She still suffers from her traumatic childhood memories and returns to Wonderland in search for comfort - but Wonderland once again changed accordingly to Alice’s psyche and a new threat to the whole land has risen.Madness Returns plays very similar to that of its predecessor, as in most of game consists of the player exploring Wonderland, fighting enemies, and navigating the environments along the way. The game is a great platformer, giving Alice the abilities to double jump and float. To make her way through Wonderland, Alice has to locate switches to open doors or make a new path available. Other means of furthering her progress include shooting flying pig snorts with a pepper grinder, shrink herself to fit through small (key) holes and place and detonate the clockwork bomb.Some obligatory minigames round the game up - though they are either interesting or annoying (mostly the latter).The game is definitely fun. I personally enjoyed the ties to the old game, the way of telling the story through Alice memories she finds along the way that are filled with metaphors and hints to the events in Wonderland.The gameplay can be repetitive, but is still enjoyable and fits into the nicely done levels and lore. The game looks beautiful and has a very unique atmosphere that sucked me right in. Wonderland is interesting, though it could have been more lore-intensive. There aren't that many things to discover you wouldn't see in the main storyline. Sadly, this game seems to be quite buggy. There are a variety of problems reported by the community, but most of them have an easy work-around.All in all, I recommend to get this game on sale if you're interested in a unique story with a beautiful setting and if you're fan of platformers.

Unfortunately it is very expensive in Europe still.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												The sequel to 2000's American McGee's Alice.Madness Returns brings the thirdperson-platformer to hack'n'slash territory, with fluid like combat, and easy to learn controls.The games graphics are far more styilized compared to the first game. Sure this one is a decade ahead in terms of graphic capibility, but the overall style and tone is much more cartoonish, which I actually think aids the games narritive. The original was dark and depressing because that game was just that. A dark and depressing variation on the novel.Here, the world of Wonderland is drastically more colorful. The combat is rather basic, but it's simple enough to not get in the way. This isn't a game that really needs combos. There are a few, and they do do more damage, but that's about it.One of the negative aspects I feel of the game is that you only have 5 weapons. You have the Vorpal Blade, the classic Knife Alice used in the first game, the Hobbyborse, which acts as your strong attack that can break defenses, a timed Rabbit bomb which can press down weighted switches and deal explosive damage, a Pepper grinder that can be used as a longranged attack, a Tea-Pot cannon, which is a strong explosive ranged attack, and the last one is the Umbrella. The umbrella doesn't really count as a weapon, you just use it to deflect projectiles back at certian enemies.Since the game has a hack'n'slash perspective, the limited arsenal is understandable, but can get a tad bland late in the game. The game is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing long. If it's your first time, you may spend well over 24+ hours on it depending on what difficulty you play on. And that's all just in one sit down, nevermind the amount of time you may put off on it. Part of this problem is that the chapters are so excessivley long. Chapter 1 took me around 3 1/2 hours the first time I played the game, simply because I wanted to explore everywhere.The enviroments are absolutely breathtaking. The game runs on Unreal3, but they really took advantage of it. The Vale of Tears, The Hatter's Domain, Queensland, and Cardbridge are all stunning to look at. It's an absolutely gorgeous game and one that demands to be played at max settings.American McGee is an amazingly creative individual, and shows that he can once again bring the magic back to Wonderland for a second romp. It's drasticly different combat mechanics may put off fans of the original, but as a sequel, it's absolutely fantastic, and I could recommend this to anyone. Even if you haven't played the first game.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2013
												NOTE: This is my opinions and thoughts of the game and not an overall view if the game for general audience. As with many reviews and opinions, take this with a grain of salt and do your own research. It is a shame I have to put up these notes telling people what they should already know on to do their own, but due to inflammatory commentry, I do.Okay, so I wound up playing this game for 5 hours straight and absolutely love it. From the beginning, this game is artsy, gothic, surreal, creative, inventive, and a bit disturbing. The beloved fantasy realm Alice used as her escape from reality-from life-is thrown into chaos, mirroring the once innocent girl's now tomented mind. Through stunning and disturbing imagery we can see what Wonderland once was, what it has become, and what it is turning into. The camera and movement controls are just as perfect as directional buttons and a joystick, so those used to PS3 like myself had no problems adjusting. Gameplay is fluid, colors are vibrant to dull, sharp to blended, and the attention to detail is perfect. There is nothing boring or dull about this game as it really takes hold or your senses of sight and sound, keeping your brain stimulated and your reflexes ready.My only complait about this game is that there is no camera sensitivity controls and during in-game play it's kind of fast, out of gameplay it's slow. Other than that this game is worth the money for more than just the gameplay, but the experience as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
Quality Summer Sale Purchase!You won't go wrong with adding this to your library, espeically if picked up cheap at a sale.Nice mature revist to the aftermath of the fairytale we all know.GameplayThe game has a nice balance between the platforming/fights while traversing the imaginative world of Wonderland.It is a linear platforming exploration experience but the way you move really livens it up. It does hold your hands for the most part due to the nature of the on-demand shrinking of Alice that allows her to see wall markings that point out hidden paths, activation switches and imminent battles.CombatCombat is simple yet surprisingly enjoyable. Even on the hard difficulty enemies are easy to take down but can prove problematic if you get complacent around a group of varied enemies types.I went into the game with only a brief look at the combat system on YouTube videos and was bracing myself for it to be the weakest aspect to the game but it strangley develops into a very satisfying part of the game.Alice has an arsenal of deadly weaponary that all comes together allowing her to combo her two primaries together.  decent pc controls  enemy designs  upgrading system that changes weapon appearancesArtThe main reason for wanting this game was for the surreal and fantastical environments and it delievered on that account to which I've found myself staring off into the distance at the dreamlike imagery. Not the mention the costume designs that Alice sports.Characters other than Alice are portrayed as caricatures making her seem "normal" in respect to her appearance despite her suffering from a debilitating mental affliction.The denizens of Wonderland also come off as unsettling creatures.Overall, this is a highly enjoyable game that just feels good to play. I guarantee you'll find fun with this.

content:
Posted: January 16
												8/10As an Alice in Wonderland fan, I'll be the first to say that I adore this game. It's not Alice though - it's a set a few years after Alice's parents burned to death in a fire and Alice's has to make her way in the world, occasionally seeing her therapist. Now, she returns to Wonderland. Madness returns.I completed this game on the Xbox 360. The controls are pretty clunky for PC so I'd recommend using a controller of some sort. The mechanics of the game are fairly enjoyable. A bit simplistic in places, There's a typical optional side quest for the completionists where you can collect some hidden treasures scattered throughout the game.The plot is excellent, and pretty dark in places. For those who require it, I'll offer a trigger warning for sexual abuse.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2016
												-If you value visuals over minor bugs, then I'm sure you'll be okay with this game. Any glitch or bug I've had while playing could be fixed by restarting the game, so nothing game-breaking so far.-This game is beautiful and dark. There is some blood and other disturbing elements involved, but also some gorgeous sights to behold.-The general game difficulty and puzzles aren't mind-numbingly difficult, so prepare for a smooth ride.-There aren't jumpscares. (This is something I'm happy about.) It saves you the terrifyingly annoying fear of being screamed at around the next corner. The horror aspect is mostly from the atmosphere, and there are many bits (Alice's attire, environment, music, etc.) that contribute to the theme of the chapter/area.-Took me a little while to understand all aspects of the story, but being the age I am, it always takes me a while to get it.-The combat, weapon upgrades and platform/jumping puzzles are quite fun in my opinion, especially once you know what you're doingI will continue to play and replay this game. It is one of the gems that reaches many of the things I love to see in games.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Alice : Madness Returns is a adventure/platformer game that takes you through various locations, while jumping, bouncing, exploring & killing monsters. I will keep the review simple, list of pros & cons below.+Unique artstyle, creepy, eerie & dark is what it's best described as.+Game runs fluid for me, 60+fps all the time (a few stutters do happen mainly when starting a new level or due to physx)+Physx is amazing, dust, particle effects & other things all move around when touched.+Various locations to explore, half the time you'll end up just gazing at the wonderfully done environments & backgrounds+Platforming is actually fun and not tedious, you have the ability to double jump & hover.+Cheshire the cat and his quotes+Various enemies will be encountered along your adventure+/- repetitive combat, while I didn't mind it others will be bored to death because you're mainly doing the same moves over & over. You do have some different weapons to take on enemies, the vorpal knife & hobby horse for light/heavy melee attacks, pepper grinder & teapot cannon for light/heavy ranged attacks and an umbrella for deflecting some ranged attacks back. +/- Game takes about 9-11 hours average to complete, while I thought it was a decent length, it might overstay it's welcome to some-Some ugly graphics up close-Needed to edit a file to unlock framerate-Previous game not includedWould definitely recommend this game to people who like Alice and/or adventure platforming games with a unique artstyle.PC SPECSGTX 980ti4790K 4.4ghz16GB DDR3 Ram

content:
Posted: August 16, 2012
												Standard progression, through a wonderfully prepared set of levels but just when you begin to tire of the one-paced experience they throw in something different to keep it interesting.A shame the in-game collectibles don't entice you in to having a need to complete the set - and considering there are 150+, they've missed a trick. The weapon upgrades are straight forward, and again it would have been nice to see something other than simply brute force and a change of graphics added.Chaper 5 onward is strictly out of bounds for your kids as the game takes a dark, bitter turn and won't be pleasant viewing for any little ones.Beautiful, bonkers and occasionally an exceptionally frustrating playing experience - but the other 95% game and delicious scenery more than make up for the occasional shortcoming. Most definitely recommended.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												To fully understand Alice: Madness Returns, we must first examine the original game, American McGee's Alice. Which is arguably my favorite videogame of all time. Let's consider various qualities of the first title and let's see if they were brought back in the sequel.Alice had a wonderful level design and art direction, with impressive textures for its time. While Madness Returns retains such great artistic value and a fairly good level design, the textures and props scattered around are fairly repetitive, and rather muddy in some sections. To the point of low resolution.Alice's combat revolved around various weapons, saved for the late, very powerful, mandatory tools of destruction. Also, the title offered various enemies to keep things interesting. While Madness Returns got its good share of unique monsters, the combat is made a trivial affair by two or three weapons, with some of the Alice's moves barely being involved at all. It's a practical matter.Alice liked to throw in some puzzles from time to time, each of them different and increasingly difficult, to the point of reaching PLATFORM HELL in later levels. Madness Returns has a great total of three or four kinds of puzzle which are repeated every time is needed. Also, they are skippable with impunity.To cut this suggestion short, Alice: Madness Returns can be enjoyed for its intriguing, fridge horrorific story, atmosphere and artistic design, but it has very little to offer elsewhere, with a repetitive gameplay and a general lack of polish.... Also, no bosses.... I belived I had to mention that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												When I was just 12 I got my hands on this games predecessor, American McGee's Alice. Back in the day, it was well known for his beautiful graphics with a very nice horror vibe, a haunting soundtrack by Chris Vrenna and a great story. And these parts of Alice: Madness Returns as just as great as in its prequel.The game continues the story of the alternative Alice we met in 2000. After the events in wonderland Alice is being released from the asylum and now lives in London under the care of Dr. Angus Bumby. She still suffers from her traumatic childhood memories and returns to Wonderland in search for comfort - but Wonderland once again changed accordingly to Alice’s psyche and a new threat to the whole land has risen.Madness Returns plays very similar to that of its predecessor, as in most of game consists of the player exploring Wonderland, fighting enemies, and navigating the environments along the way. The game is a great platformer, giving Alice the abilities to double jump and float. To make her way through Wonderland, Alice has to locate switches to open doors or make a new path available. Other means of furthering her progress include shooting flying pig snorts with a pepper grinder, shrink herself to fit through small (key) holes and place and detonate the clockwork bomb.Some obligatory minigames round the game up - though they are either interesting or annoying (mostly the latter).The game is definitely fun. I personally enjoyed the ties to the old game, the way of telling the story through Alice memories she finds along the way that are filled with metaphors and hints to the events in Wonderland.The gameplay can be repetitive, but is still enjoyable and fits into the nicely done levels and lore. The game looks beautiful and has a very unique atmosphere that sucked me right in. Wonderland is interesting, though it could have been more lore-intensive. There aren't that many things to discover you wouldn't see in the main storyline. Sadly, this game seems to be quite buggy. There are a variety of problems reported by the community, but most of them have an easy work-around.All in all, I recommend to get this game on sale if you're interested in a unique story with a beautiful setting and if you're fan of platformers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
Alice: Madness ReturnsTo begin with, I highly recommend playing this game, and here's the reason why: Alice.Based on American McGee's vision of Alice and her imaginary (for sure?) Wonderland, this game takes you on a adventure into depths of Alice's mind, which in it's current state, is a pretty devasted place. A:MR is a typical platforming slasher, similar to Devil May Cry but a little less complicated - combos are limited, there's not much special attacks etc. Fighting mechanism, though limited, is based on finding enemies' weaknesses and using them, which on higher difficulty levels (I played on Nightmare) can be a bit tricky to pull off. Throughout the game, you're able to use 5 types of weapons (with a very interesting design), given to you on various stages of gameplay. Fights are extremely satisfying, challenging and well-balanced. The only aspect of fighting which I didn't like was targetting (by default set to Caps Lock), as it sometimes messes with the camera. Platforming aspect of the game lacks a little comparing to similar games. There are a lot of invisible walls, meshes and textures which block your path (best example being straight floor with a little crack in it which you have to jump over) or places where you'd think you can jump to, but you can't. Also, Alice's ability to dodge mid-air, which makes your jump longer, sometimes doesn't work properly, making you dodge into the abyss rather than forward.  All of those though, become forgivable, when you take a look at scenery and level design. I've never seen world more beautiful and grotesque in a video game. There's always a challenge of some sort in your path, which makes the game enjoyable throughout the ~17 hours gameplay (on Nightmare difficulty). Every chapter is different, introducing new lands in Wonderland and what comes with it - new enemies. The most important thing is the plot. Grotesque, fascinating and magical at the same time. I can only say that you must save Wonderland, to save yourself, and vice-versa. Pros: gameplay, plot, atmosphere, fights, visuals, Alice and WonderlandCons: invisible walls (!), targeting during fights, places which you might find reachable in fact are not, a little bit of general "bugginess"All in all: 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												While Alice is now a bit dated (time of writing 2016), the colors and design of the levels make the very best of the relatively simple geometries from 2011 and looks great. The unique story is interesting and in each chapter you learn a new clue that keeps your attention. It's also been a while since a game had actual sidescroller mini-games in it. The dresses are cool and the music is great. While you might think "an Alice in Wonderland game? Must be for kids.." Ha no, don't let kids play this, they'll get nightmares and end up like Alice!The bad: This is unfortunately a console port and EA did very little to make it compatable with PC controls. First off, if the game won't let you register open starting, copy the key and add it to Origin, then it'll even work through Steam. There are many forum posts online on what lines to change in the .ini's for removing the horrible mouse lag/smoothing, as well as removing the 30fps cap among other things. You will run into bugs and sudden crashes happen occasionally, but it's not bad enough to ruin the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game's reputation as a flawed gem is well deserved. Once tweaked effectively (i.e. kill PhysX) it plays smoothly and looks good on a moderately powered machine which is just as well as the environments are varied and all beautifully realised both in Wonderland and back in reality. You're constantly given snippets of back-story via various collectibles so there's a big sense of immersion.The downsides are that this game is riddled with bugs. I didn't suffer the umbrella issues that many report but the game crashed to dektop at least once per playthrough. As with many EA games on Steam there are no achievements or trading cards. Controller support is passable but not all on-screen prompts have been updated (which is odd considering there's an Xbox 360 version) which often leaves you struggling to locate the buttons for new abilities/weapons. Overall it's an enjoyable romp through the scenery but with 70% of terrain being moving platforms of one sort or another it cann leave you feeling like you're in one big jump puzzle. I enjoyed a single playthrough but there wasn't anything that made me want to go back start a New Game +. I'd recommend getting this in a sale. It was certainly worth the £2.50 I paid for it but not a great deal more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												I'm not quite done with the game but considering my play time, I think it's safe to say that I get the gist and understand the point of Alice: Madness Returns. Basically, you play as Alice Liddell who's deeply distressed because of the death of her parents. But to be able to get rid of her sufferings and to learn the truth about her past, she once again falls into Wonderland, as there is a new evil force that has corrupted it.Pros:- Third-person game- Beautiful topography- Easy Puzzles - You can skip some mini-games- Sp00py !Third-person game: This game being a third-person game is an advantage for me as I get motion sickness from playing first-person games. So to anyone who is like me, this game is perfect for you!Beautiful topography: The efforts into putting meticulous details in the cinematography, scenery, atmosphere, and artwork are absolutely stunning. Believe it or not, I've found myself just wandering in the game looking at every thing precisely. I'm unable to express how the evironment (?? of the game shocked me. I seem to always go "woowww"  I'M SHOOK!!!!!!! Easy Puzzles: It doesn't take very long to solve a puzzle because they're really simple! They just require the right timing (which I'm not good at, but hey! I know how to solve them!) You can skip some mini-games: Pretty much self explanatory. If you would just like to save time or not use your brain to solve these mini-game puzzles ('Cause you're probably saving it for the main puzzles in the game) Or don't skip it if you don't want to and get the whole experience of the game. Who am I to judge? You do you. Sp00py !: The aesthetic of this game is almost identical to mine! This is the main reason that keeps me going back to play the game - Just to experience the horror/creepy elements of the game combined with the gorgeous art.Cons: In my opinion/experience, the biggest drawback to this game are:- Annoying camera angles - Some of the minigames (omg!!!!! ><) - Repetitive Story (??? Annoying camera angles: THISSSS. This is so freaking annoying! As I try to solve puzzles, the camera angles change and I screw up (As mentioned above, timing is important) and I'll have to attempt it so many times until I pass the level! I believe it's a matter of getting used to. I guess that's something I'm not very good at. Minigames: I'm not a big fan of side scrolling games and there are a few in here that either frustrated me to a point where I have to take a break or it either turned me off that I stop playing the game for a while. Story: For lack of better word, I have used 'Story' About the story, yes, I get it that she's mentally scarred. However, the game emphasizes on it several times that it gets redundant that makes me question, "What's the plot again?" I mean, I understand what I'm supposed to do and why I'm doing it but somehow, the repetition just makes me so lost.So this is my review for now! Please bear in mind that my thoughts and opinions may change as I progress in the game and also, our opinions may vary! So please do not say anything harsh! I shall edit this review once I finish this wonderful game! ♡〜٩( ╹▿╹ )۶〜♡

content:
Posted: August 26, 2016
												Alice is an interesting tale of dark magic and repressed memories from psychological scarring. I won't applaud it for doing anything particularly amazing as the gameplay and story feel mostly disconnected. However, it provides drive to keep you going, if you can push yourself through the hurdles this game unnecessarily provides you.As a 3D platformer with combat elements, the game is actually very solid, with tight controls and a (mostly) fluid combat system. It's a pretty stock standard combat system, but it's functional and with additional abilities unlocked over time, it does gain some diversity.My biggest complaint is the sheer length of the game. While it looks pretty good throughout, a lot of areas drag out far longer than is welcome. I legit put in about 15 hours to complete this game and  I have to say most of it was tedious and repetitive.Alice is a good game, trapped inside EA's Origin system. If you're prepared to struggle through, you will get a pretty decent platformer so long as you bring a controller. The mouse/keyboard controls are balls.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												Since Steam only supports up or down reviews I’ll give this one a thumbs-up on the basis of its great graphics, superb voice acting and dark story. The action throughout the game is generally good as well, although, as other reviewers have pointed out, the “lock on” feature can be a pain to use. In short, if you’re willing to see the game through it can be a rewarding experience, and the finale is incredibly satisfying.Unfortunately, the game has its fair share of faults as well. There are no Steam achievements and the game is home to more than its fair share of bugs and glitches, sometimes requiring a restart. However, the biggest problem with the game is some of the design choices; it's full of “padding” meant to add hours to the game that feel totally unnecessary. Worse, while some of the easier puzzles can be skipped, most of the gimmicky sections, like directing a doll head through a 3D pinball machine, can’t. These sections are in equal parts painful and annoying and you’ll be glad when they’re done. The game’s jumping mechanic is also totally merciless; while most games will let the protagonist crawl up onto platforms that they nearly made it on, Madness Returns does not. If even Alice’s tippy-toes don’t make it onto the platform you will plummet to your death, again and again and again. This is not a game for the faint-hearted.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is true homage to the Duck Tails type of games where you jump over obstacles, collect flashy stuff and kill enemies without graphical violence. I purchased it because the design looked so irresistable beautiful. And I didn't have to be disappointed. The world is awe-strickingly beautiful, crazy in the sense of fantasy and highly original. The running speed and jumping capabilities are really pushing the whole flow of the game and make Alice a sort of superhero. I played Borderlands 2 after Alice and I couldn't get rid of trying to attempt the double jump, that was so well embed in Madness Returns that I felt disabled from the lack of this feature in other games.I consider gaming an escapist hobby and Alice: Madness Returns has taken hold of this idea and put it to use. Alice travels between two worlds: the real world, which is a dark, distorted, unpleasant and dirty place while the other, Wonderland is a colorful, bright, interesting place where Alice gains superpowers - a true escapist vision and understanding of balance between fantasy and reality. And it's yet another aspect that upgrades the game once you discover that the creators have thought about it.Some negative aspects:The game had an issue with the fighting script, especially when you were surrounded by several enemies. Executing the malee attack command caused Alice to either attack in the wrong direction or deliver several uncontrolled attacks. This put the player in a tight position because it's not a particularly easy game and every health bar was on count. This problem became more and more of an issue in the second half of the game.Verdict:The game was and Experience with a capital. It was fun, the flow of the game was very enjoyable, the puzzles were challenging, the fighting script has potential for improvement but overall the game has great replay value.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2015
												This is a very good dark themed hack & slash action platform adventure with collectathon elements & if you're into games like that then this is worth every penny.  If not, then get it when it's on sale & you'll still enjoy it.PROS-Dark Retelling of a Classic-Smooth Action Combat System-Weapon Level Ups-3D Collectathon Platform Goodness-Cute Costumes-DLC Included (Need to edit an .ini file to unlock)CONS-Repetitive Combat-Camera can be bad during combat-Target Switching during Combat doesn't work well-30FPS Cap (Requires .ini file edit to increase)STORYI'll keep it brief & spoiler free.  The game starts out with an opening cutscene of Alice undergoing therapy in her so called "Mental Health Home".  Once therapy ends, you gain control & are free to explore the house at your leisure.  Eventually, Alice leaves the house & sees a white cat that she decides to follow.  Eventually losing it's trail she starts seeing illusions until eventually is found upon by an old woman who seems to be blackmailing Alice.  The old woman takes you to her home so you can tend to her pigeons where once again more creatures start to appear until eventually Alice is sent to Wonderland.  However, Wonderland seems to be in distress as something is causing it to become corrupted with black goo like creatures.  It's up to Alice to find out what's causing the creatures of Wonderland to go mad & stop it before it's too late!GAMEPLAYThe overall gameplay is fairly simple.  Non-combat sequences consist of mostly open world exploration & platforming.  Little areas exist that you can shrink down & find hidden extras like extra teeth, bottles, or memories.  Teeth are what Alice uses to increase the strength of her equipment.  There are also Pig Snouts that can lead you to them as well.  Simply find the snouts & shoot them to open the hidden pathways.  You're starting weapon is the Vorpal Blade which looks like a bloody kitchen knife.  Simply mash X to use it.  Your second weapon is the Pepper Grinder which shoots pepper pellets at enemies.  The third is the Hobby Horse which acts like a big hammer that can break enemy defenses & unlock more hidden paths by breaking down walls.  Once you get the Hobby Horse you can also experiment with different combinations of X/Y to see what works.  For me, I found that simply mashing X or Y repeatedly is good enough.  The combat is really barebones basic here  You can also dodge with the RB & block with A while locked onto a target.  Blocking projectiles at the right time will counter & send it back, usually breaking defenses.  The beginning level is a tutorial so you learn all this pretty quickly, with the exception of the Hobby Horse being in the Second Level.  You also get a Rabbit Bomb which can be used to hold down switches during puzzles or atract enemies during combat.Outside of combat it's a fairly typical 3D Platform experience.  Alice can jump high, then perform small mid-air jumps 3 more times for a bit of extra height.  She can glide short distances, shink down to see hidden pathways & access keyholes as well as use flowers to heal.  There are tons of switch puzzles in the game that require you to use the rabbit bomb to hold a switch & quickly move to hit another switch.What I really enjoy most about the game though is the dark themed atmosphere.  It is probably one of the prettier games you'll see especially for how old it is.  The graphic styling has aged very well so far & I think it will continue to look great in years to come.The only real problem I have with the gameplay is the camera during combat.  Sometimes it will be too close & you can't see where enemies are around you & when you try to swap to another target you can't.  It gets cumbersome at times but never really frustraiting, unless you're playing on Hard or higher difficulty.Throughout the game you'll also find these odd tunnel looking shells that lead to health powerups.  You need to complete a challenge in order to clame one & it takes 4 total to increase your health There's also several different costumes which you unlock throughout the game as well as DLC costumes & weapon reskins.  The DLC equipment makes the game really easy though because they give you extra bonuses like 1/2 damage taken or health regeneration.  If you want to play the game as it was meant to be I suggest not using DLC content your first time through.  On the other hand, if the game is too hard for you equiping the content may leviate some of the difficulty.OVERALLIf you like collectathon platformers & hack/slash games then you'll probably enjoy this game. This is basically both of those genres rolled into one & the dark themed story, great graphics & interesting cutscenes make this one worth getting & playing through to completion at least once.  If you're on the fence about it then you should get it when it's on a good sale, but I think it would be worth the purchase price regardless.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Even if you didn't play American McGee's alice 14+ years ago this game is still worth a play. Personally I played it more for the art rather than the gameplay, but that's just how it appealed to me. Both the combat and the "graphics" are great. The game's combat can be challenging for an adventure type depending on the difficulty one plays the game at, and if one refrains from abusing the teapot cannon *wink, wink*. There are a few puzzles of average difficulty, but they can even be skipped if the player is so inclined. The game encourages the player to look for secret's and solve puzzles as they give one a clearer idea of what's actually going on in the story, but it tends to not be required in order to advance in the game. All it serves to acomplish is to give the player a clearer idea of what happened in Alice's past that lead up to the mystery that drives the game. The story is pretty dark and some of it is left up to one's own interpretation, but overall the game gives you a fantastic plot that has some great twists. The cinematic's are fantastic and ample throughout the game (but not annoyingly so) and the art style varries for the different cultures expirienced in it as well. Everything about it services to create a very ineteresting expirience that the player won't soon forget.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												Really great game, beautiful art and graphics, amazing soundtrack, you're the only good looking person in the game so it will help your ego in some way too =D.The gameplay is really fluid imo, although i really missed an aerial attack and had to resort into using the ranged weapons (which i really didnt like using with the mouse), and i really would like some more combos (i THINK u only get one more attack for the melee weapons, and the only other combo u can get is from switching weapons between attacks).As for the technical part, i had to tweak some .ini files to get a fluid gameplay (stuttering and freezes occurred frequently), and the physx has really poor performance on ATI video card cuz it uses the CPU (and from what i read it uses only 1 core to do it e.e) to calculate the things, Nvidia uses the GPU (in my case, i have a HD 7850 and I7 4770, i get constant 60 fps on normal gameplay but when a lot of things happen on the  screen, particles etc, i get like 10-30 fps).That aside i would like the first game to be playable on this game (like the console games or the pre order edition on origin), and for those who dont know u can activate the costume DLCs through the .ini file (theres a topic on the steam forum about it).After the tweaks and using Physx on low i'm really enjoying my experience in the game.BTW the game has a 30 fps default lock, im playing on 60 fps with a tweak on the .ini

If you would just like to save time or not use your brain to solve these mini-game puzzles ('Cause you're probably saving it for the main puzzles in the game) Or don't skip it if you don't want to and get the whole experience of the game. Who am I to judge? You do you. Sp00py !: The aesthetic of this game is almost identical to mine! This is the main reason that keeps me going back to play the game - Just to experience the horror/creepy elements of the game combined with the gorgeous art.Cons: In my opinion/experience, the biggest drawback to this game are:- Annoying camera angles - Some of the minigames (omg!!!!! ><) - Repetitive Story (??? Annoying camera angles: THISSSS. This is so freaking annoying! As I try to solve puzzles, the camera angles change and I screw up (As mentioned above, timing is important) and I'll have to attempt it so many times until I pass the level! I believe it's a matter of getting used to. I guess that's something I'm not very good at. Minigames: I'm not a big fan of side scrolling games and there are a few in here that either frustrated me to a point where I have to take a break or it either turned me off that I stop playing the game for a while. Story: For lack of better word, I have used 'Story' About the story, yes, I get it that she's mentally scarred. However, the game emphasizes on it several times that it gets redundant that makes me question, "What's the plot again?" I mean, I understand what I'm supposed to do and why I'm doing it but somehow, the repetition just makes me so lost.So this is my review for now! Please bear in mind that my thoughts and opinions may change as I progress in the game and also, our opinions may vary! So please do not say anything harsh! I shall edit this review once I finish this wonderful game! ♡〜٩( ╹▿╹ )۶〜♡

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												This game's reputation as a flawed gem is well deserved. Once tweaked effectively (i.e. kill PhysX) it plays smoothly and looks good on a moderately powered machine which is just as well as the environments are varied and all beautifully realised both in Wonderland and back in reality. You're constantly given snippets of back-story via various collectibles so there's a big sense of immersion.The downsides are that this game is riddled with bugs. I didn't suffer the umbrella issues that many report but the game crashed to dektop at least once per playthrough. As with many EA games on Steam there are no achievements or trading cards. Controller support is passable but not all on-screen prompts have been updated (which is odd considering there's an Xbox 360 version) which often leaves you struggling to locate the buttons for new abilities/weapons. Overall it's an enjoyable romp through the scenery but with 70% of terrain being moving platforms of one sort or another it cann leave you feeling like you're in one big jump puzzle. I enjoyed a single playthrough but there wasn't anything that made me want to go back start a New Game +. I'd recommend getting this in a sale. It was certainly worth the £2.50 I paid for it but not a great deal more.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Alice: Madness Returns presents the beautiful but dark memories of a young girl.Pros: Graphics, Sound, StoryCons: Controls, Gameplay, PerformanceThe world of Alice: Madness Returns is wonderfully crafted, each preserving a sense of eerie beauty.  The sound and voice acting is excellent, matching the world and characters well.  Alice's adventures through Wonderland allow her tragic and dark past to come to light.  A Mature rating is well-deserved.The controls leave much to be desired, expecially camera and combat controls.  Though no support is listed, an XBox 360 controller seems to work and is recommended.  Gameplay becomes tedious after a while.  Finally, performance is severly lacking, with multiple crashes, bugs, and freezes.Alice: Madness Returns, despite its problems, is one of the best games based on Lewis Carroll's classic.8/10

												I much prefer the original American Mcgee's Alice, but this one is still worth checking out if it's on sale.  Though highly repetitive and padded, this is still a fun experience because of its visual design and atmosphere, which changes up more than its bland gameplay does. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27
												Picked this up about a year back in a sale and sort of forgot about it untill now. I'm glad I did remember it, because, although the platforming at time is needlessly hard and the combat is quite punishing (I must shamefully admit I hacked the difficulty in a config file below to even lower than easy because my button mashing was getting me nowhere to the point where I'd nearly given up), the visuals and story telling are pretty good. The wooden voiceacting fits the awkwardness of the period and storymatter quite well. It does a good job of presenting an atmospheric environment that reflects the storyline well, and I thought the character designs were very good. As a platformer, gameplay wise it reminds me at times of titles like psychonauts or the darksider titles, with a slow paced unlocking of weappons, lots of jumping and timed switches, hidden nooks and cranies and several collectables. If you didn't like that much, you wont like this.Along the way it drops hints and suggestions at the trauma that caused Alice her titular madness and I was pretty shocked to realize the full extend of it; I imagine anyone having had an experience in the past similar to the Alice in this title may find this hitting a bit too close to home. There were some bits (like the 2d sidescrolling segment or the dolls head bit) that were not so well executed, the first because it was a good idea in theory could have gone through a few iterations to take off the edges on control, the second because navigating the levels just wasn't fun. Luckily, those segments were few and quickly passed through. Like I said, some of it I found a little bit too hard to get though without some serious cheating, but I found the slowly unfolding story as well as the presentation well worth my time, especialy for that price.

												This game is gorgeous. The art direction is beautiful; every environment is nothing short of brilliant. I don't think I've seen anything quite like Tundraful, with the moon and sun having an almost papier mache quality to them; the sun literally frozen in its orbit; while the crescent moon smokes a cigarette, the green trails of which become the aurora borealis. content:
Posted: February 22, 2013
												What can I say about Alice. Well it's another journey down the rabbit hole through her madness and her journey to cure or at least learn more about it. There are locales showcasing her inner darkness and her whimsical imagination so there are nice shifts of the overall feel between levels. That and slowly gathering the pieces of her memories either through actually collecting them in game as well as the bits the story gives you is intriguing and you want to know more just like Alice herself. My only gripe with the game are the controls are odd with a mouse and keyboard and make the platforming a nightmare at times especially in latter levels where platforming is changeling, involving timed jumps, slides and changes of direction. Other than that I'd say it's another American McGee classic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
												Ah Alice, you wonderfully insane girl. True to the vein of Alice McGee's first game, this beautifully macabre depiction of a different Wonderland will have you slashing and bashing through six lengthy chapters. If you're looking for plenty of exploration and collecting then this gorgeously rendered title is right down your alley. Pros:-Gorgeous graphics which still hold up after five years-Memorable characters and settings-Gritty horror interchanges seamlessly with beautiful decors-Challenging platforming and battles-Long, rich gameplay with plenty to explore and collect-Lots of three-dimensional movement freedomCons:-Somewhat frustrating camera especially during combat-Limited arsenal/upgrades-Bit of a basic combat scheme, but very satisfying-Very forgiving checkpoint system, might not appeal much to those looking for higher challenge-Frame capped and a little unoptimized, might not run as smoothly on older machines (so I've heard)The story comes with brilliantly simple and fun minigames that are all woven into the main experience in a way that makes sense but sometimes leaves one to wonder if they weren't pushing for too much, however, it all plays out nicely. I couldn't help but notice that some parts felt stitched in later on leading me to assume it got rushed at one point.Every location feels like it's made with love and with an attention to detail, with a large and colorful variety of enemies to dispatch. A rich in-game collection makes up for the lack of achievements, and will most likely have you replay it a second time somewhere down the line.All in all, Madness Returns is a big and beautiful, action-packed, sometimes frustrating but overall rewarding experience with a twisted story that combines both body and psychological horror which is bound to tickle your cravings for a solid action-adventure game.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Games these days have begun to trail off from one another with different themes and qualities. From Physical Action, strategical thinking, dark mystery, and more, we all love them in their own special way. However even though they are great in their own ways, what would a game look like with all of their attributes combined into one look like? And that my friends would be the very game called "Alice: Madness Returns" This game is purely amazing. It has a very nice balance of all of the qualities other game posses. As you play this game you will travel into the depths of Alice's mind (Wonderland) seeing the beauties and terrors of what lurks within, while you try and prevent her madness of overcoming her. Throughout  your journey you encounter hellishly twisted enemies , complete a large verity of quest which each one involving a different form of thinking, and of course spectacular views of Alice's marvelous Wonderland. Even though once in a while the game may have a glitch or two you may need to look up to solve, over I rate this games a tumbs. Although i consider this to be one of the ideal games for adventure gamers, I still recommend it towards everyone.

Recently in the past few years, I replayed it and though it lacked in the graphics department, still delivered in gameplay, story and overall atmosphere... I would recommend playing it if you find the time.... Alice: Madness Returns adopts the same atmosphere: gritty, dark, sinister and demented, even going as far to use similar art styles and level designs... While linear in gameplay, there are still the additions of secret and mini-puzzles that can be overlooked, and while combat only becomes a challenge on hard difficulty and up, you will most likely be dying from all the jumping and falling you will be doing... Yes, almost the entire game consists of navigational jumping and platforming, much like the first one... This in my opinion gives the game its charm and unique difficulty curve in today's games, as most tend to stay clear of this: to me it helps one to really stop and pace yourself, as well as look for alternatives methods of completing your goals.... I touched briefly on the combat earlier, and the combat is very similar to most hack and slash games like DMC and Bayonetta, though a bit more washed down and lacking a rating system... The addition to actively dodge and time your attacks in a crowd works well, and the Hysteria berserker mode when health is low really helps keep the fighting fast and menacing.... I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys the old game, as well as those who are looking for a decent length game with a moderate challenge, unique dialogue and an almost tangible darkness one can enjoy.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												I've decided to update my review of this game after reading a few others' on the hub and ultimately agreeing with them. I'll try not to spoil anything for those wishing to purchase the game. First off, let me say I absolutely adore this story. It has definitely influenced my life as I, like Alice, feel that I often cannot escape my mind's tricks.Alice: Madness Returns is a much maturer, darker themed sequel to American McGee's 2000 game (*note: I have not played this*). We follow the story of Alice Liddell, whose childhood emotional trauma causes her to "fall" into hallucinations of Wonderland to escape the horrific reality playing out before her. She follows the sly and cryptic messages from the Cheshire Cat, who acts as our mentor through the game.We begin by learning that Alice's family had perished in a tragic fire many years ago and the guilt still haunts her to point of insanity, despite being released from Rutledge Asylum a year ago. A ripe age of 19, Alice resides at an orphanage for the mentally traumatized, under care of Dr. Angus Bumby. It is in the first few scenes that my interest was tickled; the characters' appearances and graphics were very unique, bar a little odd to the eye. The atmosphere is not welcoming, with much younger orphans throwing taunts as we pass by. Alice's interactions with different characters indicates that she is still very much an outsider.After running an errand we encounter some creepy looking creatures that cause enough anxiety to fall back into Alice's safe haven, Wonderland. I think it's fair to state, this is where the true beauty of the game lies. The scenery, sound, graphics, colour... There's just SO much to see and spam F12 at (you're lying if you didn't). Just take a look at this screenshot[web-vassets.ea.com] and tell me you're not entranced. . This is Wonderland. But, sadly, it's not all butterflies and rainbows.Alice soon discovers there is a force outside herself that is causing the destruction of this once beautiful place; the Infernal Train. We venture through different stages of Wonderland, the first of which bring unique combat features, familiar faces from the original story and foes. However, as the game progresses and you've hit a few hours, you'll begin to see a pattern. It seems that the developers wanted to just drag us through the middle chapters and on to the end. I personally felt like I was doing the same level for hours at a time. The only thing that changed was maybe the scenery. Same foes. Same combat. Same old objective. That being said, it definitely picks up towards the end. There's typical Alice in Wonderland features included that are necessary to continue ("eat me!") and some challenging moments with the bosses. There are also infrequent moments where Alice's mind switches back to London where her real self has been, well, out of it. These are scenes which I found interesting and wanted more of, as they often contained hidden explanations. It's all very fascinating to watch it unfold, but I felt that the time spent in Wonderland was too much, often finding myself pausing for a moment to remember where I'd actually last been in London. Overall, the ending was very satisfactory. After being admitted back into the Rutledge Asylum, in which many disturbing scenes play out, we make our way back to meet our ultimate foe, the Dollmaker. I personally did not realise the true identity of the Dollmaker for quite a while, as I had not made the time to collect many memory capsules along the way. The scene between Alice and this character was another interesting boss battle, with some unexpected moves catching me out and posing a challenge. As a result of this confrontation, we are overwhelmed with the despicable truth behind the Dollmaker's real-life counterpart. Alice's actions portray the true extent of his cruel betrayal here, however we're not treated with any gory details. We can deal with her brain being drilled into and scenes implying prostitution, but not blood and guts? Guysssss pls. I expected a full-blown revenge, instead I got a clumsily animated and out-of-time kaput. In conclusion, I, for one, am very much looking forward to the next instalment, Alice: Otherlands! I leave with you a final perplexing quote from our friend, Cheshire Cat: "Only the savage regard the endurance of pain as the measure of worth. Forgetting pain is convenient, remembering it agonising. But recovering the truth is worth the suffering and our Wonderland, though damaged, is safe in memory... for now."

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												In short, this game is beautiful but boring.The gameplay quickly becomes routine.  Jump here, find 1-3 switches, open some door, proceed to the next room.  Occasionally, some enemies attack you - the combat is a bit more diversified since you have multiple weapons, but nothing too special.  On the plus side, the visuals in this game are beautiful.  The artists on this game did an excellent job.  The dark-asylum environments that Alice goes through are always interesting to watch.  However, the repetitive nature of the game makes you wish the chapter was done so that you could see what the next one looks like.  The chapters are excessively long though, and you'll be in the same places for a while.It really feels like the game was polished on the artistic level, but rushed on the programming level.  One example of this phenomenon:  at the end of chapter 1, you get a cutscene with big-bad menacing creature screaming at you, a nice short cinematic experience that tells you "huge boss battle time" (finally something exciting after 2 hours of boring stuff).  Then a friend of yours just beats up the creature for you, it falls down and chapter 1 ends with no battle.  The art was there, the boss 3d model was already designed, but no time to program a boss fight it seems.  The developers didn't really seem to care about the gameplay.This is when I contemplated the option of not finishing the game.  Losing my time through chapter 2 confirmed that this is what I had to do.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												I loved the 2001 Alice, it was a one of a kind game at the time.  While that game was a FPS, Madness Returns is most accurately described as a platformer, with awkward, gimped first person aim mode (the game basically forces you to use its auto-aim "focus" mode while fighting) and "challenge jumping" a constant throughout the game.  The graphics are well-done for the most part, but game progression relies too much on making a new platform appear, etc. by turning levels and shooting pig snouts with a pepper gun (Pig snouts, why?  I don't know).  Side activities are mainly to find teeth (to upgrade weapons - which is fine, but isn't finding a new gun more fun??) and bottles, memories, etc., which as far as I can tell don't directly help the player and are more of an achievement thing.  Thumbs down for an overall tedious experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												The game is a mix of things done very well and things done well enough to be just acceptable. The graphics and physics engines mesh well with the art style, yet the music is largely forgettable. The platforming is very well done, however the combat is lacking in some respects. Having read the original Alice books, the games make many references to the characters and events of the novels, yet is devoid entirely of all of the literary nonsense and madness, at least in the dialogue, that made the originals so intriguing. The story premise is also very interesting, yet the pacing and dialogue falls a tad short for me in the game.It's a good sequel to the original, and people looking for a nice romp through a dark game will find it enjoyable, as will those who like 3D platformers. I still feel it could be better, and hopefully if a sequel comes out to this one day it will further improve upon the already solid series.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
												If $5,00 or less, I would buy for the visuals and story alone (or just go watch a play through on youtube if you are still unsure after reading my thoughts) Anything more and I would pass. Buyer beware of enraging EA DRM.Let's begin with the good of the game. The visuals of the game are wondrous (yep), and the story is actually not too shabby either. Sadly, that's about the only good you will get with this game. Now on to the bad. Before even getting the game running you will have to jump through a few hoops for EA, thanks to their wonderful DRM. If you get that figured out, then you will at least get to see the game. Now onto the controls. They are not out right terrible, which is actually worse in my mind. Their awful creeps up slowly, showing hints of bad here and there. It wound almost be better if they sucked outright so you could just put the game down before being drawn into it. On top of the control issues is the out right awful camera. Be prepared to inadvertently jump off a cliff to your doom because of this. The camera hates you and wants you dead. I think it might actually be the big baddy in the game in the long run.If $5,00 or less, I would buy for the visuals and story alone (or just go watch a play through on youtube if you are still unsure after reading my thoughts) Anything more and I would pass. Buyer beware of enraging EA DRM.

They're not that hard to figure out, but the game won't spoonfeed you what to do either. The storyline.It's just fantastic. Deep, immersive, gritty, macabre, enchanting, depressing.It's flawlessly paced, flawlessly told and perfectly presented!Helping Alice overcome her sorrow, guilt and escape from the depths of her MADNESS is something you truly take to heart if you let the world of the game suck you in.

StoryWrongly accused of her family's death in a fire, Alice is tortured by her past and goes insane. To escape this unbearable reality, she travels in her Wonderland... A world she created to survive... where she hopes to find her memories and sanity.Graphics & AtmosphereThe graphics and atmosphere are great. A crazy and dark version of Wonderland, just like Alice's mind. The music is also nice. It's an artistic masterpiece.For old computers, use this guide to improve perfomance : http://forums.steampowered.com/forums/showthread.php?t=1963500GameplayAction & Platform. 												Pros:+Absolutely stunning art and world design.+Alice is a very likeable protagonist (at least to me)+Game is a decent length and is actually a bit of a challenge on the hardest difficulty.Cons:+Shaky performance on AMD here, I have a 6350 paired with a 2GB 7850 and I get nasty framerate drops every now and then when there are a lot of particles on the screen. This happens on both the Steam version and the Origin version, and did not improve with a cracked version of the game either.+Relatively short experience+Combat camera can be exceptionally clunky at times+Boss fights are generally easy, even on the hardest difficulty.Overall: 9.5/10, but sadly, as a huge fan of this game, the PC version suffers from slowdowns even on very high end computers (tested with a 4770k/GTX 980 and had the same issues.)

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												This game is an all time favourite of mine. The world is beautifully crafted and the atmosphere is suitably crazed and dark, with strange entities everywhere you look. The voice acting and cutscenes are excellent as well. While I cannot speak for gameplay without an x-box controller, with one the game flows very well and combat is challenging yet not frustrating (except for those damn teapots). Though you only have a few weapons, the enemies vary greatly and particularly in nightmare mode you have to approach them in very different ways and experiment to find the right technique to kill each enemy most effectively. The areas differ vastly as well, offering a refreshing change just when the game begins to feel monotonous. TL:DR BUY THIS GAME ITS COMPLETELY AMAZING

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												A gorgeous 3D platformer that will take you through beautiful and dark worlds in Alices mind, as she tries to deal with the psychological trama of loosing her family in a house fire. ------Summary at the Bottom------GameplayAlice Madness Returns for the most part is a linear 3D platformer with basic elements of combat. The platforming feels tight and I never had any issue with the controls other than the camera in a couple of spots but adjusting the camera fixes it easy enough.The combat is basic hack and slash combat with a small variety of weapons to use such as a teapot, a knife, a pole horse and an umbrella. Each weapon is used in its own unique way and is needed for certain situations both in combat and for progressing through levels. Each weapon works differently from one another, for example the knife is quick but does weak damage where as The horsepole is strong but slow.GraphicsThe graphics in this game are very well done with sort of a steampunk goth horror style. Whether it be the dark streets of london or the beautiful mushroom forests of wonderland, this game knows what it wants to be. Its beautiful eye candy when it needs to be and digustingly creepy when it needs to be. Each chapter is very unique with its own setting and visuals. The levels are cleverly designed using things that would be naturally found in the environment as part of the platforming, such as steam from pipes working as sort of a boost between platforms in the factory levels.Character designs are unique and well done, with each chapter having its own unique characters, some being better than others. I personally enjoyed the mushroom forests and the card castle levels.AudioThe Audio is decent with the voice acting being very hit or miss for some characters, however the voice they chose for Alice was a perfect fit. Not sure if it was the same voice actor from the first game as I never looked into it or not, but they sound similar. The level audio is well done and makes the levels feel living and tangible.StoryThe storyline is a dark one continued from the first game. However you do not need to play the first game to really enjoy this game, as I actually played through this one first without even knowing about the first game. I have since went back and played the first game and although it does help to understand the story slightly better, it is not needed.You play as Alice who is a mental mess after her family dies in a house fire with alice being the only survivor. Events lead to Alice thinking she was the one who started it and blaming herself for the death of her family. This in turn does weird and disturbing things to wonderland, which is Alices sort of world in her head she can use to escape from reality. After noticing wonderland has gone into array and is in a very dark time, Alice sets off to find out wahts behind it and solve the issue and save wonderland as well as herself.SummaryIf you are a fan of steampunk/Gothic horror visuals then you will love the setting of this game. The storyline is pretty well done and will take you through a variety of different chapters, each very unique from one another and no you do not need to play the first game to understand this one, as I actually played this one first. The platforming controls feel tight and fluent, however the combat can feel a little bit stale with it basically being a hack and slash format. You have a small variety of upgradable weapons with Some being needed to take down certain enemies. This is definetly a game I would recommend with fun platforming and so many unique worlds to go through and explore. There was so much eye candy in this game, I couldn't stop taking screenshots. The game is decently long at around 12+ hours nad a variety of hidden collectable items can keep you playing even longer. Worth it at full price.

												Pros:+Absolutely stunning art and world design.+Alice is a very likeable protagonist (at least to me)+Game is a decent length and is actually a bit of a challenge on the hardest difficulty.Cons:+Shaky performance on AMD here, I have a 6350 paired with a 2GB 7850 and I get nasty framerate drops every now and then when there are a lot of particles on the screen. This happens on both the Steam version and the Origin version, and did not improve with a cracked version of the game either.+Relatively short experience+Combat camera can be exceptionally clunky at times+Boss fights are generally easy, even on the hardest difficulty.Overall: 9.5/10, but sadly, as a huge fan of this game, the PC version suffers from slowdowns even on very high end computers (tested with a 4770k/GTX 980 and had the same issues.)

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
 Positive + Gorgeous art style/environments+ Creepy and eerie soundtrack+ Interesting story laced with dark elements+ Good mixture of platforming and combat sections, as well as many other gameplay elements+ Lengthy campaign (approximately 10 hours on Normal difficulty, almost twice as long as the first game). Negative - Various content reused throughout the game (sliding puzzles/sections, rhythm-based minigames etc.) leads to tedium- Poor camera during combat/awkward lock-on system- Minor performance issues for the PC version (occasional stuttering, frame rate cap (though the latter can be fixed via config file))- Some low resolution textures and texture pop-in (courtesy of Unreal Engine)- Lack of an extensive and memorable weapons arsenal, unlike the first game. Verdict “While the gameplay may get somewhat repetitive over the course of the long and mostly linear campaign; the visuals, sound and compelling story make the visit into Alice’s psyche one worth experiencing (again).” 8/10 TJBs

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												It is very difficult not to reccomend this game. At the same time, it is also very difficult to reccomend it. Why so?To start, we are dealing with a very good tale from the Wonderland world. The story, the characters, the voice actors are on par with the best games out there. It deals with very dark and usually untouched stories in games. It would be awesome if the game were designed well enough to be on par with its concept and story. But that is certainly not what we have here.Poor level design, repetitive tasks, far too easy puzzles, boring boss fights and the same enemies over and over again. I have come through that in many games. At least in some of those games they had some consideration for details, such as making the mouth of characters move while they are talking not in a cinematic, paying more attention to make Alice's clothing be more detailed and even sexier, since we are dealing with with some sexuality topics on the game's plot (a lot of hookers around, etc).On the level design, it looks that they didn't consider that a player would spend 15 hours at least to end the game because the level designers made the scenarios boring. And you will see you asking yourself more than once why that particular part of the game exists.Truth to be told, there are some funny and entertaining mini games during the game. But all of them ripped of from other famous classics that you'll know when you see.The last stages seem to have been made by a very different team than the ones that made the first ones. Mainly the Bridge of Cards and Queensland levels. Both deserve some merit and certainly some of your playtime exploring them.SCORE6 - I played the game for the story. But most of the time I was really annoyed by bad level design decisions and boring parts of the game. Also, there is no real motivation for the new game plus that is available after you end the game, since there are no achievements to be obtained and the bonus content is really not that appealing. Bonus points for the voice actors and the character design (most of the time).WORTH BUYING? Yes, IF it on sale on Steam and below US$5DON'T: Expect too much from this game. Play it for the story.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6
												V roku 2000 som si zamiloval prvú brutálnu verziu temnej Alenky od známeho a ujetéto dizajnéra American MsGee, aby som si o jedenásť rokov neskôr pri "šialenom návrate" povedal sakra! Ten chlap je vážne génius!Madness Returns ignorovala všetky moderne postupy trojrozmerných hopsačiek a naservírovala poctivu porciu staromilskej hratelnosti, v ktorej príliš blízke priblíženie ku kraju útesu proste spôsobilo Alenkin neovládateľný pád s následným vyústením k jej smrti, resp. nahrávaniu uloženej pozície. A toto vôbec nebolo v moderných hopsavých hrách tak bežne, pretože niekde si raz niekto zmylel, že hráč je idiot a herná postava sa sama z vlastnej iniciatívy musí zabezpečiť proti nechcenému pádu. Čo bývalo u podobného typu hier tak trochu v rozpore s logikou a samotnej podstaty hratelnosti.Jedinečný a temný výtvarný štýl s najbizarnejšími nepriateľmi si musí získať srdce každého podobne zmýšľajúceho hráča takmer okamžite. Navyše nešlo len o obyčajne preskakovanie z plošinky na plošinku v príjemnej grafike. Alenka ponúkala ďaleko variabilnejšiu hrateľnosť s časťou zmenou prostredia a kvalitne rozprávaným inak pútavým príbehom.Za hardcore hrateľnosť s nutnosťou premýšľania nad riešením úloh, budete vďačný aj dnes. Aj šesť rokov po vydaní má totiž Alenka stále čo povedať a vo svojom žánrovom zaradení je dokonca stále konkurencia schopná. Aby som ale pravdu povedal, z osobného presvedčenia si myslím, že Alenka od American MsGee je tak jedinečná záležitosť, že o konkurencii nemôže byť vlastne ani reč...

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
Product received for free
												Alice: Madness returns looks beautifull. And so it is the art that drives one trough the game. To a extent.Because Alice: Madness returns also has masssive problems (that, coincidentally are the same as in the older game).The first is that every level JUST DRAAAAGS OOOON! More or less every level is faaar to long, outstaying it's wellcome beyound the wonder of the new designs and graphics and beauty that the game posses.The same jumping puzzles, the same enemy hordes that won't and won't end making fighting to a grind, the same way the leveldesign is structured (besides the optical elements). It all just feels made to keep you from progressing more then anything else.It just doesn't end. The pacing is totally off and after a while you just want to finally move on to the next level so you can see the next beautyfull designs.The second problem is the godawfull camera. No matter if it's the platforming or (even worse) the Zelda esque battlesystem, the camera is far to drawn in and so utterly infuriatingly inflexible in the battles. It's so limiting that you often die BECAUSE of it instead of the diffculty of the enemys.Conclusion: Alice Madness Reborn is a beautifull game with really fantastic designs and enemys and an equally great atmosphere.But i just can't go on trough levels that keep going on and on and on for no reason, stacking the same exercises up one after another and another and another, level for level for level.Take a look but don't expect to finish it.
