content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												IMPORTANT NOTE:To get to play the game, you need to activate it. The very first time you start up the game a product key appears - copy it to your clipboard ... and then go to EA.COM (the homepage of the EA company) online.The game will NOT activate if you just use the activation code in the small windows that pop up on your screen, one after the other, when you start up the game!REVIEW:Good stuff:- STUNNING graphics, gorgeous and imaginative.- Great atmosphere, mysterious and slightly unnerving.- Good musicBad stuff- The game is basically a platform-jumper (urgh!) with a lot of fighting and some puzzles.- I play on a PC, and controlling Alice is dificult and confusing.- No save option. The game choses when to save your progress.Verdict:While the game is a champion when it comes to imaginative, gorgeous graphics, I found it to be very, very frustrating to play. Alice is so dificult to control that I failed a lot of jumps and battle was not a fun experience. This is especially annoying when you can't save your progress after finally succeeding with something dificult!The game does a lot of things right, but the few things it does wrong, it does wrong to SUCH a degree, that I did not enjoy playing the game. A real bummer!Bonus info:It seems that the creators of the "Batman: Arkham" games have been very heavily influenced by this game! Alice's "shrinking vision" is the same as Batman's "detective vision" - and moving around, doing puzzles and fighting as Alice made me feel like I was playing Batman in "Arkham Asylum".

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												Well, I was a fan of American McGee's orginal "Alice" game and as much as I really, really want to give this a "thumbs up", I can't.  I mean, there is a lot to like here.PROS:- They've created a Wonderland that's beautiful, twisted, creepy, dark, and wonderful.- The story (or at least the part I made it through) seemed very interesting.- Platforming elements are challenging enough to be fun, but not to the point of being frustrating.  Alice's "twist" and "float" are neat.- Hidden stuff to find.  Yay.- Alice's "shrink" adds some fun elements to the game.- Great soundtrack.MEH:- Combat is a bit clunky, but it's do-able.CONS:- If I remember correctly, this game didn't used to have an EA registration.  In any event, EA has now added a thoroughly annoying and pointless required registration (of course, right?)- But here's the real deal-breaker, folks: The game is FREAKIN' BROKEN!  Once you get the umbrella, you realize that it's required to defeat the enemy that immediately follows.  And the umbrella is busted; I can't equip or use it.  And, of course, using the umbrella seems to be the only way to defeat that enemy.  And without defeating that enemy, there is no way to move on in the game.  Nice.Apparently, there is some fix available that requires the player to re-write part of the config.  Seriously...what a pain in the @$$.  Anyway, this whole mess essentially ruined the game for me.  And it seems I'm not the only player to encouter this glitch.  Buyer beware!Needless to say, I'm über-bummed with the mess this game turned out to be.  I was really looking forward to enjoying this one.  :(

content:
Posted: March 31, 2015
A twisted journey through the mind of a disturbed AliceBeautiful platformer with decent mechanics and relaxing gameplay.-----✓ Great visuals and PhysX integration✓ Levels are decently long✓ Gorgeous outfits in every level✓ Varied gameplay, it's more than just a plain platformer✓ Delightful voice acting/cutscenes✓ Upgradeable weapons✓ A wide variety of difficulty modes✗ NO ACHIEVEMENTS!✗ REQUIRES EA/ORIGIN ACCOUNT FOR ACTIVATION!✗ Plenty of potato textures, poor graphic settings✗ Full of invisible walls✗ Even if you're using a controller, the game will keep showing mouse+keyboard commands✗ Although fun to find, collectibles feel kinda pointless✗ Capped at 30fps (see how to uncap below)✗ Nightmare difficulty is a disappointment (see detailed explanation below)-----Personal thoughtsIf you're looking for a relaxing platformer game with third-person-shooter and hack-and-slash elements, don't think twice and get it. However, keep in mind that it has no achievements, which (in my opinion) takes away the sense of self-improvement for completionists. So you found all the memories/bottles, upgraded all the weapons and finished the game in nightmare difficulty? That's cute and all but it won't be engraved in your profile. Ever.Looking for a challenge? Think twice, because Alice: Madness Returns might not be for you. Why? Because Nightmare difficulty is a disappointment (and boy am I gonna get thumbed down for saying this). It won't spawn more enemies, it won't give them more HP, puzzles won't be harder... and it won't take away the constant hand-holding factor in the game (clues everywhere and the Cheshire cat appearing out of nowhere, telling you exactly what to do). Originally posted by you:		Well, what the hell does Nightmare difficulty change then?	The damage you take from enemies.That's it.That's all it does.And given that there are no achievements, you're better off enjoying yourself, playing in whichever difficulty suits you best and finishing the game in a 100% solitary experience. However, if you can see past these major flaws, the game is quite an enjoyable experience that I'd recommend to anyone.Noteworthy In order to get rid of the peasantry in this game, go to "Documents\My Games\Alice Madness Returns\AliceGame\Config", open AliceEngine.ini, find "MaxSmoothedFrameRate=31" and change the 31 to your monitor's refresh rate (60, 120, 144, etc.) Best played with a controller

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												tl;dr Great atmosphere, good story, average gameplay. Good for a playthrough. Pick it up when it's on sale next.By far, the most striking thing about the game is its art and atmosphere. Everything feels as off-kilter as a Wonderland run through a trauma filter should, from the dodo-powered machinery of the Hatter's hijacked tea factory to the utterly peaceful, yet utterly terrifying heights of Cardbridge. Each world is absolutely engrossing and sprinkled with details, making you wonder just what strange, horrible wonder is waiting around the corner. The music is suitably downbeat and chilling, picking up with heavy drums during combat, while the occasional string piece brings it all together with Victorian Gothic flair. The character designs are wonderfully macabre, with many returning characters receiving updated designs as befitting of Alice's vastly altered mindscape, and the voice acting is strong. Of particular note is Alice's ever-changing wardrobe; each dress aptly reflects the environment she is exploring, and each appears to have been designed with great care. Each dress also gains a unique gameplay modifier on a second playthrough, such as the Steamdress rewarding more Teeth (used to upgrade weapons) and Roses (the resident health item) from breakables or the Royal Suit limiting the health bar to four Roses.The story itself is similarly strong, albeit flawed towards the end. About a year after Alice's release from Rutledge Asylum at the end of the first game, Alice has found herself under the care of one Dr. Angus Bumby, a psychiatrist helping her to forget her past trauma. However, all is not quite right in Wonderland as once thought, and she finds her world being besieged by the Infernal Train and the Ruin, monsters of oil and machinery. She must return to her once-again fractured world to find the source of the corruption, unravel the mystery of this new madness and save her mind once more. The trickle of clues throughout the levels strings the player along fairly nicely, however it feels as though a few too many important details are left as collectible memories rather than presented at key points in the story. My primary gripe with the plot, however, comes in the last two or so hours of the game. Quite a few sudden revelations happen all at once, especially during two key segments towards the end, and coupled with the fact that some of the clues leading to these revelations are, as mentioned before, left as collectibles that could be easily passed over, the reveals felt jarring.Now for the game's primary issue: the gameplay itself. Now, the game isn't bad by any means. The platforming feels quite smooth, though at times shoddy camera angles can make some jumps harder than they would normally be. Largely, however, this is offset by the fairly generous and forgiving nature of the jump and glide abilities. Combat is relatively simple, with four primary weapons to choose from: the fast-but-weak Vorpal Blade and Pepper Grinder and the slow-but-strong Hobby Horse and Teapot Cannon. While fights can be a smidge on the easy side at times, stringing various combos with the different weapons, or landing a deflecting block with the Umbrella, is satisfying.  As a little personal plus, I liked that you couldn't acidentally dodge roll off of platforms; given the size of some of the platforms you fight on and how far you dodge, it would've been all too easy to launch yourself into the abyss if you could. However, the gameplay is repetitive, repetitive, REPETITIVE. I'll admit, on my first playthrough, I really didn't notice it all that much; the atmosphere and plot were plenty engaging enough and I was so interested to see what was coming next that I really didn't pay it much mind. It wasn't until my second playthrough for a stream, and particularly it wasn't until I reached Tundraful and Deluded Depths, that I started to recognize the patterns of the levels: Platforming segment, pull some levers, a Shrink Sense here and a Clockwork Bomb there, combat, repeat. Occasionally, there are mini-games found in the different chapters, but some (the Off with her Head game, especially) become incredibly tedious. While there are hidden collectibles and Radula Rooms (challenges) to be found just slightly off the beaten path, they don't do much to break up the feeling of linearity. The Deluded Depths and Dollhouse levels, in particular, feel as though they drag on for days.My biggest issue with the game, though, is that you can see just how much more American McGee and Spicy Horse wanted to do with the game. Missed opportunities are EVERYWHERE, with the most egregious being the lack of boss battles. Each chapter has perfect setups for end bosses, but in the end, they all quickly get handwaved away and you're shuffled off to the next bridging London segment with no real payoff. A lot of features found in the beta trailer, like the expanded London segments and the ability to swim through the Deluded Depths, would've been more than welcome, the London segments especially; London would've felt more like a proper setting in its own right than as simply a bridge between Wonderland visits.In the end, though, I can't say I didn't have fun with the game, and its art and atmosphere are truly wonderful to experience. It's a shame that the gameplay doesn't quite reach the same quality, but it's by no means a bad game; it's just not really one you'll want to play through more than once. If you're looking for an aesthetically-rich world and don't mind the gameplay being just alright, give it a look.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Alice Madness Returns caught my attention due to its graphical style. After playing through about half of the game, collecting as many secrets and collectibles as I can find, I have an opinion on the game as a whole.As I said, I love the visuals, the models still look great and the scenery is timeless. Not every part of the game is equally gorgeous though. After completing a part of the game, the game puts you in an underwater environment. The visual appeal of this part is underwhelming when compared to the part you just completed. Another thing that bothered me about that part is that the physics didn't change at all while underwater. But even if this all felt unnatural and a bit underwhelming, parts of the level still got me interested. The next level I was dropped into was equally awesome as the first.The story and the unique and interesting characters really add a lot to the experience. Every character in the game is memorable in some way. Even the enemies have a memorable look. They're not that hard to kill most of the time, but can provide quite the challenge when attacking in groups and do require you to be fast with the controls. The biggest challenges lie in the side missions though, so you don't have to face enormous hordes of monsters when playing through the main game.After all this positivity, we need to talk a bit about the negatives, as there are quite a few.Some parts of the game feel a bit rushed. Enemies placed in awkward spots that render parts of their behavior useless (example: an enemy that can only be defeated by returning it's ranged attacks is placed in a spot where he's not capable of firing shots). This can get really frustrating. The fact that if you die from damage, you have to redo a part of the game doesn't help either. The game also suffers heavily from random crashes through all of the game. One moment it works smooth, the other it closes down without any clear reason. The controls are sometimes fiddly as well, but this does not pose a major issue.To make it run smoothly, you need to apply some tweaks, such as unlocking the framerate and fixing a bug with the umbrella.After all, Alice Madness Returns brings a compelling adventure that still holds up to today's standards in it's genre. It's well worth it's somewhat high price. The collectibles really add to the game as well. They're fun to collect and provide a nice bit of extra story. I would recommend this game to people who like games like Rayman, 3D Mario games and old platformers alike.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is a rather unique beast of a game. I never found the jumping and fighting incredibly fun (Although it can be a little fun sometimes), the keyboard and mouse controls stink, the game has some optimization issues, sometimes the jumping is wonky as well as the game having frequent loading times. On top of that, the game runs at 30 fps unless you hop into the config files and change some stuff, which is a bit bothersome.Despite these issues, it's still one of my favorite games I've played in a long time. The story, the view on Alice's mental state, and the presentation of this game make it all worth the trouble. Wonderland is a broken mess, and so is Alice in a lot of ways. Wonderland is falling apart and a destructive force is barrelling through the land, tearing everything apart and threatening to destroy Alice mentally. Meanwhile in Victorian London, Alice struggles with finding answers to her family's death in a fatal fire. Frequently, Alice slips between London and Wonderland, switching between trying to find answers from people she knows, and looking within her memories, respectively.Weaved through all of these events is an odd mix of disturbing and beautiful environments that you'll be jumping through and fighting all sorts of nasty beasties in in your search for the truth. As the game goes on the environments become more gruesome, further signifying the slippery slope into madness.Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys an interesting story and more interesting art. The platforming is alright, the combat is sometimes pretty fun, and the aesthetic is incredible. Just remember to look up how to unlock the framerate and use a controller.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												I rarely call games "a masterpiece" but this one trully is. Simply because you can play it on a variety of levels and you will still find something to enjoy. If you're a combat fan, the combat is fluid and responsive with the arsenal of weapons (while limited) finds its use in different situations; If you like a story you'll be absolutely taken in by the wonderful world and masterfully crafted descent into madness; If you like graphics, they are very stylized, there is no texture reusing (to the point of each level being easy to memorize, begining to end, simply because of how unique each segment is); If you like an intellectual game, this is where it really shines. It is more layered than "Inception" and the symbolism is there at almost every turn. The references for those who like something to even further probe their brains, are a plethora (so as to not spoil it, I wont say anything other than that there's a Shindler's list refence, among others,  that hits the nail on the head).In short there is someone for everyone! Of course it isnt without its bad sides. But these come only in the form of bad coding, the eventual bug and/or freeze. Thankfully the game places checkpoints often so even if you have to restart you wont feel like you have to redo too much. I very VERY strongly recommend this one if you want to spend a few hours inside a trully polished and immersive game.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Alice: Madness Returns took me down the rabbit hole like no other could. I love this version of Alice in Wonderland. It might have caused me to question my own sanity but I wouldn't have it any other way.Practical info:At first I couldn't play the game as I was supposed to play it because I couldn't use the umbrella. It has been confirmed by a lot of people that the game doesn't always want to be played. I tried playing further by using the trick with the rabbitbomb but it was tiresome. I needed a real solution. Buying an xbox-controller for the pc was that solution (in my case).Experience:+ Art: simply beautiful! I played it on a big tv and it was as if my tv turned into a painting!+ Story: Halucinating instead of dreaming. Purrrfect!+ Gameplay: the concept is rather simple. Platforming and battling. The battle style is a bit comparable to the legend of Zelda. (Don't expect a legend of Zelda wannabee though! The games are not similar, I was simply talking about the battling system.) For me it sometimes felt a bit repetitive.+ Puzzles: too simple! It could have taken this a step further but it didn't. It was a bit disappointing.Overall score:I don't like to put a number on a game but I'll tell you why I liked the game. I liked playing it because it was equally beautiful as it was a t(h)reat to my (in)sanity. But if I need to be honest with myself it feels like the art and the story need to compensate for the gameplay and the puzzles. Even though it was enjoyable, it sometimes felt a bit repetitive and the puzzles were a bit simple. In the end I'm glad I bought the game.(If you really want a number, take 7/10)

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												A sequel to the old American McGee's Alice from way back in 2000. You don't need to play the first game really but it adds to the whole story and atmosphere of this game. For those who haven't played the original you'll have to buy it online or on a console since it is not on steam. The controls are OK. The camera seems a bit too sensative and doesn't move enough at the same time. It's hard to explain but while playing the Mad Hatter level you'll see what I mean. Jumping and fighting from the original have been improved. You can jump 3 times and glide now. There is a lock on system but you use caps lock. Not too bad but it gets annoying trying to press caps lock because not many other games use that button. The design of the areas are all designed very beautifully and uniquely. It doesn't feel like they swaped a steampunk pallet for a forest pallet. The levels and enemies seem to fit each of their environments and every level seems different. The creepy atmosphere from the original travels well over to this game. I would reccomend this even if you haven't played the original.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												tl;dr Great atmosphere, good story, average gameplay. Good for a playthrough. Pick it up when it's on sale next.By far, the most striking thing about the game is its art and atmosphere. Everything feels as off-kilter as a Wonderland run through a trauma filter should, from the dodo-powered machinery of the Hatter's hijacked tea factory to the utterly peaceful, yet utterly terrifying heights of Cardbridge. Each world is absolutely engrossing and sprinkled with details, making you wonder just what strange, horrible wonder is waiting around the corner. The music is suitably downbeat and chilling, picking up with heavy drums during combat, while the occasional string piece brings it all together with Victorian Gothic flair. The character designs are wonderfully macabre, with many returning characters receiving updated designs as befitting of Alice's vastly altered mindscape, and the voice acting is strong. Of particular note is Alice's ever-changing wardrobe; each dress aptly reflects the environment she is exploring, and each appears to have been designed with great care. Each dress also gains a unique gameplay modifier on a second playthrough, such as the Steamdress rewarding more Teeth (used to upgrade weapons) and Roses (the resident health item) from breakables or the Royal Suit limiting the health bar to four Roses.The story itself is similarly strong, albeit flawed towards the end. About a year after Alice's release from Rutledge Asylum at the end of the first game, Alice has found herself under the care of one Dr. Angus Bumby, a psychiatrist helping her to forget her past trauma. However, all is not quite right in Wonderland as once thought, and she finds her world being besieged by the Infernal Train and the Ruin, monsters of oil and machinery. She must return to her once-again fractured world to find the source of the corruption, unravel the mystery of this new madness and save her mind once more. The trickle of clues throughout the levels strings the player along fairly nicely, however it feels as though a few too many important details are left as collectible memories rather than presented at key points in the story. My primary gripe with the plot, however, comes in the last two or so hours of the game. Quite a few sudden revelations happen all at once, especially during two key segments towards the end, and coupled with the fact that some of the clues leading to these revelations are, as mentioned before, left as collectibles that could be easily passed over, the reveals felt jarring.Now for the game's primary issue: the gameplay itself. Now, the game isn't bad by any means. The platforming feels quite smooth, though at times shoddy camera angles can make some jumps harder than they would normally be. Largely, however, this is offset by the fairly generous and forgiving nature of the jump and glide abilities. Combat is relatively simple, with four primary weapons to choose from: the fast-but-weak Vorpal Blade and Pepper Grinder and the slow-but-strong Hobby Horse and Teapot Cannon. While fights can be a smidge on the easy side at times, stringing various combos with the different weapons, or landing a deflecting block with the Umbrella, is satisfying.  As a little personal plus, I liked that you couldn't acidentally dodge roll off of platforms; given the size of some of the platforms you fight on and how far you dodge, it would've been all too easy to launch yourself into the abyss if you could. However, the gameplay is repetitive, repetitive, REPETITIVE. I'll admit, on my first playthrough, I really didn't notice it all that much; the atmosphere and plot were plenty engaging enough and I was so interested to see what was coming next that I really didn't pay it much mind. It wasn't until my second playthrough for a stream, and particularly it wasn't until I reached Tundraful and Deluded Depths, that I started to recognize the patterns of the levels: Platforming segment, pull some levers, a Shrink Sense here and a Clockwork Bomb there, combat, repeat. Occasionally, there are mini-games found in the different chapters, but some (the Off with her Head game, especially) become incredibly tedious. While there are hidden collectibles and Radula Rooms (challenges) to be found just slightly off the beaten path, they don't do much to break up the feeling of linearity. The Deluded Depths and Dollhouse levels, in particular, feel as though they drag on for days.My biggest issue with the game, though, is that you can see just how much more American McGee and Spicy Horse wanted to do with the game. Missed opportunities are EVERYWHERE, with the most egregious being the lack of boss battles. Each chapter has perfect setups for end bosses, but in the end, they all quickly get handwaved away and you're shuffled off to the next bridging London segment with no real payoff. A lot of features found in the beta trailer, like the expanded London segments and the ability to swim through the Deluded Depths, would've been more than welcome, the London segments especially; London would've felt more like a proper setting in its own right than as simply a bridge between Wonderland visits.In the end, though, I can't say I didn't have fun with the game, and its art and atmosphere are truly wonderful to experience. It's a shame that the gameplay doesn't quite reach the same quality, but it's by no means a bad game; it's just not really one you'll want to play through more than once. If you're looking for an aesthetically-rich world and don't mind the gameplay being just alright, give it a look.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Alice Madness Returns caught my attention due to its graphical style. After playing through about half of the game, collecting as many secrets and collectibles as I can find, I have an opinion on the game as a whole.As I said, I love the visuals, the models still look great and the scenery is timeless. Not every part of the game is equally gorgeous though. After completing a part of the game, the game puts you in an underwater environment. The visual appeal of this part is underwhelming when compared to the part you just completed. Another thing that bothered me about that part is that the physics didn't change at all while underwater. But even if this all felt unnatural and a bit underwhelming, parts of the level still got me interested. The next level I was dropped into was equally awesome as the first.The story and the unique and interesting characters really add a lot to the experience. Every character in the game is memorable in some way. Even the enemies have a memorable look. They're not that hard to kill most of the time, but can provide quite the challenge when attacking in groups and do require you to be fast with the controls. The biggest challenges lie in the side missions though, so you don't have to face enormous hordes of monsters when playing through the main game.After all this positivity, we need to talk a bit about the negatives, as there are quite a few.Some parts of the game feel a bit rushed. Enemies placed in awkward spots that render parts of their behavior useless (example: an enemy that can only be defeated by returning it's ranged attacks is placed in a spot where he's not capable of firing shots). This can get really frustrating. The fact that if you die from damage, you have to redo a part of the game doesn't help either. The game also suffers heavily from random crashes through all of the game. One moment it works smooth, the other it closes down without any clear reason. The controls are sometimes fiddly as well, but this does not pose a major issue.To make it run smoothly, you need to apply some tweaks, such as unlocking the framerate and fixing a bug with the umbrella.After all, Alice Madness Returns brings a compelling adventure that still holds up to today's standards in it's genre. It's well worth it's somewhat high price. The collectibles really add to the game as well. They're fun to collect and provide a nice bit of extra story. I would recommend this game to people who like games like Rayman, 3D Mario games and old platformers alike.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is a rather unique beast of a game. I never found the jumping and fighting incredibly fun (Although it can be a little fun sometimes), the keyboard and mouse controls stink, the game has some optimization issues, sometimes the jumping is wonky as well as the game having frequent loading times. On top of that, the game runs at 30 fps unless you hop into the config files and change some stuff, which is a bit bothersome.Despite these issues, it's still one of my favorite games I've played in a long time. The story, the view on Alice's mental state, and the presentation of this game make it all worth the trouble. Wonderland is a broken mess, and so is Alice in a lot of ways. Wonderland is falling apart and a destructive force is barrelling through the land, tearing everything apart and threatening to destroy Alice mentally. Meanwhile in Victorian London, Alice struggles with finding answers to her family's death in a fatal fire. Frequently, Alice slips between London and Wonderland, switching between trying to find answers from people she knows, and looking within her memories, respectively.Weaved through all of these events is an odd mix of disturbing and beautiful environments that you'll be jumping through and fighting all sorts of nasty beasties in in your search for the truth. As the game goes on the environments become more gruesome, further signifying the slippery slope into madness.Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone who enjoys an interesting story and more interesting art. The platforming is alright, the combat is sometimes pretty fun, and the aesthetic is incredible. Just remember to look up how to unlock the framerate and use a controller.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2016
												TL;DR: Pretty, if extremely boring game. The pacing is horrendous.Alice Maddness returns is a sequel to 2000's American McGee's Alice, which itself was a sequel to the 2 books, Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass.Too bad the game is boring as salt. There are ... 5 or 6 levels. Each levels last 3 hours. You simply get bored of simple platforming, followed by shallow combat, followed by platforming, followed by combat.The upgrading system is a joke. The levels are not even sufficiently twisted enough to keep your interest engaged.  The story  is barely there. The performance? Fine, if you are not using Physx. The effect is pretty I guess.END: Boring game, with huge pacing problems, uninterested combat and platforming sections. American McGee's Alice was a much better AND twisted game. This? Play this if you have time to waste I guess.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Much like the first game Alice is crazy and of course the best treatment is to kill everything inside fantasy worlds in her mind.It starts off abit conventional but as the game progresses the environment get more inventive. Gameplaywise its a third person platformer mixed with some melee fighting and to a lesser extent shooting - occasionally the game throws in a different formula tho. Of course theres hidden story and"just because" collectibles and this time you can upgrade your weapons with "currency" strewn about. The levels stay largely linear, the main difficulty increase is in the jumping sections/puzzles - the fights never are that difficult unless you really dont explore and therefore have weaker weapons i guess.The not so great things are :a) Origin account required, altho you just log in once to register, no need to have it openb) Its a bug free game but (and thats a big but) the developers either didnt bother or werent that familiar with things like "keyboards" and "properly programming key rebinding". If you use an xbox pad or keep with the default key bindings all will be dandy but start changing controls and all sorts of♥♥♥♥♥♥start to happen like commands plain not working anymore or directional keys being strafing and turning at the same time. Prepare to google and fart around with .ini files like its 1999.Still heartily recommended, its a fun platformer with great visuals and gameplay and i daresay a must-have for anybody who liked the original.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												Review Excerpt:"Alice is an action adventure platformer with puzzles and a definite story aspect as you play as Alice who is fighting through the madness that grips her own mind and Wonderland both. The game does a fantastic job of relating the random madness that is prevalent in Wonderland already and twisting it to make you feel the stark lunacy that has gripped the world. But is it Alice’s madness, Wonderland’s or both?The gameplay is about what you would expect from a platformer such as this. The game does support keyboard and mouse, but I recommend using a game controller if you have one as it will make things a little easier for you. Sporting surprisingly smooth gameplay for a 5 year old title, I found the controls very familiar and intuitive and I had no problem sinking my teeth into the rich world that is offered here."Still a very good game even 5 years later. I have not had a single moment of regret and have recommended it on my channel. See my full impression here:


YouTube™ Video: Almost First Impressions:  Alice Madness Returns 

			Views: 3		

			This is my gameplay review of Alice, Madness returns. A very dark, and yet interesting look into the universe of alice in wonderland.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												This game is truly magnificent, but a bit of a pain to control through PC. I've played this game through PS3 before purchasing it on Steam and it was really easy to play through it, even on Nightmare Mode. It's much more difficult to control on PC for some reason, which makes it a bit irritating.This game isn't one for challenges, but if you enjoy a great storyline and beautiful graphics, then I definitely recommend you get this game.There are a few setbacks though in order to play this game. First off, you need to have an Origin account in order to play this game (because of EA). I myself had no problem logging in since I had an account previously, though many others claim to have issues registering. Not sure how they solved that, but it's worked for me and another friend of mine who has with this game. It also asks you for a product key, which Steam provides you, and that part is easy as well though it's something else people also complain about not working. Hopefully when you buy this game, you don't get these issues.There are many bugs that exist in this game. I had to replay the first chapter a few times simply because the umbrella wasn't working when I needed it to and certain events weren't being triggered after completing a few tasks in order to move on. I found that this was actually because I had changed the settings for the DLCs manually that it began gltiching up very badly. So it's kinda impossible to actually have those DLC Dresses and Weapons unless you want to have a very glitchy game and trust me that ain't fun. Unfortunately Steam doesn't sell the DLCs anymore, so buying them is not possible either.The option for playing the original Alice game doesn't work since the game isn't installed into your computer. Even with the game installed (and I checked since I have the original one installed), the option won't work. It was also part of the DLC package with the dresses and weapons, but also unfortunately is not available.Also, make sure you have a decent graphics card. I myself have an AMD Radeon Graphics card which plays Bioshock Infinite beautifully with no lag, but with this game I sometimes get a slight lag, though it doesn't happen very often. Even though this game is older than Infinite, it tends to lag slightly because of all the beautiful graphics and such since it's heavily concentrated on that.Besides all of those things, it really is a beautiful game. If anything, I recommend getting it for console rather than PC, but if this is your only option then by all means I encourage you to buy this game. It may be irritating since the camera is iffy and it's hard to manuever around, but it's beautiful and a great story to experience.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												Alice: Madness Returns is a third person psychological horror action shooter and adventure game, developed by Spicy Horse and is a sequel to the American McGee's Alice game from 2000.In this game you play as Alice Lidell, a girl who mentally suffers from a trauma which is caused by the death of her family. Alice was discharged from the pschiatric clinic and since then she lives in an orphanage that houses mentally traumatized orphans.In the game Alice tries to get rid of her trauma,learns about her past, the truth behind it and and wakes up in Wonderland that is corrupted by an evil force.The story is told by animated drawings scenes, in-game cinematics and in-game documents.Throughout the game Alice hops between the real-world and locations in Wonderland.Alice is occasionally guided by a weird Cat with riddles and hints.Once in Wonderland Alice gains weapons to defend herself from the evil forces. Every monstrosity slain gives Alice teeth to upgrade her weapons and roses to refill her health bar.Almost every level has many things to search for such as secret chambers, memories, bottles, teeth, puzzles, pig snouts etc.Almost the entire game you run, jump and dodge and attack to make progress through the story.Alice: Madness Returns is a game with many ingredients and not easy to label, this makes the game hard to label itself.If you are looking for a wonderful fairylike horror game with magnificent narrating and a high amount of gameplay length, perhaps this game might be something for you!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												most certainly a departure from the novels O.OAlice: Madness returns is a sequel to the 2000 title "American mcgee's Alice", where Alice is driven insane due to her Family dying in a fire. in this game, we follow her story after she have been released from the asylum, but is still plagued by nightmarish horrors in wonderland. the controls are tight and well-responsive, though dogding in lock-on mode is cluncky, because there seem to be a peripheral radius from the enemy that you are allowed to dogde in, making retreating maneuvers alittle awkward. but despite that, the platforming is nicely done to be a moderat challenge for the player, combined with a plefora of enemies that can attack you on both land and in the air (without directly interfering in the platform sections), the weapons and the four deficulty levels (easy to nightmare), there is alot to the gameplay (not to mention the histeria mode). the atmosphere and tone of the game is certainly improved from its predecessor: in AMA, most of the horror Visuals came from the bloodiness of the surroundings and the enemies, while in this game, the horror elements are relying far less on the gore factor and more on the blurring of the lines between reality and wonderland, giving a sensation that Alice may be decending into madness Again. in the same way, the enemies are also given more detailed designes to depick the twisted nature of the new wonderland, though the design for most of the reoccuring characters are carried over from the first game (the mad hatter, the turtle, the chessire cat, etc.). for the design of the humans in the real World, they may look more exaggerated than the residence of wonderland, giving more a sense of isolation from the real World. the game is also generally more colourful than its predecessor, which should take away from the horror factor, but the way it is used actually kind of adds to the atmosphere. the music is far from bombastic or grand, but more subtle and soothing with a hint of the unnerving elements in between, which fits quite well with the rest of the game. during the game there is also acouple of mini-games that is intervowed into the story, which is skipable, with is good since the music ones isn't every precise. but luckily, they only make up a small percent of the mini-games.throughout the game, there is also alot of collectable either in the form of rose paint to increase Health or memories, that tell of certain quotes from different people in her life, giving a good objective to Explorer the enviroment.for all of my praise, I can't say that this game is completely flawless: I have mentioned the problems with the lock-on before, but since it also zooms somewhat more in on the target, when locked-on, it makes the camera more awkwardly angled and harder to see any surrounding enemy attacks.the games story also have a bad habit of teasing us with possible bosses to face, only for the story to abruptly cancel them, for example the first chapter leads up to a confrontation with the  march hare and the dormouse pilotting a giant robot, only for the infernal train to crash into the Facility and destroy the robot, ending the chapter. and that is how it goes for almost every single chapter's ending. the ending is also kind of weak for such a good story, but really open to interpretation. (I will not talk more about it for the case of spoilers). and finally, the music mini-games. the music mini-games have a delayed input-registration making it harder to time tunes (not by normal dificulty, but by faulty game design). and also, they require a full perfect run on three sets, so if you fail once, you have to start all over from the beginning, making it more frustrating with the music mini-games. but luckily, they are also skipable. so overall:positives:+ tight controls+ a broad arsenal of weapons and abilities for both combat and platforming. + challenging enemies+ different modes+ lore-expanding collectables+ good music+ nice Graphics+ good Visuals and designs+ good psychological elements+ unlockable costumesnegativs:-awkard lock-on-trolling us with boss battles-weak ending-music mini-games.overall, if you are interested in a challenging platformer/combat game, interesting visual and story or want to experience a twisted version of the imagination of the Lewis carroll novels with psychological reality-bending elements, I would recomment this game to you. so you are always welcome to descend into the madness with the rest of us >:-)......(just kidding).

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												Alice: Madness Returns took me down the rabbit hole like no other could. I love this version of Alice in Wonderland. It might have caused me to question my own sanity but I wouldn't have it any other way.Practical info:At first I couldn't play the game as I was supposed to play it because I couldn't use the umbrella. It has been confirmed by a lot of people that the game doesn't always want to be played. I tried playing further by using the trick with the rabbitbomb but it was tiresome. I needed a real solution. Buying an xbox-controller for the pc was that solution (in my case).Experience:+ Art: simply beautiful! I played it on a big tv and it was as if my tv turned into a painting!+ Story: Halucinating instead of dreaming. Purrrfect!+ Gameplay: the concept is rather simple. Platforming and battling. The battle style is a bit comparable to the legend of Zelda. (Don't expect a legend of Zelda wannabee though! The games are not similar, I was simply talking about the battling system.) For me it sometimes felt a bit repetitive.+ Puzzles: too simple! It could have taken this a step further but it didn't. It was a bit disappointing.Overall score:I don't like to put a number on a game but I'll tell you why I liked the game. I liked playing it because it was equally beautiful as it was a t(h)reat to my (in)sanity. But if I need to be honest with myself it feels like the art and the story need to compensate for the gameplay and the puzzles. Even though it was enjoyable, it sometimes felt a bit repetitive and the puzzles were a bit simple. In the end I'm glad I bought the game.(If you really want a number, take 7/10)

												Contains spoilers.This is what I would show to people if I needed an example of a game that could have been good if the game was finished.It is obvious that the game is NOT finished, the last level seems incredibly unfinished and the train seemed like it should have been an actual level instead of cutscenes. The weapons were all very unique and you really had to use them all to beat the game. The platforming was a lot of fun and the game seemed solid.If the developers could have (and I'm sure they wanted to) spent more time on it, it could have been much better.5/10

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												Great game but very disappointing ending... They build up a story that deserved a way better ending... Oh well, in my opinion it's not worth the 7€ I payed for it...   There are a lot of bugs in the controls if you are using a mouse and keyboard. Most of the times dodging is absolutely random: it doesn't matter what direction your trying to go. Jumping? omg... At the beginning of the game it works fine, but when you get to around chapters 3 or 4 it gets crazy! Jumping on steam is bugged a lot making you unable to go higher and most of the time when you try to jump out of it you will automatically be gliding, which makes you unable to jump higher with the extra jumps you get. The targeting system is really obnoxious and frustrating, I found myself using it only in extreme cases.The mini games are cool once or twice but they become boring and repetitive easily. I don't want to spoil anyone, so I will not go into details, but if you're like me and like to search for hidden secrets you will encounter a bunch of them. Another complaint I've got is the lack of configuration, especially video options. For some reason I would experience random freezes that lasted a few milliseconds but long enough to screw a timed run or jumping puzzle. It's possible the problem is with my computer, but still... If the game had a better settings menu, you could lower some video settings enough and possibly make it run smoothly. Again, loved the story except for the ending. The atmosphere is brilliant and really makes you believe you are in Wonderland. Beautiful scenery and sounds. I was immersed in all that was going on (except when I was having trouble with the damn controls). There are plenty of hidden secrets to find and in my 17h of gameplay I did NOT find all of them, mainly because I was getting frustrated with the controls during the last chapters. Still, my save file is at 94% completion.  Overall I would give it a 7/10, I really wanted to give it an 8, but due to the problems I had during the last chapters I can't give it more than a 7. This is my opinion and mine alone, if you disagree and didn't experience the same problems I did, I'm glad for you and I hope others won't.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												Hello close friends and strangers of the interwebs.I recently picked up Alice: Madness Returns in a steam sale (Hell, I'll buy anything for $5) and finished it 23 seconds ago.I felt like I had to write a review for this game because frankly, IT'S THE BEST THING I'VE EVER PLAYED!The first thing that struck me getting into the game was the art style. It was simply amazing how bleak and uninteresting everything in reality looked and it's contrast with wonderland, which toyed with my own sanity. as close to everything tested the limits of my own comprehension abilities. I have to say, despite it's 2011 graphics, the style of art managed to almost blow me away with the occasional cutscène being artfully displayed as a puppet show portraying Alice's family's fiery death (charming, I know) Now, after dedicating a paragraph alone to the art style, it's probably time to talk about something else. The storyline simply stunned me, making me unsure of what was real, what was relevant and what was a hallucination which kept me guessing until the very end where it made it blatantly clear that how many memories I failed to collect. With re-imagined, corrupted characters from a franchise which was a part of my childhood kept me interested as this game hacked at my innocence with a rusty axe, this game kept me enthralled for it's entirety.Probably about time to talk about some gameplay. Now, whilst my heart belongs to open world games, I was surprised how much I enjoyed the lack of control I had over which missions my protagonist completed and it what order. It almost added to the sense of complete madness that was magnified by all aspects of this game. As for the level design, it almost felt like there were two parts to this game. The puzzle-platforming segment, which had Alice bouncing from mushroom to invisible platform to pressure pad, and the fighting segment, which had a interesting system of locking onto specific enemies and defeating them using different combinations of light and heavy melee attacks and ranged attacks which include a giant teapot-grenade launcher and a minigun that gives an entirely different definition to peppering your enemies (ADUHDUHDUH). Whilst the combat was comprised of simply mechanics, the creative enemies meant that you always had to be trying different things instead of spamming certain attacks.Alright guys, I'm freaking tired of the emotional rollercoaster that this game provided me, i think it's time I wrapped this up. In conclusion (If you were going to read any of this review, this would be the part)Art style: SensationalStoryline: SensationalGameplay: Sensational10/10 Would recommend.Thanks for reading, I'm George, and I'll see you next time.

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Long game, can be repetitive – definitely maddening.. worth a go if you like surreal games, with odd enemies and an unusual array or weapons. Controlling the character can be a bit frustrating at times as the camera sometimes fixes itself into strange positions and the keys respond relative to how you view the screen not how Alice moves.. e.g. you have to run down a corridor "into" the camera, so S becomes forwards, W back, A/D revert left/right – tricky orientation to play with. Also includes a couple of mini-ingames: side-on and platform games, chess and slider puzzles, and a bowling ball style game which are short but mandatory. Probably best bought during a sale or deal, the full price seems a little on the high side.

												Pros: - A delightful aesthetic ranging from the beautiful Vale of Tears, the disgusting streets of London and the horrifically twisted Dollhouse. The game's visuals are imaginative and a joy to behold.- Reliable controls.- A warped, sad story that held my attention.Cons:- Much too long. While the levels are beautiful many of them badly overstay their welcome and leave me exasperated when faced with another twenty minute platforming section.- Combat is easy to master and eventually provides no challenge. Once you know how to defeat even the strongest enemies - even in groups - it's just a matter of crowd control and keeping out of harm's way. Only boss fight is at the very end.Overall: A beautiful but pretty average action platformer. Got it on sale and glad I played through it. Would recommend for the experience but don't expect too much and you might find something to enjoy.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is a 3D on-rails platformer with horror elements that tells the story of Alice Liddell - a teenaged girl who's suffering from trauma caused by the death of her family in a fire. The player's role is to guide her through the Wonderland, which represents different parts of her mind, to recover her lost memory and find the source of corruption that's been ruining it.In terms of graphics, I wouldn't compliment their general quality as the models and textures aren't top notch, but the general design is splendid. The locations are beautifully done, dark and moody, which creates an incredible effect when combined with the game's psychodelic music. It all creates a borderline horror-like climate throughout most of the game. The imagery may not be as disturbing as for example Yume Nikki, but comes quite close.In terms of gameplay, the player has quite a bit of movement options in his hands, and even more when it comes to combat. Alice can quadrupple jump and float, making her one of the more nimble characters in the history of platformers. She also gets an assortment of different (upgradeable) weapons that she can use to battle the quite diverse library of foes she will encounter, as well as a dodge move which is basically a flash step. She can also lock-on to her enemies and aim automatically. This all makes the combat very satisfying and when you lose, it's usually your own fault, not the control's. For those who feel hardcore enough, there is the Nightmare difficulty which vastly bumps up the strength of enemies, and certain dresses Alice can wear albo make the game harder (like limiting her health). Of course, you can also opt for a low difficulty, if you're a casual gamer. Pretty much the only bad thing is the fact that the final boss is kind of easy in comparison to the rest of the game on any given difficulty.One last thing to say is that this game is not for kids. More thanks to disturbing imagery than anything, really.Overall, this game is a great platformer, with moody, psychodelic environments and very good combat system. I recommend it to both casual players and hardcore on-rails platformer fans.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Alice In Wonderland by way of Tim Burton and Sam Raimi. You play Alice as her memories return and she has to come to term with what really happened to her family in a house fire and the reasons behind it.Within the grimy Victorian seediness lies a fantastic platformer, and one of my all-time favourites, together with the orginal American McGee's Alice. The platforming is regularly interspersed with some surprisingly frenetic combat.You have five weapons at your disposal: the Vorpal blade which is your standard weapon, the Pepper Grinder (read machine gun), the Teapot (read grenade launcher), and the Hobby Horse which is really a substitute for a Sledgehammer. Also the player can also drop clockwork bombs that either uses a timer, or can be manually detonated. Though the fighting can get frantic at times, it is only ever really difficult if you don't employ some kind of tactics. The bomb, for instance, is essential for distracting enemies and overturning crabs to reveal their weak underbelly.The graphics of this game are gorgeous, but they have an 'ugly beauty' about them, inspired by the East European puppet animations of Jan Svankmeyer and the Brothers Quay. The music of A: MR also has a disturbing charm, as it moves between whimsical piano and grungey industrial ambience.I can really recommend Alice: Madness Returns to any platformer-lover, but with reservations about the adult themes that run through the game. Also, if activated (my Steam version was deactivated by default), the language can be quite mature at times, with the C-word used once or twice.My only gripe with this game, and it's not the only game to be guilty of this, is doors shutting behind the player, thus closing off parts of a level without warning and without the player having fully explored an area. This often means completionists need to replay levels to get pickups they missed. Surely some warning that going through a doorway, or moving into an area, will end the level isn't too much to ask?Apart from that, Alice: Madness Returns is a great old-school platformer with some of the most creatively inspiring environments I've ever seen in a game. Weapons are varied; Fighting frantic but fun; Lots of collectibles; Soundtrack is awesome.Always been a big fan of this game: 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Alice:Madness Returns is a terrific if flawed sequel to the original. As a narrative, it picks up the story where it left off in the first game and intelligently brings it to a conclusion. When it's over, you fully understand why Alice was driven to her madness in the first place, a reason much more sinister than simply that her family died in a fire years ago. The story is told wonderfully through excellent voice acting in recovered memories and in sequences cleverly done in cartoon cutouts. Alice also communicates with Cheshire Cat throughout the game in the game's 3D world.Visually, Alice is beautiful and a treat for the eyes. The game uses a wide color palette based on the theme of the area she is in, and the level design and art direction are excellent and sometimes spectacular. London itself is appropriately dark and gritty, all done in greyscale, making the Wonderland segments pop more colorfully than they probably really are. Character models are also appropriately cartoony and slightly twisted. The musical score effectively evokes the mood of the game, though it lacks the disturbing discord that the original's soundtrack evoked.The gameplay itself was mostly very enjoyable. The platforming was clever and challenging, and the combat (which there is a lot of) was very smooth (the "focus" or auto-targetting system works wonderfully if used correctly). The game also breaks things up nicely with various themed puzzles and even some sidescrolling mini games that were very fun. While a bit long for a platformer, Alice was nonetheless engaging all the way to the end.There were some negatives that marred the overall experience, some significant. The autosave feature is probably the biggest problem with the game. Since you can't manually save (like in the original Alice), you can only restart from the last checkpoint. The problem is, it is very easy to unwittingly transition out of an area when you still had another path you wanted to explore that might have lead to collectibles or an optional arena fight (to gain HP), and you can't go back since the game only stores one auto save (it does allow you to revisit major checkpoints after you complete a chapter, but you would have to go back and replay several areas to get back to where you want to be). Some of the auto saves are well-placed, but not all, forcing you to redo a jumping sequence for example before you can get back to the mini boss who just beat you. The auto save feature really rears its ugly head in the final boss fight, as it saves at two points during the fight. This sounds convenient on the surface, not having to start the whole long fight over from the beginning if you die. The problem is, you could in theory be down to your last bit of health when it auto saves for the next part of the fight, so now if you die you will always restart from that point at near-death, you can't go back to the begnning. They needed to include two or three auto save slots in the game to avoid this game-breaking scenario.Another issue with the game is the repetitive combat. Too many times in the game must you fight the menacing ruin, for example, which appears in various combinations with other enemies. There are many times in the game where you will run into one and say, "didn't I just beat this guy?" A similar experience happens near the end of chapter 2, where you defeat a mini boss called the drowned sailor, only to meet another one on the other side of a gate, then have to go inside three separate buildings to beat three more of them. This kind of gratuitous combat served to needlessly drag out the game and produce too many moments of "Oh, not again."The bottle collecting in the game is rendered almost pointless because in order to unlock what I believe is additional concept art, you have to collect every bottle in each chapter. Unfortunately, I was always a couple of bottles short of the dozen or so I needed to find. It would have been nice if they unlocked "some" of the content based on what you found, instead of making it all or nothing.Lastly, I found the jumping mechanics to be a little off, making some of the jumping sequences needlessly frustrating. Mainly, Alice would many times drop like a rock on the third jump in a three-jump sequence no matter how dextrously I hit the jump key, and this also happened a lot when hitting the jump key as she was hitting the apex of an air plume or off a jumping mushroom. They needed to fine-tune this, the jumping mechanics should have been much smoother and more forgiving.Overall, though, Alice is a fine sequel and is a must-play if you wre a fan of the original. Even if you aren't, it is a solid platformer and a very unique and original experience.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Done. *Sigh*… this was hard work. At the end of the day, I liked the game. The artwork is nice and the action-jump-and-run-mix is one of my favorites. I like the adult story, which is wrapped in the “Alice in Wonderland”-theme. But I’ve one big problem with this game … it’s way too long. In my opinion, you can see that the game is purposely stretched, after ca 2,5 hours of gameplay. Unnecessarily long jump-session or the 2128th wave of the same enemies you have to kill, supports this theory. This was the first time I felt slightly bored, but then the designer present you the first feature (like some sort of puzzle, etc.), that you don’t see too often in gaming. Little did I know that this feature was torturing me for over 2 hours, again and again. On the first appearance I thought: “Oh, nice!” but after the 3rd or 4th time I only could think: “OH MY GOD! MAKE IT STOP!”.At this point I was suspicious about every upcoming feature, because it was going to hunt me for hours like the first one. After that, I was not only bored, but also annoyed.Please, don’t misunderstand me! It’s not a bad game and I think it’s really worth playing. The story is very good and contains a big wtf-moment, when everything is explained. But I also think you should know before the purchase, what lies ahead of you.  Sometimes less is more. ;)

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I'm not the kind of person who writes reviews for anything, but I feel like people should know what they are getting into BEFORE they make the decision to purchase this game.First things first:1.  I chose not to recommend this based on the game-breaking bugs.  The plot is fantastic so far, and the worlds are gorgeous.  No gripes on that.2.  Read the EULA. Apparently somewhere in there it mentions you MUST log in to an EA/Origin account. I didn't do this (I usually don't), and at my own expense--but I've chosen to ignore it partly because I wanted this game that badly.  I hate EA/Origin but for this game I tolerate the (so far) seemingly one-time login to EA/Origin. 3. If you are not great with understanding how to tweak the files of a game (even minimally), DO NOT waste your money.Further Elaboration:I have no idea who's at fault for the coding here, if I can even call it that, since I've never once had to do this in my life beforehand, or else be forced to give up on a game.  But within three hours of gameplay (at least one of those hours letting it idle on my computer while I looked up how to FIX the damned thing), it has become quite apparent that the game exhibits several crushing, game-breaking bugs. The first (and so far, only game-breaking one I've witnessed) of these bugs happened to me when she picks up the umbrella to learn to block (NOTE: YOU CANNOT PROCEED FURTHER UNTIL SHE BLOCKS).  I understand it that if you don't change the standard controls (which, by the way, are utter crap for controls) that there shouldn't be any problem. Well, this was not the case for me.  I tried several of the fixes, most of which were people condescendingly talking down to others like, "You know you have to focus on an enemy first, right?" Yes, obviously, thank you, AND IT'S STILL NOT WORKING! I also, obviously, tried to reset the original controls or assigning them elsewhere to no avail; so I was absolutely stuck and could proceed no further in the game.I finally found a video on youtube explaining that the spacing between the command words in the .cfg file AliceLayout (something along those lines) is so freaking messed up that the umbrella use simply WILL NOT WORK unless you go in and manually space everything yourself. That's downright ♥♥♥♥ing annoying, folks.  I'm not being paid to clean up somebody else's mess.Other glitches include Alice running while nothing is being pressed (cut-scene glitch of some kind), Alice not spinning/floating/jumping properly while in mid-air, and the Giant Stomp (which I have not encountered since I'm not far enough into the game) not working.  Supposedly manually editing the crap-excuse of a .cfg file fixes these problems, according to those with more expertise on the issue.   The problem with altering said file, however, is that it could break the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of your game; which is why, typically, only those well-versed in such things do this--and why I hope I NEVER AGAIN have to try and manually tweek files.  That said, I REALLY WANTED TO PLAY THIS GAME! The fact that it's an older game means there's no support for it--and like EA would ever give support anyways--I recall the ♥♥♥♥♥torm I went through with SimCity 5 and Origin. Bottom Line: If you are prepared to face the hardships and challenges that await you, Alice: MR is very captivating and so far seems to be worth my ten dollars.  But all that said, I just cannot recommend a broken game to the general population.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2016
												Lets get this out of the way with first. I love this concept. Super dark Alice In Wonderland who turns out to be literally insane; yes, just yes. While the concept is superb, the gameplay and story is different. I'd say it's rather boring to play and pay attention to after 3 hours. This game plays like a normal 'hack n' slash', just lacking a variety of combat related moves and combinations. While I came across many different items and upgrades throughout the story, it still always felt I was repeating myself a lot. Not to mention, the enemies feel awkward to attack at times, often feeling like they aren't living beings, repeating the same animation over and over again, not responding differently to different attacks. While the story is rather interesting to begin with, with Alice describing her urge to go insane, I still have to say the story seems quiet. By this I mean; dialogue seems forced, but not important at the same time. Whenever the Cheshire Cat talks, his dialogue just doesn't fit in with the situation. The same could be said with other characters in hub areas.There isn't much to say about this game. I wanted to like playing it, but there's just a lot missing. It feels unfinished. While the graphics are nice, with vibrant colours and varying environments, I just can't say I enjoy exploring the world either. The adventure is missing soul, meaning and likable important characters. Certainly give this a go when it's cheap, but I can't say for sure you'll love it.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												I don't know what to say. Let me compare the pros and cons of this game.PROS+ The story is INCREDIBLE. It's mind-blowing, very complex, and it really affects you. It's not for the faint of the heart, mind you. On the outside, it looks like a fairy tale, but inside, there's corruption and vice of every kind.+ The artwork for this game is out of this world. I really wonder whether the people in Spicy Horse studio are sane people. This is definitely the most pscyhopatic game I've ever seen.+ The weapons are awesome. A teapot cannon to scold enemies? Cool!+ The gameplay has some really crazy moments. You shoot disembodied snouts with pepper grinder, which makes them sneeze secrets and bonuses. Need I say more?+ The soundtrack is amazing. The main menu theme is simply a masterpiece.CONS- Except the first, fourth and last chapter, the game is extremely boring. Chapter 3 and Chapter 5 is so boring, I almost literally fell asleep. - The game is too long. Sometimes you really feel like the developers just ran out of ideas and randomly inserted platform puzzles here and there.- The game micro-stutters and sometimes freezes, but this may be hardware-related, I'm not sure.In summary, this game has an incredible potential, which is wasted by very poor and extremely boring gameplay. I suggest this game ONLY if you have too much time in your hands.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												Alice Madness Returns is the successor to American McGee's Alice.The Story is about Alice Liddell. She suffers from a trauma which effects hear reality.She often goes into the Wonderland. She suffers from this because of a fire in her family house when she was young.She lost her whole family to this fire and therefore suffers from the trauma. But something is different. Her Wonderland suffers from destruction and madness. In the game she figures out what really happened in the night of the fire.Pinpoiting the game to 1 Genre is nearly impossible because it has so many different ones.Jump & Run, Hack & Slay, Puzzle, 2D, 3D, Action, Fantasy, Horror.I rarely seen a game with so many different influences. I really enjoyed it. The game got never tedious because of this great variety in gameplay. But the main aspect of the game is the Jump & Run and Hack & Slay gameplay. She has to pass several levels. To do so she has to jump and run, fight against monsters or solve riddles and puzzles. Or sometimes just explore the world. I really like the fighting system. Its really addicting for me because it has a learning curve. The game might be difficult to new players. I in fact died very very often when playing this game the first time. What helped me was a controller though. I dont think mouse and keyboard work well in this game. You have several weapons to attack the monsters like a blade or a pepper mill machine gun. You also have to dodge the attacks of the enemies either with an umbrella or just vanishing and appearing somewhere again. This game definitely needs skill! There are also many secrets and collectibles in the levels which are fun to explore and collect.The whole game runs on the Unreal Engine 3 and it looks really beautiful!I rarely seen such amazing designed worlds. Especially the PhysX effects give the game an own touch.However, those can be quite taxing. Not even my GTX 970 could maintain 60FPS on High PhysX settings.I only had like 5% of the game slowdowns or whatever so mostly it went totally fine. Sadly the game suffers from some annoying stutter from time to time. Like all 5 minutes it hangs for a sec and then continues playing. This is not that bad and I got used to it. I dont know what exactly is causing it. Maybe the texture steaming system of the UE3 or PhysX or even EAs badly and horrible implemented copy protection.Postive:- Very nice and diverse gameplay- Interesting Story- Never gets tedious or boring- Addicting fighting system with learning curve- Beautiful designed worlds and artwork in general- Stunning PhysX effects- Nice and fitting soundtrack- Nearly totally bugfree, even without any patches, since none have been released- Limited Edition content can be activated with an easy ini edit- Steam version automatically unlocks the game on EAs Origin aswellNegative:- Some small performance and stutter problems- Annoying EA copy protection which needs an EA account- The Steam version misses additional content like the American McGee's Alice HD version.Check out my guide to obtain the HD versionRating: 8.5/10I really enjoyed this game. In fact this game was one of the best of 2011. It was totally underrated by gaming magazines for whatever reason. The art design was just so beautiful and sick at the same time. This game is not meant for young people! I mean it seriously.Also make sure to check out the first Alice. It might be a bit dated but its just as beautiful. Wouldnt mind a remake of this one!

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												One of the weirdest and probably the most creative game I've ever seen, this is pretty good, but it is not exactly phenomenal. It has great controls, great sound, awesome crazy graphics, interesting crazy enemies, awesome weapons, awesome combat, and gorgeous graphics. It is weird and ♥♥♥♥ed up akin to the likes of a Nine Inch Nails video because lord knows Trent Reznor is a ♥♥♥♥ing weirdo. It has great sound: on my 5.1 surround sound speakers it sounds great: the sledgehammer horse pounding into the ground makes my floor vibrate and the peppergrinder machinegun blasting shots off sounds like booming thunder. One of the coolest things about it are the weapons and how they act and look when you upgrade. You get a butcher knife, a hobby horse (like a sledgehammer), a pepper grinder (machinegun), and a boiling tea kettle (like a grenade launcher). Their graphic effects and attacks change as you level them up, becoming more and more cool looking. It is also pretty long, around 15-20 hours or so, which is a nice change because most dumbass SP games are barely over 8 hours anymore. The art design is amazing. It really is a great looking game. It's definitely worth its $20 price tag, and a must buy if you can catch it on sale. Also make sure you google how to easily remove the 30fps cap for a far more enjoyable smooth 60fps experience.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2013
												Re-review. The game runs on UE3 and that's both a good thing and a bad thing. The good thing is the visuals are great. The bad thing is it's buggy and still to this day I hate the engine's habit of not pre-loading the textures. For a split second, Alice looks like a lip-less pile of flesh on the main menu. Game runs at 31 FPS by default and you must tweak the ini files to get 60+ FPS and unlock on disc DLC. Clear signs of this being a direct console port with no love for the PC crowd. Game is very buggy and the devs never bothered patching the game. How about you patch your existing game before going to kickstarter for that third Alice game, eh, American?Story is interesting but the acting is spotty. Not sure the awkward voices were intentional. Art is very impressive with some gothic feel. However there are some areas that look bland. Gameplay is okay but some areas are too repetitive with lengthy platforming sections that basically lets you do the same thing like jumping on mushrooms, entering keyholes and switch levers.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												A good linear RPG with combat similar to the Zelda games.  Combat isn't as good, nor is it open world, and not nearly as many weapons although there are multiple upgradeable weapon choices for both ranged and melee, and you can toggle ranged weapons while they are on their respective short cooldowns.  The graphics aren't terrible or great, but the atmosphere is wonderfull and the art is fantastic.  I'm just under 10 hours in and a little under halfway through so it seems like the game will be decent length if you don't blow through it.9/10ProsEnough weapons to keep combat interestingArt/scenary is fantasticCollectibles to findPlenty of secret places(not always so secret)Quadruple jump-Makes the platforming easier if you have issues with thatFloating-See aboveConsLinearMost of the combat isn't too hard but some fights I found wayyy too hard for how the rest of the game isGame can be pretty forgiving usually, if you die you respawn close, not always the case and some parts you mess up a jump by an inch and youre going back pretty far just to fail again.TL;DR If you were already interested and would like a linear somewhat zelda combatlike RPG worth the 20 bucks easily, and at the very least pick it up on sale.  I can see myself replaying this again, not right away, but Im not uninstalling and putting it down for good.  I dig the art too much!
