content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I absolutely loved the art design and music of the original Alice.  But AMR has a game breaking flaw that occurs for a lot of players.  Early in the game she gains access to an umbrella that is used as a shield to block incoming attacks.  All fine and dandy except that it is impossible to use in the standard keyboard/mouse setup.  That's  what happens on a lousy port from a console to pc. You could probably plug in a controller in your computer as a workaround but I felt so burned I never even bothered to check.  This was a known issue after the fact but no one, not Spicy Horse or EA, could be bothered to patch it.  Way to support your game, American.  Never again.

number of helpful: 8 of 17 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												American McGee's Alice was incredibly popular for what it was: a generic third-person platformer/shooter. What made it stand out as a true joy and masterpiece was its phantasmic, whimsical art-direction and devious atmosphere. It is natural, then, that a sequal must either improve on the original's platforming, or at the very least give us "more of the same" of whatthe original does best. Alice: Madness Returns continues the trend of giving players a fantastic atmosphere and art style, but the gameplay is so atrocious that this game is hard to play, let alone reccomend.The Good:* Absolutely stunning and interesting visuals, probably some of the best I have seen for a console game. From the backdrops, to the costumes, to the platforms, to the character models, everything about this game is ocularly incredible.* The ability to shrink at any time is a great idea and is fun. However, I think the developers missed a world of opportunity to really make the game shine with this mechanic. I was hoping for something like Tiny-Huge World from Super Mario 64 - the opportunity to explore a world from an entirely new perspective.The Bad:* Bugs encountered: red mouse pointer stayed on screen while playing after navigating a menu pop-up, one tooth (the game's in-game collectible) dropped but could not be picked up, sometimes auto-aim would randomly turn on while using the ranged weapon.* While Alice performs actions, such as turning a steam vent on, she is vulnerable to attack. However, you have no control over her for several seconds during this time.* When you start a new area, you will always jump down to it from a high-up area so that there is no "going back." This also seems like lazy level design.* In one area where they could not use an invisible wall, the power of Alice's double-jump is purposefully nerfed so you can't reach a certain platform early.* The collision mechanic when Alice walks into a wall, or jumps into a column or something, is a good effort but feels awful. Alice sort of "glides" past the obstacle rather than actually interacting with it. It's as-if Alice has some sort of anti-magnetism that does not allow her to physically touch objects.* I get better FPS while in the game than while in the pause screen. What's going on with the pause screen?The Ugly:* Bad mouse control/aiming while using the ranged attack. My view was always being whipped around every which way because the computer thought I ought to aim in a completely non-sensical direction. I have a $100 mouse and this game won't let me use it.* Invisible Walls. They are everywhere. Even in places where the developers don't need them. even in front of Alice-sized holes. EVEN IN FRONT OF PLATFORMS DURING JUMPING PUZZLES.The Verdict:Playing Alice: Madness Returns will certainly make your eyes very happy, but it's a mess of a game and not worth $20. I do think you should pick it up if the game is on sale, though, just to check out the amazing visuals.

												Sadly not a patch on the original American MccGee's Alice. A perfect demonstration of how even a truly great game can be turned to @**% by 'consolizing' it. Pos -- Graphics refresh looks good..- Story still seems quite interesting, and at least at the begining has a little feel of depth...Mixed - - Uses the same old difficult platform + mulitple jumps trick that can leave you taking an hour to cross a small and annoying section.Neg -- Stupidly difficult in stupid places, and not for good reasons.- Very crude clipping planes in places.. levels frequently leave ways through which you could fit through but you are not allowed to use them. Also places where scenery clipping leaves ugly holes behind scenery..- Controls kill you when fighting or jumping, camera view skews and you die, get caught on scenery and you die, lack of fine conrtol in jumping & moving when fighting - and you die.- Definite console feel to game - and not in a good way..- Just doesnt quite have the 'charm' of the original.

												This is a good game, that is plagued by bugs and errors, mainly caused by EA's DRM. First off, why does EA need DRM on an offline single-player game? Second, since it's published by EA, there's no cloud saving via steam. And on Origin, cloud saving doesn't work at all. I've lost my save file twice because of this. If you like platforming games with puzzle thrown-in, I definitely recommend it. When it DOES work, the game is fun. Controls are smooth, combat is similar to Legend of Zelda with it's targeting system, you upgrade your weapons by collecting teeth(similar to the red orbs from the God of War games). I recommend getting the game, but you're probably better off buying it on xbox360 or PS3; those versions might have fewer bugs.

Posted: June 12, 2016
												I hated this game. Environments were interesting at first, but dragged on and became boring. Combat is fast but clunky and unbalanced. I think once I got the ranged weapons, I didn't use any others and just upgraded them because they were more useful. Camera control is really bad. The story tries its hardest to rewrite the previous game's story. Game promises cool boss battles but doesn't deliver as it kills them in cutscenes. Texture work just wasn't good. There wasn't much enemy variety. It kinda seemed like there was more work in the player character then ANYTHING else.I'm never touching this game again.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Don't get me wrong - there are moments of true brilliance, both visually and in terms of script, in this game. This is a propper arthouse game, no doubt about that. But to experience it all you must grind for hours and hours on end. The length of this thing is ridiculous. There are five chapters there. Sounds reasonable? Not so, unfortunately. The length extends enormously, because you will die/fail and retry hundreds (literally!) of times. When after a series of lengthy action/platforming sequences you think that you're finally at the end of the chapter, you're usually not even one third way through. The change of scenery helps combat this, but everything brakes down again when you are  forced to stay in the new environment for much longer than is actually required. This is irritating as hell. And the emphasis on arcade-like (and even 2D sidescrolling!) timed jumping - mind boggling. There is no proper feeling of flow at all here.Sure, if you're a hardened gamer specializing in third person action games, get this game. You should have a blast! But if you are not (I myself have 20 years of experience, but mostly in first person action games), think twice. And if you do buy it, don't even contemplate playing it on anything but the easiest mode. Developers of this thing should point their attention towards regular people next time and get rid of this tedious platforming and trial/error based mechanics of grinding out enormously drawn-out levels.BTW, Steam says I'm 13+ hours in (actual number may be even higher, as usual), but in the game, I'm about 50% done. So for me this is a 25-30 hours game, and that is way too much for a story driven linnear action experience, imho.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2016
												It's an alright game, 6/10 maybe. The story is good, albeit very dark.The reason I don't recommend this is that this game is mainly repetition. Chapters are insanely long of platforming. The game was charming for the first 3-4 hours, by after that, it becomes tedious. Chapter 5 in particular, is ridiculously long. 2 hours of no story-telling and simply jumping and jumping and jumping until you finally get the story bit.I completed it on a fast pace at 10 hours and the last 4 were painful as I only wanted to finish the story. The gameplay is good, but combat is, again, very repetitive. Later enemies are made uncessarily difficult, and the camera, dear god the camera, it's awful. It will random lock unto things. More than once you'll die to a platform when you jump > jump > glide and then teh camera shifts and you can't see where you're going.Pros:-Really good story, good story-telling-Unique atmosphere-Unique ArtCons:-Gameplay is REPETITIVE-Combat is made gimmicky to be challenging, mare worse by awful camera and targetting system-Camer is AWFUL-Gameplay is VERY repetitive-Platform areas are made stupidly long as filler, don't be surprised to go 2 hours of non-stop platforming, puzzles, etc... with no explaination and interaction. You'll sometimes see the cat, who will tell you something funny, then it's another hour of jumping and fighting for no reasons. It's supposed to represent Alice's broken mind, we get it.It's as if they tried to make us go as mad as alice.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2015
												It's okay but wasn't as fun as I had hoped. It has some nice ideas but is too lengthy with too little variety and bored me throughout numerous parts. It lacks difficulty and challenge and playing it can feel like a tedious chore. I got used to the looks of each level quickly. You change between reality and Wonderland scenes in a predictable succession. They can appear initially impressive but everything submits heavily to the basic mechanics. There isn't much feeling of consistency or meaning, the levels are cluttered and lack elements to excite you with. One could end in a minute and the other in hours and it would still amount to the same. Sometimes while platforming you change without too much of a warning between various graphical dimensions and visual styles or even have the game turn into a sidescrolling shooter. Some of these sections fit the themes of the levels they happen in nicely and were interesting to witness but gameplay-wise turned repetitive soon. You hardly ever interact with anyone or anything that isn't a mob to slash at but move on and on traversing the always kinda same ways and exploring the kinda same secret passages to unlock collectibles you might care or not about. Having a deranged protagonist explore her mind to sort things out regarding her psyche, her real-life situation and that Wonderland of hers could've offered lots of possibilites to deal with your environments and their inhabitants, and the "interim" scenes of switching worlds were rather interesting but the game dares not to progress beyond it's otherwise predictable level patterns and fundamental platforming and combat mechanics which leaves the rather nice voice actors severly underused as well.There isn't much substance to the characters. They aren't very tangible, they don't have too many lines and when they speak they do it in ways or making references to previous events or characters that can be hard to understand (without being necessarily complicated by nature) for non-native English speakers or when not knowing the book this is based on or the previous game "American McGee’s Alice". There isn't too much of story progression. You're jumping and slashing your way through the mind of Alice, sometimes moving around the real life, facing a predictable twist, some end boss and a relatively vague open end. My ultimate feeling was, I believe, that I haven't accomplished much. There really isn't much I would've missed had I not played this. I dare not go as far as I regret my time with this game but I wasn't particularily enthusiastic about it either.What is nice is how monsters (visually; the combat never becomes too diverse or interesting) and Alice are designed. The latter has beautiful hair and clothes (in grim Gothic style) flutter around (I suggest manually unlocking the otherwise hidden dresses DLC content) and the game makes pretty heavy use of NVIDIA PhysX which leads to very realistic and impressive particles and puddles of black goo one main set of enemies leaves behind.  The game is by default locked to 30 FPS which I advise fixing via some .ini file as mentioned by other reviewers because it makes the game look better (some menus load more smoothly then as well). That aside, within the context of its gameplay/story/characer limits, the game works techncially nicely and is pretty foolproof. So if you can forgive its repetitiveness, have the patience to go through it and don't expect any great story or character display you can still have an experience of something.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Just as a cautionary point to those considering buying this game: if you don't like the control scheme and key bindings, I'm afraid it's hard cheese for you, because though you do have the option to change them, doing so can cause a multitude of malfunctions in-game. For example, if you change the button that activates the umbrella block, the umbrella block may just stop working altogether even after defaults are reset (unless the game is quit and re-entered), to name but one.Disregarding this, the game does tell an engaging story set in a "corrupted" vision of Alice's wonderland, which seems to exist entirely in her own delusions. A continuation of American McGee's first foray into the realms of Lewis Caroll (which I admit to not having played), this game makes many references to the game that preceded it, but not in a way that makes it impossible to gleam at the events that took place in said predecessor, making it an adequate starting point in the series. All in all, the world this game portrays is very absorbing, but you may find difficulty in being absorbed if the aforementioned control problems become annoying (which they easily can).

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												I was really disappointed in this game.The premise seemed promising, you would think that it would be a nice dark take on the Alice in Wonderland franchise. For its age, it's pretty alright. The movements are fluid enough, the constantly changing outfits and new weapons were interesting, and the story has a good concept. But it has some serious issues. It really ruins the atmosphere when you're constantly getting stuck to the ground, having Alice nonstop walk without my hand on the keys, and monsters glitching so they don't take any damage. You don't become very compelled to continue as the story has barely any development. Most of the voice acting is pretty good, but you will find characters or lines that just sound corny and out of place. The puzzles are challenging enough, but very repetitive. I really want to recommend this game, and I would if you're okay with all of the issues I had. The character design is unique, the premise is interesting, and if you love Alice in Wonderland you'll at the least tolerate it. If you're on the fence about it, wait until a sale like the summer or winter sales. It comes down to $5 and at that price it's worth it.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												Overall:As a game it's a failure. The art and premise are rich and provocative, but the gameplay is boring and repetetive. The overarching story is nice but it's stretched thin across the 8+ hour gameplay. Damn you, lack of funding. Great to play if you want to write fanfic or immerse yourself in the universe, but not if you want an actual fun game.The good:-ArtThe art style is gorgeous. They executed a twisted wonderland marvelously, and there are many imagination-stimulating environments and objects. Alice herself is extremely well animated and rather fun to move around, even in "reality."The character archetypes are fun to think about. Just the whole idea of a more mature, twisted Alice in Wonderland is fertile ground.-SoundIt won't be winning any awards, but there are a few tracks that are interesting. The voice acting is generally of high quality.The bad:-StoryThe writing is subpar. The characters mostly feel bland and unendearing. The dialogue sounds a bit like what an average american would make up if you said "give me a sentence that a british person might say".The story itself lacks depth. It's a kid's story that was sprinkled with some superficial violence and edgy imagery to make it look more mature. And even those played it safe. They were too few and far between and just... arbitrary. Their grotesque form had no purpose or story or meaning, it was just there to be grotesque. Most of the wonderland parts just felt empty.The best part of the story was the London sequences, but every time you get a little morsel you have to go through another an hour+ of boring gameplay.-GameplayWhen you get to a new area you're at first wowed by how cool the environment is, but you quickly get tired of it as you go through the repetetive task of killing monsters and collecting teeth. Combat is mostly mindless. Once you've figured out how to kill a type enemy, the rest are a chore - not difficult, just time consuming. Increasing the difficulty only makes monsters do more damage.Then there's the platforming. It's extremely easy. You can triple jump, but you never even need the third jump unless you ♥♥♥♥ up.The game is extremely linear. Side paths never last longer than a few seconds and then you double back. Finding secrets consists of remembering to press ctrl every so often. The secrets do nothing besides give you bits of dialogue that don't really add to the story much and increase your % completion on the menu screen.Oh right. There are puzzles. They're trivial. Also, you get some weapons. They're not very interesting either. Upgrade them with teeth. Once you've upgraded them all the way the teeth are worthless and that will happen well before the end of the game if you collect them zealously.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												American Mcgee showed the world how a story could turned into a dark, twisted material to read and/or play with his 2000 platformer, American Mcgee's Alice. - and after eleven years, he published the next installment of his Alice series, Madness Returns. Now, this is actually an undone product due to the same story as always; Publishers pushing deadlines over Developers. - Alice: Madness Returns is actually a game without its boss fights, because of this. And, again, because of the same reason; The Publisher; It can't get patches to actually put boss fights into this lovely game.What makes Madness Returns a unique game is majorly the intriguing storyline it has to offer, alongside with beautiful level designs, overall atmosphere/ambient and the sad, smooth, disturbing soundtrack album from talented names. - With the mixture of intense gameplay, level-based dynamic mechanics and a twisted sense of humor, Madness Returns offers more than just your regular, repetitive action/platformer game.On a side note: I was about ten years old when I first played American Mcgee's Alice and after eleven years, the moment I've got my hands on this game, I was living a dream once more.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Pros:+Amazing art style and idea.Well, that sums it up for pros, now consSo, cons.. yeah:-Lets start with worthless PC port, shall we? 30 FPS lock. Barely any graphical and other options. In-game menu seems to be slow for some reason. While it's playable with keyboard, some parts of the game are not. Also, some button prompts are shown for Xbox controller, while it is not connected. This may lead to a quite frustation.-It is, needlessly long and repetitive. The combat, the platforming, even plot elements seems to repeat themselves every chapter.-Game also constantly fails to tell you some key moments, which can get you stuck sometimes.-Most annoying and plain stupid minigames, thankfully, some of then can be skipped, but, unfortunately, not all of them. Seriously, did they actually think that it would be a good idea to throw in some qte, puzzles, 2d platforming or even pinball arcade !@#$ in the middle of an action? I can hardly imagine.-The secrets are met so often, they become generic. Even worse, finding them don't seem to reward you in any way, shape or form. In fact, they make you take longer paths, which result in major waste of time. Well, sometimes you get enough stuff from secrets to upgrade your weapons, but you can do it without secrets. You can, however, upgrade your health via secrets only. But, you have to find so many, and it give you so little, you would not want even bother in the first place.-Countless bugs and glitches. It's just terrible. Sometimes you have a cursor appear in game for some reason (they even multiply), other times Alice just starts running forward after cutscene or loadscreen and dies horribly in first pit.. yeah. Some invisible walls that you always hit every once in a while, some stuff glitch through, some enemies getting stuck in walls and you can't get them out, so u have to restart checkpoint. And so on and so forth. Countless, really.Overall ~ I would love to like this game, but I can't. It caused me too much pain. It could have been a good.. no, amazing game, assuming the team had a decent programmers and level designers.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Freaking amazing! Love it! The scenery is fantasticly wonderous and everchanging. The mysterious eerie feel of the game really captures and keeps interest! Totally got me hooked! The puzzles are very well designed and everything feels so wierd. You will not at any point in the game feel comfortable and you will feel on the run even in relatively peaceful places. A total rush. I would highly reccomend a controller to play. (the keyboard controls gave me trouble and are so difficult to pick up) The only thing I would complain about is how the camera tips back and forth and every which way when in combat, even when focused. It feels a bit awkward and takes getting used to. Other than that, fluttering and twirling through the air, bouncing on mushrooms, and discovering broken memories are sure to keep the game fun and interesting.  If you love a good puzzle adventure this is for you! (If you can handle the mind-mangling wonderland of course...) 9.5/10

												Published by EA, made by a bunch of Chinese, no offense.The most annoying part during the whole game for me were the terrible but seriously. Horrible hitboxes.This made the game harder then it actually was.Besides that, the target switching when focussed was annoying too.Also not knowing wich way to go, either it's the next step forward, or a secret level.And sometimes you'd skip secrets knowingly you thought they were the next step to progress in the game instead of a secret, vise versa. content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												THIS game... is probably one of THE BEST games i've played in such a VERY VERY long time.  Such a cynical and heart wrenching story. The Game is long and can be VERY VERY difficult if you play it on the hardest difficulty. there is a learning curve if you are not use to hack n slash games.The story is very very in depth if you can find all the secrets. The environments are also very much eye candy, i just can't get enough of this game, i just want to hug Alice! it's beautiful, i'd give it a 10/10with replay value? i have no idea, i haven't beaten it yet only at 44% on Nightmare difficulty. I got on today, at 42% and played for 1.6 hours and i only got 2% farther... this game is hard... not because the enemies hit you like a truck but it's because of the situational fights they give you that makes you have to find a strategy to win.The fighting is also unique in some ways, being able to upgrade your weapons and ocassional puzzles, platformers and sidescrollers. This game is definitely worth the money!

The developers have done a great job of the game itself.But... it really sucks that this game requires that you register and login to another Steam-like UI. I purchase games on Steam because I want to play them within Steam's ecosystem; it is really disappointing that this game goes against the grain and tries to bring along an entirely different system.Almost everytime I go to run this game the other launcher UI asks me to sign in and I can never remember the password that I came up with for that account and end up not bothering to play it. content:
Posted: March 21, 2012
												Things I liked about Alice Madness Returns:- Different outfits for different worlds. It's the small details that I appreciate, and Alice has plenty of them. Just excellent !- The visuals are some of the best I've ever seen (but the voice overs could use a little work at times).- Skippable puzzles. I don't play chess, never have played it and don't intend on learning it so I was pleased to see that I could skip these puzzles altogether.- Big worlds- Enemies really do require different weapons and tacticsThings I disliked:- It outstayed its welcome before it was over. Meaning it was overly long (yes, there is a thing as 'too long').- Hitboxes were a disaster. There are times where you jump and crash into a barrier that isn't supposed to be there yet, where you slide, hit NOTHING and still get hit anyway and more silly things like that.- The camera isn't always working properly.Just a great action platformer, but with some minor, annoying, flaws.[Rating: 75/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 14, 2016
												5/10Not a very good game. While visually interesting at first, the polish and freshness runs out in the first half hour or so, and  the game turns into endless copy pasted envirnments. The screenshots above are not representative of the game as a whole, and that trailer is even worse. While I'm not one to gripe about graphics, the character models look and move like ps2 era npcs. The game also runs fairly poorly, with freezing and frame skipping on a regular basis, and whenever anything chaotic happens the game slows to a crawl. The enemy designs are not particularly varied, and the main type of enemy is repeated ad nosium, the only variants simply being bigger versions of the small ones. The plot is virtually none existant, and isn't communicated much to the player except through vague and incongruently drawn cutscenes. Perhaps those who played the original (or prequel? the relationship is unclear in this game) game American Mcgee's Alice would get more here, but as for this game on its own, practically no story. Voice acting gets irritating very quickly, especially the main npc's like hatter and march hare, and a lot of the clips sound like they don't even belong in the game (muted or too quiet, jumpy breaks between lines). The voice actress playing Alice sounds incredibly bored the whole time. Game play is straight forward and gets stale very quickly, and the few minigames end up being tedious. Platforming is not great, as alice's jumping mechanics are hard to control. A section around the middle in the souls locker area is particularly tedious thanks to the bad controls. Overall, a great first thirty minutes, but it overstays its welcome beyond that and becomes a generic, gray hack and slash. Might as well just play God of War or any other game with this exact formula. TLDR: In conclusion, gray and generic.  Best parts are the menus and the first two areas. Runs like crap with bad controls. Mind numbing and time cocnsuming as it goes on, even the characters are bored. In a word, Mediocre.

												At first I thought it will be a great story. Perhaps it is.Then I was amazed with graphical design. Not just graphics but artistic touch which makes the game remarkable. Models are great. But it seems like even decent machine is not capable of running it with good details - optimization neglected?When I fell of the cliff for the first time it was wonderful. I didn't know yet how much I will hate this 'death' animation. Then I started to think - why do I repeat this jump. And again. And again. Because I really want to get there to check that item... Yes... Do I? Another place looked like a reachable one but it was not. Bad move. Get back for the same series of jumps again.It is neither "adventure" nor "action", not even "platformer". It is damn arcade! And this twists whole experience and ruins possibly great game. And it changes my vote to one huge "NO!".Furthermore EA account is necessary. Unnecessary DRM, spying and God knows what else. Avoid.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Excellent and engaging combat set in imaginative and dazzling worlds, with a marvellous soundtrack. Marred mostly by tedious and repetitive level design, frustrating camera and enemy lock-in issues, and a bit rough around the edges with regards to bugs and smooth controls. The minigames are a bit crap, too.It's a dark, twisted little number with flowery writing and a fairly interesting, if predictable, story. The graphics aren't too bad but clearly aimed at consoles, but little features like Alice's hair and dress flowing as she moves adds a nice touch (I believe the game was a bit of a tech demo for Nvidia's hair rendering tech, but it looked nice enough on my AMD card).If there was more emphasis on combat than platforming (The latter is so easy you'll be hard pressed to ever be challenged by it), I'd have probably enjoyed it much more, especially with the potential of enemy combinations they could have had.Still, recommended, it's charming enough that boring and linear level design is at least eclipsed by good combat, writing, and art direction.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												I really wanted to like Alice: Madness Returns, and I do like some things about it. The story is a dark and deep tale of a young girl with a shattered mind. The characters, both real and imaginary, are compelling. The art dances back and forth between hauntingly beautiful and terrifyingly grotesque. Unfortunately, the game falters when it comes to combat and level design. The combat is exciting and visceral in the earlier levels but quickly becomes a hassle as the lock-on system allows off-screen enemies to repeatedly assault you with lunges and ranged attacks. Meanwhile, the level design is outdated, completely linear, and relies heavily on a small handful overused mechanics. Oddly, there is an interesting "shrinking" mechanic that seems to have a lot of potential, but never evolves beyond fitting into small holes and finding invisble platforms. These glaring flaws aside, there are also more than a few bugs - especially in later levels. If you can look past these issues there is a good game somewhere in there, but overall, Madness Returns just feels unpolished.

												This game blends beauty and darkness in an awesome way.  The story while veiled behind the events of the game is subtle but disturbing. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Hands down the best game I've played all year and most definitely one of the best games I've played ever.American McGee has made an incredible comeback with this sequel. I fondly remember playing American McGee's Alice in high school but Madness Returns is volumes better in all aspects of concept, storyline, graphics, and gameplay. This game takes on more of a platform concept which incorporates plenty of jumping, twirling, and floating in the air. This is a beautiful psychological horror game with jaw dropping artwork and a very developed storyline. It is a highly grotesque game in all the right ways. Mcgee takes an even further step away from the classic Alice prototype and recreates an even more disturbing and grown up Wonderland. The fighting in this game is much more complex than the original and it is gorgeous to watch. The vorpal blade is the only returning weapon, but there are new and more exciting weapons including the hobby horse, which was probably my favourite addition. Alice's outfits change with her state of mind and the parts of Wonderland which she visits. There are "mini-game" sections added throughout that are fun to play. Absolutely brilliant game. Highly recommend. 10/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												Great game. A very creative and dark twist on the Alice in Wonderland world.PROS:-amazing surreal and often disturbing art design-very dark and demented story with many adult themes (this is not a kid's game)-interesting weapons-combat is great-enemies are unique and require different strategies to defeat, keeping the combat fresh-platforming is very solid-lots of hidden collectibles (if you're into that kind of thing)CONS (sorta):-the platforming segments drag on for waaaaay too long, making a game that could/should have been about 7-8 hours turn into 14+, however the story was so good i personally felt compelled to tough it out and i don't regret it-keyboard and mouse controls are not the best but they are playable, i preferred a controller-the game is locked at 30fps, HOWEVER there is an extremely easy fix in the config files that allows you to change it to whatever you want, i set mine to 60 and it never dropped below that (GTX 760), so it's really not a reason to avoid this game-you do have to sign in to your EA account the first time you launch it, but again, not really a reason to avoid this game

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is the sequel to the cult hit American McGee's Alice. This is a game that takes the familiar wonderland and turns it on its head, making it a morbid, gruesome and dangerous place. In this game, Wonderland is the delusion of a disturbed girl who is seeking an escape from her dreary life and forgiveness for her failures. Alice really delivers in terms of striking visuals and an art style that is reminiscent of the films of Tim Burton, but different enough that it doesn't feel like a direct imitation. Alice herself changes in each zone of the game, her dress taking on different elements of goth, S&M or Steampunk attire. Enemies and npcs are bizarre and magical and discovering more of them compels one to continue playing.  The only thing I dislike about Alice is how familiar it feels. It is very much an action platformer at its heart, with Alice taking on the monsters of Wonderland and of her own psyche with a magical butcher knife and a pepper grinder which acts as a machine gun. However, it is a very strong action platformer with plenty of hidden areas and challenging jumping puzzles that make the experience compelling, challenging and rewarding. While the game is in a genre that I feel stopped being intresting in the early 2000s, Alice has interesting enough scenery and characters and a good enough overall story to keep most players interested. It is worth it for the visuals alone. Play this one if you want to play a fun, challenging game that is not too deep.

content:
Posted: June 9, 2016
												An absolute must-play for everyone who likes dark fantasy, horror and a healthy dose of surrealism. I don't know, for me personally, this may have become the ultimate 'Alice' rendition out of all the media that this classic tale has spawned over the years, both style and story-wise. If I think of Alice and what makes Wonderland special, haunting, beautiful, creepy and alienating, I think of images from this game. The story in the campaign offers many familiar elements and also puts a little bit of it's own twist on the classic, but it does so in a sublime way. It is haunting and because of the video game medium, it immerses you in the surreal nightmare of Alice like no other 'Alice' franchise will. The world looks absolutely stunning. The game keeps throwing new cool looking enemies and beautiful environments at you like there's no end. The gameplay is absolutely great too; I really thought this was a really decent action game that can hold it's own amongst the greats. It's addictive and fun to play. Cool enemies and cool weapons. Sometimes challenging, but nowhere really frustrating.  The story is longer than I expected... at a certain point I was positively surprised that it wasn't over yet. They really didn't deliver half work here! A really decent campaign and an awesome game overall. This is pretty much the beautiful and immersive experience that any Alice fan would hope to find.

content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
												Horror, combat, platforming and puzzles all in one.  Now all we need is the movie!Overall very fun game.  I was pleasently supprised.  Some of the levels did get a little long.  Combat is fun and interesting as the game is always throwing different types of enemies at you each requiring a different strategy.  Almost all enemies are easy 1 on 1 once you learn thier weakness but you will find yourself battling numerous easy ones in the middle of a boss enemy or two, or three...and then nothing is easy anymore.  It makes combat a lot of fun.  You have four weapons all of which can be upgraded.  You can also shadow dodge, jump, or deflect projectiles.  Tons of Gore.  Phys X is neat in game.  The game is not scary type horror but more of the sic and twisted kind of horror.  There are puzzles and mini games that are combined into the level progression.  Not any game breaking bugs but I did have studdering whenever the game was loading stuff in the background.  Was slighty annoying when it happend in the middle of combat.Check the Guides on how to unlock the 30fps cap among other things.  Seriously though someone needs to make a movie...

content:
Posted: November 2, 2011
												Alice is a great platformer, featuring fluid animations and dazzling twisted visuals.  The art style of the various "chapters" varies significantly, as does Alice's "dress" which billows with each step.  The world features many characters and some excellent voice acting.  The story can be difficult to follow at times, and also some chapters drag on much too long - my playthrough took around 20 hours which is lengthy for a platformer without RPG elements - 10-12 seems like a better target.  However, I was pleased with the overall experience and definitely recommend it for those interested in the genre.  The PC version features high def textures and Physx support for nVidia cards.  I do recommend that you visit the steam forum to learn how to tweak the game performance - it can make a huge difference in frame rates and visual quality.

Now on being stuck in a tedious boss battle with the March Hare I'm back to feeling it's tedious again.Basically Prince of Persia 3D but with Alice. Generally worth the bother if you like that sort of game and it is mostly fun and creative (love the EyePots and the Pepper Gun), but they could have cut out some of the annoying autosave nonsense which makes more difficult sections a drag when you've died and then have to redo half the section again!

												Are you a little mad? Perhaps you consider yourself to be as mad as a hatter? I must confess that this game is great and that you are missing out. You're running out of time, friend. Hurry it up! If you don't buy Alice: Madness Returns, then how will you ever experience the crazy happenings in Wonderland to save it in time? What do I mean? I don't have time to explain, but Wonderland is being destroyed! 'Come Alice, don't dawdel. You've already missed the train!' Have you forgotten that Wonderland needs you? We will give you a bloody knife, a pepper shooting projectile weapon, a hobby horse, or anything else you desire so long as you come and help us! Are you crazy enough to buy the game? Well, we all are a little mad.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Absolutely love Alice: Madness Returns. This is a sequel game from American McGee's Alice where we are forward several years later into which Alice Liddel is forged into a orphanage run by Dr. Bumby (a powerful man who manipulates children's minds in to forgetting their own past by destroying their present which Alice slowly realizes on her own). The game takes place in the early/mid 1800's which gives the area of the game a dark Tim Burton affect as well as how the character's look with a slight cartoonish look to them. The game by far is absolutely beautiful with it's graphics and with the whole story all together. For a game that was made in 2011, its graphics were far above fabulous. What I like about this game is that it get's harder and more frustrating (rage-quit effective) but is hard to stop playing with the story tagged along with it's graphics. The only complaint that I don't like about the game is some lag in the movie cuts and in some parts of the game where some tutorials are being explained but that shouldnt stop you or anyone into having such a great time with this game. Another thing i would like to mention is that this game is rated "M" for a reason because of sexual inuendo's/influences, slight drugs, and tons of violence so if you are not comfortable with any of these i would not reccomend it since Alice: Madness Returns is a very dark and disturbing game to play and some people can't handle it while others like myself can handle it. For those of you who haven't heard of American McGee's Alice (which I didn't either after looking into this game) it is OKAY! The sequal explains everything that happened in the last game so you don't have to worry spending a couple bucks on buying it (it was made in 2000 so the graphics were a little choppy but still a good story). Now the last thing I would like to say is that there is a huge possibility of Alice: Otherlands becoming a third installment to the Alice Series but also the last since the series has been running for quite sometime. It will either be turned into a Mini-Series sold on DVD or BluRay or another video game (which I am happy for either production). So if you love the Alice Series i'm sure you will love what is coming soon. I rate this game a 9 1/2 out of 10. (9 1/2 because of some lag but other than that there is nothing to complain about!). Now do yourself a favour, get this game because you won't regret it!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2012
												In American McGee's Clive Barker's Archer Maclean's Alice: Brown Returns: Chapter IV of the Hoopz Barkley SaGa, Alice has grown up and decided she will only play mature games for mature gamers such as herself. You'll explore dozens of exotic locations such as a mushroom forest, an ice level, a castle, and Tim Burton's Beltan Zipper land, all of which have been delicately roasted to a nice golden brown hue.This game manages the rare feat of feeling long enough to be tedious, but short enough to leave you feeling unsatisfied. Though perhaps your enjoyment of it will be heightened if you first read "Alice in Wonderland" and "Through The Looking Glass," and play "American McGee's Alice," as the game seems to expect you to. You did do that, right?

Posted: September 7, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is a very atmospheric, Burton-esque game that bears resemblance to the old glory of the Medievil series. Good longivity, challenging platforming sections, an intricate fighting system and rewarding collectables are the strong points of this game. The only downside is that the emphasis is strongly on platforming. Some sections are quite hard, which may lead to irration and even rage quitting. Nevertheless, a terrific action-adventure.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												If you like Psychonauts, then you're likely to enjoy Alice: Madness Returns; (in fact, there's an easter egg that gives a nod to Psychonauts in the Queen's Castle). Like Psychonauts, it's a highly stylized action-adventure platformer with amazing characters, story, and level design. Two warnings however:1) The combat can feel a bit overwhelming at times due to the number of enemies and the not so great lock-on system and camera. 2) Parts of the game are a bit twitch/reflex heavy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												If you like Psychonauts, then you're likely to enjoy Alice: Madness Returns; (in fact, there's an easter egg that gives a nod to Psychonauts in the Queen's Castle). Like Psychonauts, it's a highly stylized action-adventure platformer with amazing characters, story, and level design. Two warnings however:1) The combat can feel a bit overwhelming at times due to the number of enemies and the not so great lock-on system and camera. 2) Parts of the game are a bit twitch/reflex heavy.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												This is one of the games I wish steam had a neutral rating for.Pros:Theme (Traveling through Alices shattered mind.)Atmosphere (Nice and creepy, and each area has it's on feel to it.)Visuals (Decent graphics with a unique style to them.)Animation (Combat animation seemed fluid to me. Her hair sure has more animation that I expected.)Costumes (Different one for every chapter it seems, one makes her look like Wednesday Addams.)Story Cons:Gameplay, honestly just this but it's enough to have me not recommending it. The combat gets repetative since there only a few enemy times per level and only 4 weapons. The collectables feel pointless, in the beginning I'd hunt them down, by the middle I would get them if I could and at the end I was ignoring them completely. Even the memories are usually only a character from Alices life saying a single sentence or maybe two when you pick them up. The game seems like jumping puzzles and some hack n' slash wedged into a story. It felt more like the gameplay was a chore you had to do to get to the next bit of story, because the gameplay itself doesn't seem to tell much of the story.Also the multijump function in the game screwed me over even when I did know what to do for the puzzle. You can jump in mid-air to gain height but if you don't do it at the perfect time she just spins in the air staying the same height, multiple times I watched her twirl right next to a ledge she was only maybe 2" under and then fall to her death. The side scroller bits in chapter 3 were really bad for this, trying to jump on a tiger statue head that's shooting fireballs at you only to barely fail the jump and get shot in the face.I enjoyed the feel of the game, the creepy atmosphere was really well done, if the gameplay elements don't sound that bad and it's on sale I wouldn't be against someone picking it up. But for full price I don't think it's worth it, for me the gameplay just didn't live up to the rest of the games elements.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												After Finally finishing his game, Here are my thoughts.This game is focused on a girl named alice which she is recovering from her family's death from a house fire which people around town say was a "accident" by a cat who knocked over a lamp, she belives someone else might have cause it, By going through her mind's "wonderland", meeting strange characters all messed up from the orignial fairy tail, collecting memories and shooting pig snouts with some pepper. You'll find the truth to who actually killed your family!Pros: Good visuals, good level designs and voices. actual good story. Dresses that not only make you look good, give out some abitities to make the game harder or easier. New game plus +, allowing you to carry your stuff over if you decide to play again.Combat is good as you have weapons for different enemies, who are fast or may have high defense.Collectables.Cons: the game has a frame cap set at "30" and you want to increase it by checking out the guide.Some dress and weapons are locked for some reason and you also need to read the guide to unlock them.The game rarely, but sometimes freezes for a good 2 seconds before resume. Camera shifts a bit funky but doable.(Ending was a bit strange, but you decide on that one!)Over all it was a fun and good game, it had those moments where you felt, alone, scared, One moment everything is all nice the sun is out, birds are chirping and boom it gets all scaryand dark!,(like the under the sea level, those poor fish...)  Also its not all just about combat, but exploring, jumping, platforming, finding hidden items and solving puzzles. If you didn't know a puzzle you could just skip it if your not the puzzle type. Also Razputin from psychonauts is there, go find him, he's been wanting to "pick a bone" with you. ;)I give it a 8.9/10, pick it up when it's on sale I recommend it. Have a good one lad!

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												If Alice In Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass were written with a crazy touch of irony and satirical comedy, this game is full crazy and nothing more, taking the story of the famous Alice Liddell where the previous entry (American McGee's Alice) stopped.New and old shadows lurk in the broken mind of Alice and you'll have to guide her down the Rabbit hole once again to take on a journey that will uncover the most secrets truth behind the poor girl's family tragic death.The game is stunningly beutyful, with landscapes reflecting the constantly mental change of the main character, reflected upon the Wonderland.If you're a youngster, play it as a beautyful adventure.....if you're an adult, well, there'll be some harsh and bitter bits to swallow along the road, as the thematics will carve deeper and deeper in the abyss of the human nature the further the game progresses.My final vote: the game is simple and funny, an action platformer, with an awesome taste for art and dialogues loyal to the previous game and the books. Still it has some technical flaws, but nothing unbearable.8/10

												Think what you want about American McGee as a character in the gaming industry, but his vision of Alice is at least as good as some of Tim Burton's weaker moments.  With a crazy art style, this twisted approach to a nonsensical tale is only hurt by the same problem I find in most third-person action platformers: camera frustrations during close combat and jumping.  I recommend you turn the beautiful graphics down until they don't stutter, use a controller, and set the combat to easy.  It makes a world of difference.

												Art - Droll - Jump - Smash - Hack - Slay - Jump - Fall - Jump - Fall -Jump - Fall - Jump - Land - Jump - Land - Jump - Fall - Back on the Platform - Rage!This game is wonderful and it gives you the ability to become one of the most interesting characters in the gaming-industry: An psychotic female underage/teenager with morbid thoughts and the will to destroy her inner emptiness after seeing her whole family die in the hellfire that was taking down her once so called home (even so everyone seems to be mean to her in the first place - thank you collectible memorys).Now, besides the trouble of getting through the game for me personal (a lot of puking was included, thanks to motion sickness), I really have to say that the game was much easier with an controller. Than again the controller didn't help with the glitchy jumping in this game and you will jump a LOT!The biggest flaw for the game is the endless fights against the endless enemies, in endless stages after endless jumps and endless falling because of the endless problems with the double-jump. It is boring. If it wouldn't be for the great story, I would have never played this for sure.Would I say "Buy it!" Yes/No - Where are my Nes/Yo-buttons?6/10 I do see the beauty, but there is the beast.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
												I had hope for this title. I originally picked this up on sale after seeing a friend play through a level or two and thinking it looked like a relatively fun platformer, and it helped that I am also a fan of the multiple variants on Alice in Wonderland and Through The Looking Glass. But after playing through the entirety of the story mode and reaching the game's conclusion, I was more than happy to be done with it for good.The plot wasn't too complex, though I did wonder if there was anything in the first game that I had missed out on. The story flowed rather well through each of the levels and interludes between them, following Alice as she walks the line between the real world and Wonderland, trying to find out why her visions of Wonderland persist even after she's supposedly "cured" by her psychiatrist. The art style of the levels themselves is fantastic, bringing life to the eccentric and often gruesome aspects of both Wonderland and 1875 Victorian London. Even the combat and platforming elements had a little flair to them, with varying puzzles, multiple different weapons and tools, a triple jump and glide ability, and enemies that follow certain patterns during a fight, but can be defeated in a number of ways.However, I felt the problem with the game was a lack of diversity in platforming elements and puzzles. Platforming didn't get that much more difficult from the start of the game to the finish. Some portions of levels seem like reskins of sections contained in older levels, and though a few of the puzzles were unique, at least half of them were revisited throughout the course of the game. Though the first few hours playing the game were fresh and entertaining, it quickly devolved into seeing how quickly I could finish the rehashed bits of the levels to attempt to move on to something new. There was a level of progression that just wasn't there. It got rather boring fairly quickly, and the repetitiveness of the game is most definitely the main cause of that for me. (The addition of requiring activation through EA as well as Steam was also quite frustrating, as sometimes the game was rendered unlaunchable for periods of time.)Unless you're a diehard fan of either Alice in Wonderland, American McGee, or both, I would not recommend picking up this game.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Do not buy this game, pirate it instead if you really want to play it.Do not make the mistake of accidentally supporting EA.The scenery is excellent, and the art designers did a great job.Gameplay is extremely similar to Assassin's Creed and Devil May Cry.The combat is fluid, but the system is implemented badly, and loss of "focus" is frequent.The storyline is average at best, and character development is mediocre.Area progression is very linear with only very minor deviation from The Path.The soundtrack is terrible, and half the game is literally a 5 second loop of monotonous annoyance.Bugs are frequent, but usually not gamebreaking, although one of them almost completely blocks the main menu with literally a < 1 FPS, but luckily once past it will allow the game to be usable.You will need the product key steam gives you, but EA's nonsense is as usual too stupid to understand product keys through steam.You must first be forced to reset your Origin account details since steam is forced to open Origin dialog, then after you are forced to open the Origin website, and then go in to your account settings to add a game for some inane reason, and after that it will take a few tries to get them to actually accept your legitimate product key. Once your account is reset and your key is accepted, you will then only need to relog into Origin every time you want to play this.This would be a positive or average review if not affiliated with any of EA's nonsense.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												I have mixed feelings about this game. While I loved the first game, and I was looking forward to this one. However it just doesn't attach itself to you as much. And after a while you just get tired of it. On a positive note, the graphics are much better and McGee's imagination is still quite active. But it's lost on a clunky game engine and bad design patterns that ruin the experience. I'd have enjoyed the game much more if not for the bad engine and design. It's got most of the charm of the original Alice but you wouldn't like this one if you did't play the original. For example (spoiler), you get to see the mechanical version of the Mad Hatter, but you're never told why he's like that. They just assumed you knew that from the first game. It doesn't help that it feels like it's just a retelling of the first game (note: I haven't finished the game yet). The first few stages let you get a feel of what the original Wonderland felt like, just like the first game. But they take you into the new Wonderland way too early and they show you what the new version looks like without you getting attached to the original. Unfortunately, the game doesn't have enough charm to keep you playing for long. If you didn't pay the first before this, I suggest you start there. You'll enjoy this version more if you do that. If you did play the first, you could pick this game up on sale, but paying full price for it just doesn't feel right for me.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												The only nice thing I will say, is that the art direction was well done. With that said, on with the rant...The very first problem with this game is the ridiculous EA Login to verify the game. This alone would have prevented me from buying the game if I'd checked/been warned. The level design is maddening. Keeping track of secret cubbies to collect memories was headache inducing. At times, I felt like the whole point was to collect memories and teeth, but luckily for me, the previously mentioned level design made that close to impossible to collect them all on the first go, even being extremely careful. Not that it matters since this game lacks achievements (GRRRRRR!) The Voice Talent was weak. The main character comes off as spineless, which in this specific story makes her unlikeable. Talking about story, for a game this mediocre, a good story keeps people playing, but there wasn't even that to enjoy. I found myself wishing Wonderland would just be nuked into oblivion, just so that she'd stop whining.I constantly felt like I was being sent on fetch quests, except when these happen in other platformers or MMORPGs you at least get some level of satisfaction for completion. Not in this game. Unless your goal is to subject yourself to a Tim Burton-esque Mediocre Platformer, stay away from this game.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
												Hi guys! Well I've been playing Alice: Madness Returns for now 17 hours and I've just begun the fourth chapter, I would have prefered to finish it before publishing my opinion about it but I can't help warning you now, all the more since if you've played the whole first chapter you can consider you've played the whole game...A few months ago a friend of mine showed me the trailer, saying "Look! A dark version of Alice In Wonderland!" and I was like "ahmagad I must get it!", and it was indeed the first game I bought on Steam. I was about to regret it very soon.First impression, I was amazed by the universe and the landscapes, and more than anything the representation of madness and the new interpretation of Alice, which keeps the main elements of the Carrol's version. Let's be honest, the cathedral train, the steam punk-like chapter, etc, were pure artistic genius. I was also pleased with the gameplay, which I found pleasantly fluid, and was a good point for me as I'm a beginner with PC games. The fights were cool, in short it seemed to be a really cool game.But now I'm in chapter 4 and I promised myself I would finish it, but my word, I'm so bored! I've never played a so boring game in my whole life! It is way too repetitive, seriously, it seems like they kept the same paterns through the complete game and juste changed the skins. You almost always fight against the same three or four kinds of ennemies, who never get harder, and in each level you have a puzzle that can be solved by an eight-year-old kid, a long slide where you can catch more teeth (the sort of money you use to improve your weapons) and platforms, platforms everywhere, moving platforms to make it more difficult to reach, just like in games for children - and I know what I'm talking about, I played Monsters & Cie on PS when I was six and there were all these elements. It's just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 3D platform game (and I hate 3D platforms, I die more often by falling than in the battles) dudes !I still play Alice to relax when I'm tired but the developers have been really lazy (except the ones who created the graphics), I'm really disappointed and I think you'll be too. A beautiful wrapping but definitely empty...

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												My interest in this game was piqued, paradoxically, by the IGN review. You know, the one that gave it a 6.5 which, by IGN standards, meant it wasn't worth playing to them? They're main complaint was that there was an overabundance of invisible walls, and I found that sufficiently idiotic to be interested. I have no past experience with American McGee's games so I was looking at Madness Returns with fresh eyes. All the screenshots I saw as I looked into it made it look more and more intrigueing, but at the time I wasn't really interested in this genre. Fastforward to the 2013 Christmas sale, and I finally got around to buying it. Boy did it ever live up to expectations. I have simply not played a game with as diverse an atmosphere, as creative a world, and as well-realized a story.Let's start with the atmosphere. I think many would be tempted to say that "dark" is the atmosphere here. While that is a prevailing theme, the method of presentation of that theme varies significantly between each of the worlds. From the slight perversion of the Vale of Tears signaling things to come to the oppressiveness of Hatters domain to the heavy, heavy irony of the Deluded Depths, this game uses every trick in the book to convey the same message.What message? Well, that's simple: "Something is seriously wrong."Every world feels incredibly distinct and dear God is that ever refreshing. None of the worlds really feel borrowed from anywhere else, and because of the distinctness from every world that came before it, starting a new level is a true exploration. Some of the levels are just awe inspriring, both when you first see them and while you're making your way through them.As for the story, it may seem to be somewhat hamfisted at first glance; the somewhat melodramatic voice acting, the comic book cutscenes, and the over the top characters. But once you start hitting the ends of levels, that all changes dramatically.The keys you find to your sanity begin to unlock the subtle turnings of the story. Obviously, without giving any spoilers, let's just say that a story of this magnitude and gravity has very rarely ever had the dubious distinction of being attached to a video game.Most writers in this industry would have beaten us over the head with the plot twists, having the characters wallow in their self pity, all  while stripping everything resembling a truely grotesque detail. As an example of everything this game DOESN'T do, I need only point to Bioshock Infinite's handling of racism with kid gloves. Every punch that game pulled, this one delivered with follow through and, while the subjects being covered were dramatically different, they were also so much more pertinent, so much more dangerous, and ultimately leagues more risky.Through level design, art, characters, and dialog, this game accomplishes a hundred times more towards elliciting an emotional response than any other game I've played outside of an RPG.Of course, no diamond in the rough is complete without some rough edges. Though I absolutely loved most of this game, as the game reaches the end, several nuisances within the combat system become major irritations, then progress well past that into infuriations. Auto-targetting is almost useless except against very specific, and powerful, enemy types and, in a very misguided effort to increase difficulty late stage, the developers intentionally exploit this irritation to make combatting those powerful enemy types artificially harder. This culminates in an end-boss whose PITA Level I have never seen equalled by a game of this quality.Though that issue and the overall repetitive nature of the enemy types towards the last third of the game can easily be explained by EA's ceasing of funding, that really doesn't change the fact that combat is at best more boring and at worst actively angering in this later stage.But it is still absolutely worth it to play through to the end. When those answers are finally given, even if you'd figured many of them out already, the result is a terrifying resolution to a plot that NO other major publisher would touch with a 39 and 1/2 foot pole.This is something only Spicy Horse is giving you right now, and for all its faults in the late-stage gameplay department, I have no reservations about recommending this game to anyone not completely brainwashed by the media's hype-machine.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												I really wish I could recommend this game. It does have a great athmosphere and setting. The story seems okay. That's where good ends, unfortunately. The gameplay is quite repetitive, and a lot of the originality that was in the first part is missing. The controls are absolutely awful (console port, yay). Playing the same part over and over, not because it's hard, but because the controls make you do something else than you wanted is terrible. Even aiming with the mouse is so nasty, that they added a key to focus on an enemy. Obviously you'll always focus on the wrong one, and you have to tab through them to even shoot in the right direction. With some of your moves (that more or less chain together involuntarily) you can't control where you're going, so expect walking into enemies, or not being able to get away while shots fly at you.So - if you like to have that console gaming feeling on PC (press random keys and restart until you win), give it a go. Otherwise, stay clear.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Why do I play console ports? They are so often frustrating like this game. The controls are mushy and imprecise; the camera causes problems in fighting, and the save points are so poorly chosen that I have twice immediately quit out after restarting the game because I discovered I had to re-play a section that I had completed before quitting (there are no manual saves because this game's save system sucks). I really love the Alice stories and the gothic spin is great, too, and I remember enjoying American's first Alice game. But the gameplay here is frustrated by the controls, the camera and a save system so bad as to render the game an unwelcoming chore. Mushy combat coupled with wonky camera and jumping/timing puzzles; fun! The voice for Alice is a bit off, too, but that is so minor a complaint I feel bad making it. Damn it, I really wanted to like this game.That's it; I'm boycotting EA games. Not just because they are evil but because their games just frustrate me more than the reviews would indicate. I used to deduct 20% from a game's rating when it was made by EA but now I'm just going to assume the reviewer was paid off or played the game in one two-hour sitting. Oh, and the intro movies last forever. You can edit the files to get to the start screen about 20 seconds quicker but this the 21st century, we should be past that.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												I wanted to really like this game, I did. I came into it after hearing some of the negative reviews and thought, "Well all the negatives they stated probably won't bother me" because they were all about dated graphics and whatnot and I really don't care about that. I thought the game was actually quite beautiful at times and I enjoyed the graphics and art style for the most part. The biggest issue I had with this game is it just overstayed its welcome. While the story was interesting (I enjoyed the slower story moments the most) there was just way too much that didn't progress the story at all and just had you doing the same basic tasks over and over. You'd do some platforming, fight some bad guys, find some secrets, then repeat. There are a few different enemies, and new enemy types come in over the course of the game, but once you figure out each enemy pattern the majority are relatively easy to fight, if you can get the lock on to work that is. The lock on system works for simple enemies, but when faced with a boss it tends to hurt you rather than help you. The lock-on camera is locked in a position so if you move around an enemy you'll find yourself having to turn it off just to let the camera fix itself, or else you'll dodge straight into an enemy attack. Other than the lock-on feature, the combat is generally pretty fun for awhile, it just gets old once you fight the same enemy type over an over for a few hours. The game is also pretty linear, other than a few secret areas (which are for the most part are all reached the same two ways). You'll find yourself going exactly where the developers want you to, with invisible walls blocking anything that may look like a chance of exploration. The invisible walls contribute to my last major gripe, the game feels clunky and outdated. This includes the animation, controls, and mostly platforming. Alice can't climb edges, so if you make a jump and just one toe is below the platform, ledge, etc. you wanted to get on, you plummet straight to your death.All in all, I wanted to recommend this game, at first I was very content but after awhile the feeling died down and I found myself playing it just to beat it. The game does have a good story, and the art style is pretty cool, but everything else is just overly monotonous and extremely disappointing.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2014
												Sadly I do not recomend this game. It is a nice idea etc etc but unfortunately there are some technichal issues which took away from the game so much that I had to  force myself to play - not something I really look for in a game.For example, I found myself having to redo many of the platforming elements again and again simply because it was difficult to understand when certain controls would be usable. In other words, when you jump the double jump was slow to respond and the 'dash' would not always work. Additionally, the camera control left something to be desired as I was often left with the impression that I really couldn't predict where I would land. In a platformer this is frustrating and I wasn't left with the impression that my failures were related to my level of skill as a player.The other issue was that the scenary was annoyingly glitchy. It gave the impression that they used big cube-shaped coliders which didn't always fit what the game object looked like. In other words, there would frequently be massive twice-Alice-sized spaces between objects yet the way was still blocked even if you became 'small Alice'.Shame really.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												this is my first time playing McGee's Alice, and from my opinion i would give the game 8/10. First impression was good art design in levels(didn't like sea level design), it's gorgious how mix of steam punk and a bit ghotic(Tim Burtoun style) in it give beauty to it. Second, story is very interesting and original, you can see Alice's memory come together one after another which is rempresented in game by a collosal train. Combat system is simple and a bit boring, click click click, shift click click etc. i would really like some combo attacks to be added in game to make it more interesting. Now my biggest issue is lenght of specific levels (3 especially) that can take 2-3 hours to complete and after some time on SAME level it gets a bit boring and you keep saying to yourself "omg is there end to this godamn level). Puzzles are somewhat challenging and other can be frustrating because you have little time to finish them. Now about charecters... Alice here is one BAD MOTHER***** who came to destroyed Wonderland to restore piece and show who is boss here, you will love Alice after you start with levels. All in all i can say the game is amazing but could have been a bit shorter on some levels.this is my 1st review hope you liked it :)

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Alice: Madness Returns is very much a retro-styled title in terms of gameplay, which will turn many people off right away.  The floaty and imprecise platforming is sure to discourage the uninitiated.  The easiest way to review it is to put it in terms of it's previous title.  Did you play American McGee's Alice?  No?  Wait for a steam sale so you're not too disappointed if you hate it.You did play AMA?  Did you like it?  No?  Skip this title completely.  Chances are very good that you were turned off by either AMA's floaty platforming or American McGee's childhood destroying storyline.  Both are still in full effect here.  Even though the jumping physics have been tightened up a bit, it is still frustrating at times.You did like AMA?  You love it, and you're one of those rabid fans that did a happy dance when you found out that your favorite (only?) gothic absurdist horror title was finally getting a remake?  (Yeah, I'm one of those.)  WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR?  BUY MADNESS RETURNS!  NOW!  YOU'RE GOING TO LOVE IT!Hope this helps.

In a platformer this is frustrating and I wasn't left with the impression that my failures were related to my level of skill as a player.The other issue was that the scenary was annoyingly glitchy. It gave the impression that they used big cube-shaped coliders which didn't always fit what the game object looked like. In other words, there would frequently be massive twice-Alice-sized spaces between objects yet the way was still blocked even if you became 'small Alice'.Shame really.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												The game looks absolutely beautiful. Everything from the artwork, level design and animations just look phenominal. Each area really has its own beauty and unique atmosphere.The story is interesting, with lots of colorful characters and more than a few twists. Alice takes quite a few very dark turns as she explores her imagination to escape her real life problems.The gameplay is good although a little on the easy side, with a spammable invincibility move later on. There are a fair share of weapons, some feel better than others, but they all follow the Alice theme pretty well. The platforming and puzzles are pretty standard, nothing super innovative here but still good.Overall the game is good, with only a few hangups. For example, the non combat areas can be a bit restrictive and linear. Would say its a solid fit for anyone looking for an action platformer with a little madness.

												I like this game very much, the story is interesting, chracters are interesting, grahphics is nice, fps is nice. Why locked at that kind of fps?? This is the clear sign of poor console port. The games also contain some annoying bugs, during one of the section, you are granded an umbrealla for blocking the enemy, however, the button won't work at all, you can't block no matter which button you mapped to. Some of the paltforming is kind furstrating as well due to not so perfect jumping mechanic. The game does get a little bit repeatetive, recommended take some rest or else you might starting to hate this game. The graphics menu is a bit limited, only contains AA, Shadow, physx and post processing. You will have to change the rest of the graphics like AO, via config file. Physx looks really good, but as always, kill your fps like crazy, even for Nvidia users, if you have a gpu that barely makes 60fps, recommended to turn this option off.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This is what I call a 10/10 game. Alice: Madness Returns is an amazing puzzle platforming game with a twist of morbid and grotesque enviroments that create a story so painful, yet so satisfying when you complete the game. Unlike most games, this game captivated my atention for hours with it's smooth yet fast-paced combat, excellent dialog sequences, abundant secret locations that heighten the story and, the brilliance behind the artwork. This is the movie that should of been made, not that atrocious remake by Tim Burton. I am sadden that this game only got a 75/100 when the criticism is that it is too long, camera is buggy, and the gameplay is repetitive. THAT IS LIKE SAYING ZELDA IS BORING BECAUSE, IT GETS CHALLENGING THE FURTHER YOU ADVANCE INTO THE GAME. Do not listen to the reviews on metacritic. This is a phenomenal game and you will definitely enjoy what it has to offer.
